title: A City on Mars: Can We Settle Space, Should We Settle Space, and Have We Really Thought This Through?
author: Weinersmith, Kelly*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I probably shouldn't have rated this, since at best, I skimmed the book. In the 1950's, I KNEW I would be an astronaut. I was wrong. But the dream dieI probably shouldn't have rated this, since at best, I skimmed the book. In the 1950's, I KNEW I would be an astronaut. I was wrong. But the dream died hard. I didn't really think about settling down somewhere out there, more like a Star Trek existence. Exploring where no ONE had gone before. That dream had kind of died down, but then we went to the moon!! Over 50 years ago and we haven't been back.... as time went on, I forgot my dream. And really good science fiction, e.g. The Expanse had enough detail that it seemed like a lot of questions and problems had been addressed (or would have been in 200-400 years into the future) which helped sort of keep the dream alive. Not that I would be going - I aged out of the possibility long ago - but I still enjoyed thinking about it. But that's not the same as trying to work it out realistically. Enter the Weinersmiths. Popped that balloon hard. I had actually come to the same conclusions that they do, but I didn't have to face it head on. This book does that and I'm sad. Not surprised, just sad.But I couldn't dig in and finish it because it was too sad to keep smashing my childhood dreams.It seems to be very thorough. So depressing.I guess I never really wanted to have an answer, especially if the answer is no..... ...more

review: OK, I'm not sure what to say about this. It has wonderful elements and some dreadful elements. However, if you are in the market for "playful, yet horOK, I'm not sure what to say about this. It has wonderful elements and some dreadful elements. However, if you are in the market for "playful, yet horrific", this might be for you. I did enjoy it, but I winced a lot. I'd guess the target audience is younger than I am.... that is a bit of an understatement. I think what was hardest for me to take was the casualness of both watching Earth succumb to climate change and at the same time being part of a trip to Mars. I find being part of the first trip to Mars thrilling; watching the Earth burn, not so much. The author really mined it for humor, and sometimes was very scientific and sometimes was describing a cartoon trip to Mars.Lots of points for inventiveness, and overall I enjoyed it, but sometimes... ...more

title: Blood, Sweat & Chrome: The Wild and True Story of Mad Max: Fury Road
author: Buchanan, Kyle
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: First of all, I am not a fan of "action" movies - I honestly fall asleep during the "action" of most movies. I have come to regard the MCU as a colossFirst of all, I am not a fan of "action" movies - I honestly fall asleep during the "action" of most movies. I have come to regard the MCU as a colossal bore. Mad Max - both Road Warrior and Fury Road are just about 100% action movies. But. I think both are masterpieces. In both, I think I held my breath for two hours. When the Road Warrior came out (40 years ago!!) I tried to get some of my friends to see the movie because I thought it was one of the best "see what happens when you destroy everything, humans" pieces of propaganda I'd ever seen. Here's your humanity - little glory, almost all guts - I'd never seen anything to top Road Warrior. Then Miller comes out with Fury Road. My God.I truly have trouble believing that no one died making that movie. This book does a great job of explaining how. Such meticulous planning, such devotion - by cast, crew, craftspeople that make so much out of old junk - junk that would have survived Armageddon. And then there's George Miller. Twenty five years in the making, fighting the movie suits and the Namib desert (not sure which was worse), George wouldn't let go.I couldn't put the book down. And couldn't wait to watch the movie again - which I did, even though I'm sure I had seen it at least three times before. I even bought the movie - (BTW, I am a notorious cheapskate about buying movies, but I had to in this case). Having read this book, I was so much more aware of the details of the story and was brought to tears several times watching the movie. I now knew these actors and crew as human beings, not just people playing parts.I cannot recommend this book enough if you have ANY interest in the movie, or even if you don't....more

title: No One Is Talking About This
author: Lockwood, Patricia*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Extraordinary. I almost threw this book across the room and quit very early on. Just gibberish in the first half of the book, and heartrending prose iExtraordinary. I almost threw this book across the room and quit very early on. Just gibberish in the first half of the book, and heartrending prose in the second half. But the gibberish is a wonderful way to portray what it is like to get sucked into social media - no beginning, no end, no structure at all, just jumping from one incomplete thought to another, just clicking on not necessarily the next thing but something with shared partial thought or impulse until - oh yeah, jump from one incomplete thought to another just related tangentially by a word or phrase until you stop or get interrupted. And you say to yourself - what just happened to the last hour or three and what the hell was I looking for?And the second part breaks your heart - in a kinda good way.One half free of your earthly existence and the second half EXTREMELY grounded in actual existence. Just an amazing feat....more

title: Act of Oblivion
author: Harris, Robert*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Interesting and much of the time, a page turner. Reminded me that I never mastered the fact that when "Cromwell" was referenced, there were two of theInteresting and much of the time, a page turner. Reminded me that I never mastered the fact that when "Cromwell" was referenced, there were two of them of note - Oliver and Thomas. This book is about Oliver. Well, it was about the events that occurred after his followers killed Charles I. And the vengeance that was sought when Charles II was restored to the throne.The historical novel covers the cat-and-mouse game of chasing down the 59 men who were implicated in the overthrow of Charles I. But it got stale. Most of the 59 were tracked down and summarily executed in short order. This book is mostly about two that got away, and their implacable pursuer. It is interesting, but after a while, my interest waned. Mostly, I felt a lot of sympathy for these two who escaped to New England - Boston and Connecticut of the 1660's. Refreshed my thoughts of gratitude that I was NOT a woman of that place or time. Or a man, for that matter, but much worse for women. I don't know which would have been worse - the hard living, or the Puritans. A decent read if this era appeals - it held my interest for about two-thirds of the book, and that's not bad....more

title: The River We Remember
author: Krueger, William Kent*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really liked this book. It is for everyone, but for those of us of a certain age, definitely a memory lane trip. The author is about my age (3 yearsI really liked this book. It is for everyone, but for those of us of a certain age, definitely a memory lane trip. The author is about my age (3 years difference), and the novel is set in 1958, a year I remember well. And it would appear upstate New York and the north woods of Minnesota were not very different in terms of the sentiments of their respective populations, based on my own memories growing up. And while the sentiments and judgments ring true, my own small town was much more diverse. But the prejudices run in a very familiar path. It will come across as old-fashioned to many readers younger than 60 or so. But I can say that it rings true.It is a good story (he has written quite a few murder mysteries) and it moves along pretty smoothly. If you are a fan of his, you will enjoy this book. Even if you aren't, you should try it, and you might want to read others....more

review: I don't know if this is the final book of a trilogy or not. I don't care. If he keeps writing them, I'll keep reading them. Even though each of the boI don't know if this is the final book of a trilogy or not. I don't care. If he keeps writing them, I'll keep reading them. Even though each of the books are great, they do increase in difficulty, or at least, they did for me. No matter. All are brilliant.Some commentators seem to think each of the books can be stand alone novels. As lost as I got at times, I don't think I could have made it through without all of the buildup in Children of Time, Children of Ruin, and then this one. But whatever your experience, mine was wonderful. Even with the occasional brain fog and confusion. (That's what you get when you keep the headphones on even as you are falling asleep.)I am promising myself to read all three again, in sequence. This may be another promise to myself that I am unlikely to keep, but I sure hope I do. I have read Lonesome Dove several times, and it only gets richer. This has the same potential for me. I think. Long live Adrian Tchaikovsky!...more

review: A remarkable book, but I am exhausted. I like long books, but this was.....There were some hiccups, but the ambition of the book was fully realized. TA remarkable book, but I am exhausted. I like long books, but this was.....There were some hiccups, but the ambition of the book was fully realized. The only complaints I have are (1) the end of the book felt choppy and somewhat thrown together, as if the author either couldn't figure out how to tie it up, or was just sandwiching things in to come to a close; (2) the anthropomorphism of all the critters was a bit much at times [I don't need to be in the head of a fingerling salmon or a grannie mammoth, thanks anyway], and (3) as mentioned, I am exhausted.I always felt certain that I have read Michener before, but I'm not sure now. But I would recommend this book to anyone who is interested in the amazing history of Alaska - just take your time....more

review: Extraordinary book. In reading through other people's s, I could understand some of the negative comments, but they were a bit difficult for me Extraordinary book. In reading through other people's s, I could understand some of the negative comments, but they were a bit difficult for me to accept. Yes, the science was probably oversimplified, but my science knowledge is not so vast that it posed a problem - the concepts were clear and I didn't need more than that. Also, the complaint that a major part of the plot was very similar to that of another novel didn't disturb me because that prior novel was one of the greatest of all time. Well, particularly for the 1960's. And, yes, there was some unnecessary political showcasing.But what does set this book apart is the sheer poetry of Powers' writing. I re-read sentences just to savor them. And to appreciate what he can do with words.Anyway, good story and wonderful writing. My Thanksgiving is complete....more

title: To The Bright Edge of the World
author: Ivey, Eowyn*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: While I'm not generally a fan of magic, I am a fan of magical folklore. Which is where I am choosing to place this book. Also historical fiction, whicWhile I'm not generally a fan of magic, I am a fan of magical folklore. Which is where I am choosing to place this book. Also historical fiction, which I love.Allen Forrester is in charge of a military expedition into interior Alaska in 1885. Newly married to Sophie, their separation is painful. Sophie is just the kind of person/woman I really admire. She has figured herself out on a basic level, and lives her life according to her own precepts. As such, she takes up photography in the early days of that craft/profession. The novel is largely an epistolary story, again one of my favorite styles.Anyway, I'm going on about the novel without getting to its intrinsic wonder. I can't do it justice. There is elegant prose, unbelievable events, and good characters. There are also a few plot holes. I don't care. As people who know me are aware, I'm a sucker for Alaska based stories, especially in the 19th century, and in particular a sucker for expeditions into very inhospitable territory, while sitting in front of a fire with a cozy blanket.The characters are not necessarily heroic, but very human. Extraordinary, but flawed.I can only suggest you read the book, rather then waste more time reading my prattling....more

title: Cloud Cuckoo Land
author: Doerr, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A truly wonderful book. A bit complicated, but like a good interlocking puzzle. Several stories are told and woven together, resulting in a magical soA truly wonderful book. A bit complicated, but like a good interlocking puzzle. Several stories are told and woven together, resulting in a magical sort of tapestry. And when you have finished it and see the whole work, it is astonishing.I cannot imagine how the author conceived of this "whole". And then he executed it. The thread that binds them all is an invented story from ancient Greece, possibly based on The Birds, a play by Aristophanes. (As in Cloud Cuckoo Land-get it?!) An ancient manuscript from that period has survived as a seriously damaged set of folios until the 15th century. More damage and heroic attempts at preservation bring a tattered version of it to the 20th century, where the next set of stories picks up until they are brought together as the completed story.Probably not a good candidate as an audiobook standalone. I toggled back and forth between audio and print, but as a re-read of each section, which is somewhat like reading it twice, but for me, it really worked. I'm not sure I would have been able to take it all in in just audio form.I really liked "All the Stars We Cannot See". This is even better....more

review: Well, Brooks has done it again. Whenever I finish a book of hers, I always tell myself to get the rest of her output and just read them and stop fo0liWell, Brooks has done it again. Whenever I finish a book of hers, I always tell myself to get the rest of her output and just read them and stop fo0ling around. This historical novel consists of multiple layers that she weaves together, consisting of three parts: (a) the world of antebellum southern horse racing, (b) the NYC art world circa 1955, and (c) the universe of the Smithsonian labs in 2019. The common thread is a magnificent thoroughbred race horse, Lexington, who outperformed his peers both on the track and at stud after retiring from racing.The inclusion of the NYC art world was the weakest of the three and felt a bit forced, but it provided a crucial link that Brooks clearly felt needed to be there. I think she was right, but it felt a bit contrived.Nonetheless, a great read!!!...more

review: There may be one more book with Harry Bosch, but this particular pairing with Renee Ballard seems destined to be a handoff to Ms. Ballard for future bThere may be one more book with Harry Bosch, but this particular pairing with Renee Ballard seems destined to be a handoff to Ms. Ballard for future books. Or Harry will become a magical partner, sort of like Joe Pike is to Elvis Cole. That is, whenever Renee Ballard is in over her head (usually pertaining to overwhelming violence in the near future), she calls in Harry. Actually, that's unfair. Harry's encyclopedic knowledge of well, everything crime related in LA, often opens up a case that Renee has picked up on her beloved night shift (the dark hours) when she starts working the case. But they seem destined to become partners - two prickly, thin-skinned cops who are second to none in their abilities to solve crimes. But clearly Connelly is moving Bosch off center stage and focusing on Ballard.I hope they become partners, because I'm not ready to let go of Harry Bosch yet....more

title: The Day the World Came to Town: 9/11 in Gander, Newfoundland
author: DeFede, Jim
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Listening to this book in between listening to the hearings on the January 6th insurrection was pretty surreal. To remember those days and weeks afterListening to this book in between listening to the hearings on the January 6th insurrection was pretty surreal. To remember those days and weeks after 9/11 when the whole world reached out to us in kindness - juxtaposed with the spewing of hate between and among Americans following the 2020 election and its toxic fallout.This book documents the reaction of the good people of Gander when America closed its airspace in the immediate aftermath of the 9/11 attack and 38 planes were diverted to Gander, Newfoundland. It made me so sad thinking about where we are today.However, aside from that emotional reaction, I have to say it isn't a very good book. It is just steady stream of documentation- "first Bill Smith did this, and then two elderly friends did that", and so on and so on. It is a very thorough recitation of a lot of individual kindnesses that were remarkable, but it made for tedious reading. Its saving graces are that it is short, and the book documents a supreme moment of grace by a group of people who shared their homes and kindness in a situation that sorely needed that generosity....more

Primarily, I Well, I have mixed feelings about this book, but overall, a very good read. Ann Patchett's writing overcomes the problems I had with it. Primarily, I have never wanted to explore hot, humid places that are populated by poisonous critters. Northern territories, yes. Equatorial climes, not so much. And the problem, ironically, is that Ann Patchett writes so well that you are thrust into the experience. My skin crawled during large chunks of the book. But, that said, I very much liked the solving of the underlying mystery about the boundaries of female fertility. And I was glad for Patchett's resolution. title: Rocket Men: The Daring Odyssey of Apollo 8 and the Astronauts Who Made Man's First Journey to the Moon
author: Kurson, Robert*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Remarkable. Although I was (vaguely) aware of Apollo 8, I had almost no memory of the particulars, nor of its importance to the feasibility of the ApoRemarkable. Although I was (vaguely) aware of Apollo 8, I had almost no memory of the particulars, nor of its importance to the feasibility of the Apollo 11 mission. This book is very detailed (without losing the reader) - about the men and their families, the family that NASA was for the Apollo program, and the particular genius of using the other events of 1968 to show how much we (America) needed a win. Not just in the space program, but even more so the other, more shattering events. I turned 21 in 1968, and I can attest to how difficult a year it was. The Vietnam War was in full bloom (the TET "offensive" started the year off with many American soldiers' deaths), the USS Pueblo was captured by North Korea, Martin Luther King was assassinated in April, RFK in June, rioting was happening in all our major cities, and the Democratic Party Convention in Chicago showed police beating the shit out of college students. It felt like the country was on fire because it was.Yet, somehow in all of this, three dedicated and competent men (and yes, women were out of the question in those days) went about their business and demonstrated that we could get to the moon AND COME BACK. Even though no one stepped on the moon until July 1969, after Apollo 8 it wasn't whether it could be done, it was a matter of when. Pretty quickly, as it turned out....This book is a feat of reporting, and I am so glad I read it. It just makes me wonder how much else I have missed in all of my turns around the sun.Sadly, a cursory googling does not provide any indication of the enormous contribution that Apollo 8 made in opening the door to the lunar landing. This book remedies that.And, after all, America ended 1968 on a high note because of Borman, Lovell, and Anders and their quiet heroics. ...more

title: Pastoral Song: A Farmer’s Journey
author: Rebanks, James
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Incredible. I'm not sure what I was expecting, but not this. Or sort of this, but the author avoids going down any common pathways. He confounded me.TIncredible. I'm not sure what I was expecting, but not this. Or sort of this, but the author avoids going down any common pathways. He confounded me.The first part of the book is titled, appropriately, Nostalgia. It is a lovely look back by the author when he was seated behind his grandfather plowing fields on his family farm. Just the first few pages thrilled me. The birds, the dirt, the smells, the five year old's perspective. This section was just pure joy.The second and third parts were also spectacular, but didn't hit me quite as emotionally. (Nothing like nostalgia to get the emoting glands revved up.) But they did trip the guilt switches. He kept surprising me - I thought he was on Path A - damn corporate agriculture, which he is, but he understands that's too simplistic; or then, Path B - if we just farmed like in olden days, everything would be wonderful; that is also too simplistic.Rebanks knows that neither Path A or B will work. He believes that we have to keep experimenting to find the right kind of balances. And he doesn't believe either path is sustainable. He just kept surprising me.Rather then continue babbling, my short comment would be READ THIS BOOK.A few quotations just to tease you:1. "Farming for nature is economic suicide."2. "Cheap food is unsustainable." (He is not the first to say such a thing.)3. "There is a very thin line between idealism and bullshit."4. "Technically, the best thing we could do for nature in most landscapes is to not be there at all."Well, that doesn't do justice either. Just read the book....more

author: Burton, Art T.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Did not finish. Seems like great subject matter and really amazing history, but the writing was terrible. So dry. Mostly nouns and verbs - reads like Did not finish. Seems like great subject matter and really amazing history, but the writing was terrible. So dry. Mostly nouns and verbs - reads like police statements of cases with obsessive detail about nothing important. You know, where the police spokesperson steps up and talks about perpetrators, and uses a lot of words to say nothing and promises to update everyone regularly. Actually, most court transcripts are more interesting. It is a shame, because from what I could glean, Bass Reeves deserves a good telling of his story. And Art Burton is to be commended for his quest for very difficult to obtain information about someone who definitely didn't get his due. But Burton isn't a writer, just a dry reciter of facts.For a while, I thought it would get better, but I skipped ahead and around and couldn't find a paragraph that would remain in my brain for more than 5 seconds.But - in the future, I will always think of Bass Reeves whenever I run across the Lone Ranger....more

title: Earning the Rockies: How Geography Shapes America's Role in the World
author: Kaplan, Robert D.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The first two-thirds of this book was wonderful. It fell off a bit at the end, but it was still good. The early part of the book was a terrific versioThe first two-thirds of this book was wonderful. It fell off a bit at the end, but it was still good. The early part of the book was a terrific version of the "geography is destiny" lecture.Beginning with an extended trip with his parents in 1962, and ending with a trip by himself in 2016, Kaplan entertainingly brings you along for the ride. In 1962, the trip was limited to the eastern United States, and involved visiting many presidential homes - Buchanan, Jefferson, and of course, Lincoln - with an eye toward how each fit into American expansion. The history lessons imparted to Kaplan by his father were still very alive for him and he makes them so for the reader.Toward the end of the book, I think maybe Kaplan was pushing it to make his deadline. But he takes you with him as he visits diners, BBQ joints, regional fast food eateries, all with an eavesdropping ear for his fellow diners as he makes his way across the Great Basin and ends in San Diego. He makes quite a point of how little conversation outside of the Boston-NY-Washington corridor is about politics. Not that that is a surprise, but I was expecting more conflict than was evident.Finally, while I much prefer fiction to nonfiction, this is an exception....more

title: Migrations
author: McConaghy, Charlotte*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "It isn't fair to be the kind of creature who is able to love but unable to stay."A fair warning of what you will be reading if you pick up this book."It isn't fair to be the kind of creature who is able to love but unable to stay."A fair warning of what you will be reading if you pick up this book. And I am so glad I picked it up. This is one of the most beautiful pieces of literature I've read in quite a while. It is also very emotionally difficult, and has a protagonist who is very self destructive. So. Not my usual fare, I admit. I really couldn't handle such reading as a regular diet. But so glorious.Franny Stone is a tragic, poetic, resilient figure. In my head, a tragic Irish heroine. Maybe even part selkie. I am having great difficulty expressing myself.Just read this book. It will either call out to you, or it won't. The book is also a great adventure set in a near future, with Franny and her fellow travelers on a commercial fishing boat who are following the last of the arctic terns on their final migration from the Arctic to Antarctica. She is going as a witness, they are looking for fish to make a living. They don't always agree on things....1/1o/22 Re-read for my book club. Still great. Made for great discussion - a lot of different, but always passionate, takes on the story/book....more

title: The Book Woman of Troublesome Creek
author: Richardson, Kim Michele*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: An interesting book based on wonderful program in the 1930's - the Pack Horse Library Project in Kentucky, advocated by Eleanor Roosevelt. Dedicated rAn interesting book based on wonderful program in the 1930's - the Pack Horse Library Project in Kentucky, advocated by Eleanor Roosevelt. Dedicated riders (mostly women) rode the back hollers and hills delivering books on regular, but arduous, routes. They would then return and pick up the loaned books and replenish them with new selections. The program itself is worth reading about, but the novel focused as much on the women who rode those mules/horses, in particular a young woman who has blue skin. While she is a fictitious character, there were blue skinned people in the hills of Kentucky who were shunned by the "regular" population.A good read, and fascinating pair of ingredients - pack horse librarians and the blue-skinned people in the backwoods of Kentucky in the depths of the depression....more

She coversI've threatened to never read another Kristin Hannah book before. This time, I mean it. I keep waiting to CARE about any of her characters. She covers a lot of ground, and the bones of her stories are well grounded. I cannot put my finger on why exactly I have trouble with her writing, but I find it deadening. I just keep digging for the pony.The story itself is interesting, but I just don't care about the characters. And she puts them through such hell. The best word I can think of is prosaic - there isn't anything wrong, but I can't find any joy in reading her writing. So, good story, plodding narrative.And what I really hated in this book is that several animals you grow to care about, die. Lingering, miserable deaths. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Adrian Tchaikovsky may be the most inventive writer out there. Clever, clever boy. I decided to read this, even though I went in knowing it was a timeAdrian Tchaikovsky may be the most inventive writer out there. Clever, clever boy. I decided to read this, even though I went in knowing it was a time travel story. And time travel stories often give me a headache. But he pulled it off. And I would have gotten a headache at points except I knew to trust the author and just did the hand waving bit when I hit parts that got sticky. For those of you more comfortable with, say, quantum mechanics and quantum physics, you might want to work harder than I did for those plot points. I just decided that four dimensional space could exist and moved on. I guess you could summarize this book as a tale of the "Last" War to End All Wars (until you get to the next war to end all wars), as long as your tongue is firmly planted in your cheek.This is the author who made a giant spider the protagonist of one of the best books I've ever read (Children of Time), and from a first person perspective, no less.Like his stuff or hate it, he is a genius....more

title: Hamnet
author: O'Farrell, Maggie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Beautiful story about the heartbreak of losing a child. This novel is based in fact - namely, that that William Shakespeare and his wife Agnes (Anne) Beautiful story about the heartbreak of losing a child. This novel is based in fact - namely, that that William Shakespeare and his wife Agnes (Anne) lost their 11 year old son, Hamnet, perhaps to the bubonic plague. Add to that fact that the name Hamnet was interchangeable with the name Hamlet at that time (1585-1596), and you have the framework of a story and how grief works it way through the survivors. Although this novel posits that Shakespeare wrote his masterpiece in memory of his son, this story is that of Hamnet's mother, Agnes, and of her grief. Read it at your own risk....more

title: The Pull of the Stars
author: Donoghue, Emma*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A minute by minute fictional (but very reality-based) history of three days in a hospital in Dublin in late 1918 (or 1917, I'm not completely sure). IA minute by minute fictional (but very reality-based) history of three days in a hospital in Dublin in late 1918 (or 1917, I'm not completely sure). In particular, a maternity sub-section for women who were experiencing the pandemic flu symptoms. It is a small population (3 beds, not enough nurses - a fair amount of the three days with only one nurse), but a very challenging population...as if childbirth in that time wasn't difficult enough.Extremely detailed and heart-breaking, with moments of joy and happiness, this reminded me very much of the qualities I love in Call the Midwife. But the ratio of heartbreak to joy is much more devastating than it is in Call the Midwife.There is a fair amount of unflattering depiction of the expectations for women of child-bearing age especially with respect to the Irish Roman Catholic control on social norms...one charming phrase was "she doesn't love him unless she gives him twelve". And of course, these women who were expected to become baby making machines were often subject to conditions that cruelly damage the chances of a healthy pregnancy - poverty, physical and mental abuse, and the dietary and housing shortcomings that come with those conditions.However, it is a glorious read. You are THERE, in that little repurposed stockroom, taking temperatures and delivering babies, and you grow to care very much about the individuals who are heroic in carrying out their duties. Unless you are dead inside, your heart will soar and break along with this small, impactful group of women. ...more

title: The Haunting of Tram Car 015        (Dead Djinn Universe, #0.3)
author: Clark, P. Djèlí*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Bureaucrats and magic. Cairo 1912. Alternative history. Pretty good ingredients for a long-ish novella. In this story, Egypt threw the Brits out in 18Bureaucrats and magic. Cairo 1912. Alternative history. Pretty good ingredients for a long-ish novella. In this story, Egypt threw the Brits out in 1879 with the help of "an influx of djinn". The protagonists are a couple of not-quite-hapless bureaucrats from the Ministry of Alchemy, Enchantments and Supernatural Entities - they are law enforcement, sort of cops and detectives. Not Keystone Kops, but there were moments....Their assignment is to rid Tram Car 015 of an unwelcome guest - is it a djinn or demon or what? And they have to accomplish this within a constrained budget....The setting is wonderful. An NPR  described it as "a vivid, loving imagining of what a successfully decolonized Middle-East and North Africa could look like, with people looking at each other and seeing each other and their differences without the interfering, distorting lenses of whiteness and imperialism."It is no wonder it was a finalist for the Hugo and won the Nebula in the novella category. Pure catnip for authors of scifi/speculative fiction/whatever you want to label it these days.But very confusing. I was particularly glad I read this on a library e-book where I could look up definitions of words by pressing my finger against the word in the text - because there were a LOT of words that were unknown to me. And several of them were also unknown to the e-book library, but context worked most of the time.It is also a mash-up that includes a full-on suffragette movement, and some truly scary moments. An enjoyable and relatively short read. I took away a star because it was confusing - I know, I know - unfair to punish something because of my limitations, but it did interfere with the flow of the book for me. But a fun treat to start the year....more

title: Fair Warning        (Jack McEvoy, #3; Harry Bosch Universe, #34)
author: Connelly, Michael*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I love Michael Connelly but he just phoned this one in. That doesn't make it a bad book, just not up to his usual standard. No Bosch or Rene Ballard -I love Michael Connelly but he just phoned this one in. That doesn't make it a bad book, just not up to his usual standard. No Bosch or Rene Ballard - or Lincoln Lawyer, Mickey Haller. Rather, we get Jack McEvoy who hasn't been around for quite a while.It is a good book and reads easily, just like all of Connelly's work, but it never felt like there were any stakes in it. There is a personal angle here for Connelly that he explains in an afterward - there is a real Fair Warning consumer organization and Connelly is on the board. This book will probably shed a little light/love on an agency he believes in, and that's all to the good. Just maybe set up the wrong stakes for writing a book. But he has earned it, so not complaining....This is a serial killer book where the killer has a very specific MO. He basically decapitates people by twisting their necks a la the little girl/demon in the Exorcist. A fairly monstrous technique. And the guy calls himself the Shrike, because there is a bird by that name that kills its prey by decapitation. Ick. I like the name Shrike, because it harkens back to a wonderful book by Dan Simmons - Hyperion. Now THAT book is a real classic....more

title: The City in the Middle of the Night
author: Anders, Charlie Jane*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Really wanted this to be five stars and it almost was. Just a bit too YA for me - I'm pretty much past the unrequited love part of my emotional develoReally wanted this to be five stars and it almost was. Just a bit too YA for me - I'm pretty much past the unrequited love part of my emotional development. But. The world building, the intricately woven narrations were great! I was pushing the YA stuff into the background pretty successfully until the protagonist went back one time too many. Or maybe two times too many.That said, the exploration of a tidally locked planet (one side always in the sun, the other always in the dark - like our moon) was fascinating in itself; the impact that has on life on that planet, both native and interlopers such as humans (presumably from Earth) was also beautifully explored; and the inevitability of the ugly side of human nature, no matter the circumstances, while predictable, was presented fairly realistically. But the most amazing part was the development of the native species as characters. Beings that communicate in a totally different manner, coupled with a very different relationship to time than humans have, was extraordinarily well done.A good read, but spare me the teenage angst. For others, that may be a selling point, but not for me....more

review: The book had me at the first page from its chapter header and first sentence:The Good People of Goleen"Long before we discovered that he had fathered The book had me at the first page from its chapter header and first sentence:The Good People of Goleen"Long before we discovered that he had fathered two children by two different women, one in Drimoleague and one in Clonakilty, Father James Monroe stood on the altar of the Church of Our Lady, Star of the Sea, in the parish of Goleen, West Cork, and denounced my mother as a whore."And later, in the same paragraph:"My six uncles, their dark hair glistening with rose-scented lacquer, sat next to her in ascending order of age and stupidity."And all delivered in a wonderful Irish brogue.I was hooked. The dialogue is just some of the best I've ever encountered. This is a long story that is filled with a lot of sadness and occasional violent incidents. But I (sometimes guiltily) laughed a LOT. This writing reminds me of Richard Russo or some weird combination of Thomas Hardy and Carl Hiaasen. All of whom I adore. Yes, even Hardy. But not too much Hardy.I'd recommend the audio version, but there are a lot of characters by the end of the book to keep track of, so.... I did my usual audio for an hour or two followed by print reading of the same material to keep it all straight. Not for everyone, but it works for me....more

review: Adrian Tchaikovsky isn't for everybody. But if you are lucky, he might be for you. His world-building is second to none. And his bugs - real, AI, otheAdrian Tchaikovsky isn't for everybody. But if you are lucky, he might be for you. His world-building is second to none. And his bugs - real, AI, other-worldly, are second to none. Of course, they can be creepy or endearing (not many endearing in this book), but they are always interesting. His prose is deeply laced with references to obscure poetry and ancient mythology. I just love his stuff, but it is taxing to wade through at times.This is the most overtly political of his books that I have read - climate change, income/resource inequality are at the heart of this story. And the Firewalkers - the protagonists of the story - inhabit the pretty much uninhabitable parts of the devastated earth.Sadly, the locusts of this book aren't nearly as interesting as the spiders and squids of Children of Time or Children of Ruin, but they are pretty horrific.......more

title: The Color of Water: A Black Man's Tribute to His White Mother
author: McBride, James*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is one of those "has to be true, because no one could make this up" books. Reads a lot like a novel, but it is written as a memoir/tribute to a mThis is one of those "has to be true, because no one could make this up" books. Reads a lot like a novel, but it is written as a memoir/tribute to a mother. A mother who was born into an Orthodox Jewish immigrant family - a cold and unloving family except for her own mother, who was treated very badly by her itinerant rabbi husband and abandoned by her own family. That this woman ended up having 12 children with two wonderful and loving husbands and pushed all of her children to go to college, many of them to postgraduate and professional school, is a testament in and of itself. When her first husband died, she was only 37 and pregnant with her eighth child (the author, James McBride). In a few years, she had remarried and had four more children with her second husband. She may have lost her sanity at times, but her energy and drive didn't leave her time to dwell on her difficulties. In fact, she adopted Christianity and with her first husband founded a church in Red Hook (infamous projects in NYC), the New Brown Memorial Baptist Church - first in their apartment, later in its own building, that is still standing. Religion was very important in her life.There is a lot in the book about the confusion/difficulty of growing up biracial, especially when your mother refuses to acknowledge such a concept. McBride wrote this book as a way to find out about his own heritage, and tapped into an incredibly rich vein that is his own mother's story.I read The Good Lord Bird a few years ago, and it was, and is, one of my very favorite books. Reading this book was a completely different experience - not surprising, since they are very different stories - but a good experience, nonetheless.In these days of coronavirus and Black Lives Matter, it was also a bit jarring to read, but it throws a light on humanity that is ultimately affirming and generous. A good read....more

review: Pretty standard Rollins. Take a little science bending (a la Michael Crichton), mix with nonstop action (Dan Brown, maybe?), and throw everyone in a fPretty standard Rollins. Take a little science bending (a la Michael Crichton), mix with nonstop action (Dan Brown, maybe?), and throw everyone in a fast-moving story that has formidable assassins, science-y weapons, government treachery, etc etc. I had more trouble than usual with the defects of Rollins' writing - thin characters, just-in-time escapes and rescues, wanton destruction of treasures (in this one, he destroys the papal summer home; my least favorite was when he destroyed the Roman Coliseum in an earlier novel), ridiculous coincidences, etc. But, I have to admit he can write a page-turner. In this one, our happy protagonists are following Odysseus's path home, but via the gates of Hell. I do love the travelogue aspect - kept me busy on Wikipedia and Google maps, which I really like to do while reading a novel. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a pretty good book and a pretty good mystery. But I have been fighting to read and to finish it. I have been attributing that to the times we This is a pretty good book and a pretty good mystery. But I have been fighting to read and to finish it. I have been attributing that to the times we are living in - coronavirus and staying home - but after finishing and going back over it, I do believe that this is a good book, just not very well written. It is a first novel, and the plot was interesting, but the mystery was a bit obscure and the writing was, well, not very good. I know that I decided to read it because it was situated in Alaska, which is always a draw for me. The author uses a device that usually appeals to me - embedding foreign words and including a glossary. However, there aren't a lot of words, and since it is based on a real native language which bears no relationship to English-Germanic languages, it seems more like Welsh (as in, VERY limited vowels) than anything else. In other words, pretty resistant to incorporating into a narrative without bringing the whole thing to a halt while you look up the word for the 112th time. (There are only a handful of words.) But I was very satisfied with the ending. It just took me forever. And again, I am reluctant to blame that all on the author........more

author: Taylor, James
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a great audiobook. I knew that James Taylor had issues with his mental health and that it “ran” in his family, but I didn’t have any real understWhat a great audiobook. I knew that James Taylor had issues with his mental health and that it “ran” in his family, but I didn’t have any real understanding of what that meant. It is a tragic story, especially since it was a history that was multigenerational. This only covers his early years until he was 21 or 22. While some of this story is painful to listen to, Taylor has his guitar and uses it to smooth out the transitions. Sometimes he just strums a few chords, sometimes song fragments, sometimes the whole song. These are the early glorious years of Joan Baez, Joni Mitchell, the Beatles, and Taylor tells us how he grew from those experiences. Since I am almost exactly his age, the stories echoed my youth, so of course, it made all of this more meaningful to me. Perfect little freebie....more

title: The Leisure Seeker
author: Zadoorian, Michael*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I found this book to be very endearing. I would guess your age would play a large role in your ability to enjoy it. As someone with most of my road beI found this book to be very endearing. I would guess your age would play a large role in your ability to enjoy it. As someone with most of my road behind me, I found it frightening at times, but ultimately reassuring and lovely. It deals very realistically with what the aging process takes from us and what makes life worth living. The specifics of the story are what they are (cancer-ridden woman but with her mental faculties intact and her husband with his physical ability intact, but his mind has lost a lot of ground and has the potential to lead to very dangerous situations), but generic enough to resonate with most of us.It is both an adventure story (leaving behind all the "helpers" - kids, doctors) and a love story at the same time of a couple who have spent some sixty years together and want live (and perhaps die) on their own terms. Wonderful insight into what memory is or isn't, what a shared life means, and a road trip on Route 66. Who could ask for more?P.S. There is a lovely movie based on this book starring Helen Mirran and Donald Sutherland. Not as good as the book, but they seldom are.......more

Shout out to Di for bringing it to my attention. How have I never heard of this author before? I read so many books of this type/subject matter in my youth that this one took me right back - hard living on land that really wasn't meant to be farmed, one-room schoolhouses, and lots of chores (we're not talking about dusting your room here; we're talking up before dawn to milk the cows, clean out the stables, splitting wood, starting the fire in the old cast iron stoves, riding horseback to school, and lots more when you got home from school). That might have been enough, but the prose! Sample [when going over narrator's memories]: "The Rembrandt light of memory, finicky and magical and faithful at the same time, as the cheaper tint of nostalgia never is"....I was really sad to come to the end of the book - luckily, he has written more.This is just one of the best books I've ever read. title: Breakthrough        (Breakthrough, #1)
author: Grumley, Michael C.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Well. A truly frustrating reading experience. First, this book needed an editor, just to make the reading of it less work. Chapters come and go with nWell. A truly frustrating reading experience. First, this book needed an editor, just to make the reading of it less work. Chapters come and go with no particular "chunking" of the book. Characters are introduced and not explored at all. Some characters seem to have two dimensions by the end, but most are just names on the page. Protagonists and antagonists need SOME development - this is an all verbs and nouns book. (And I don't always object to that, but this was too much of it.)Many interesting sub-plots are developed (the overarching plot is - "Oh my god, we're going to die") and the particular sub-plots were interesting, but not particularly well developed.I read to the end, and am sorry I did. My particular frustration is that this teased an early Jim Rollins type writer, but while Rollins has the same problems with character development, he has a pretty tightly wound series of actions that are absolute page turners. And Rollins' "science" is much more rooted in actual science - he does the same thing Michael Crichton does - takes real science and adds a twist and rolls from there. This author just goes wild with multiple (maybe 6 or 7) science adjacent facts and jumps off of all of them.I think this author has promise - he just needs some discipline and probably an editor. Maybe he works that out, because lots of people like his stuff, and it doesn't surprise me. But for me, the promise of the novel was ultimately not realized. So. There I was at the end, and not happy. But unable to say that there might not still be a pony in there........more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I guess nothing will match the Dog Stars, but this is a worthy novel in its own right. It's just that it suffers a bit in comparison. No one writes abI guess nothing will match the Dog Stars, but this is a worthy novel in its own right. It's just that it suffers a bit in comparison. No one writes about being in, or surviving in, the wilderness/outdoors better than Peter Heller. I also enjoyed the two main characters - best friends on a dream canoeing trip in the Canadian wilderness. Heller did a very good job of making you care a lot about them. And the trials and tribulations they endure - a massive out-of-control wildfire, a couple of drunk semi-Deliverance characters (in fairness, only one of them really is), and a couple that they hear quarreling in the fog early in their journey. And a day or two later, the man shows up alone, claiming his wife disappeared. At that point, the book kicks into high gear. What had been a nice, meandering river trip turns into a flat out race to outrun and evade the various terrors. And I really can't say more than that.One quibble - as much as I like his outdoorsy writing, there was a bit too much about the fishing gear - description of the various flies, rods, weights - for me, but I bet if you are into fishing you would love that stuff. Again, his descriptions and love of the flora and fauna of the wilderness are second to none. ...more

title: Chances Are...
author: Russo, Richard*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I love Richard Russo. Even when he comes up a little short, I still love his writing. His characters and their interactions always ring true to me. HiI love Richard Russo. Even when he comes up a little short, I still love his writing. His characters and their interactions always ring true to me. His best writing usually has a fair amount of pathos mixed in with some slap-stick humor. 'Chances Are' is heavy on the self doubt and self loathing but too light on the humor. Still, as he always does, he drops me into my past - in this instance December 1, 1969 when every young man (and anyone who cared about them) was glued to the TV set, watching the lottery numbers being drawn for the draft. As summed up by a critic of the Vietnam War:"December 1, 1969: A Date Which Will Live in Irony. This was the date of the first Vietnam Draft Lottery, the day the phrase “to win the lottery” became, not a prize, but a death sentence."And that's how it felt. And Richard Russo brings it all back by opening his story with three friends watching TV. These friends were close (enough) to graduation from college to feel the heat of the draft board - the same draft board that had granted them deferments until their graduation dates. (Note: the lottery numbers ran from 1 to 365, one for each day of the year. Your lottery number was randomly assigned to each day of the year, so your birthday date determined your fate. The higher the number, the better. Draft numbers 1-195 ended up being called in that first year.) Of course Russo creates drama just by assigning the three protagonists very different draft numbers: 9, 189, and 322. And all the air goes out of the room.So. That was the prologue. We now skip forward to a reunion, when these three friends are no longer young men but forty-four years older, meeting on Martha's Vineyard, commiserating over their lives and wondering where Jacy went. Jacy, the girl they were all in love with. Enter the mystery. And a lot of self introspection. I got very impatient with these guys at times. But I liked spending time with them, nonetheless, and finding out what they had been doing for all of these years. And Russo writes well enough that I enjoyed the time spent....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Well, it's Backman, so it's wonderful. For those of you who haven't read this book or "Britt Marie Was Here", definitely read this one first. I didn'tWell, it's Backman, so it's wonderful. For those of you who haven't read this book or "Britt Marie Was Here", definitely read this one first. I didn't, and even though I loved both, I wish I had known to read "My Grandmother Asked Me To Tell You She's Sorry" first. Didn't so much lessen anything, but I think I would have appreciated Britt Marie (the character) much more if I had read this one first.So, dotty grandmother and precocious granddaughter have adventures. And a truly motley crew of folks who all inhabit the same apartment building figure into those adventures in ways I did not see coming. Until about a third of the way through this book, I thought maybe this would be one of the weaker entries in the Backman collection. Not so. A bit more plot in this one, but as always, it's about the characters. Wonderfully flawed characters. Backman is a treasure in his ability to create cranky, but ultimately wonderful, people who inhabit these small universes he builds. Mostly, they are very human.I can't say enough about this author, and this book is up there with any of them....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wow. I finished this book a few days ago, and my stomach still hurts. This read much like a horror novel - I kept waiting for people to die horribly. Wow. I finished this book a few days ago, and my stomach still hurts. This read much like a horror novel - I kept waiting for people to die horribly. Actually, no one dies, but it stretches credulity that some of the things that happened to people didn't kill them.This book reinforces my belief that none of us can be a reliable narrator, because you only have your own perspective to draw from. And whatever your experiences for the first 10 or so years of your life, those experiences pretty much define "normal" to you. Unfortunately for Tara Westover, her first ten years were shaped (actually "warped" is probably more appropriate) by her insane parents. But whatever you might think of the importance of this book, it is impossible to put down. You just have to turn to the next page to see what new damages have accrued to the children of this family (and at some point, one of the sons becomes as abusive as his parents)....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A really fine debut novel. And a breath of fresh air from what I've been reading lately. Elegant simplicity (some ers equated that with boring),A really fine debut novel. And a breath of fresh air from what I've been reading lately. Elegant simplicity (some ers equated that with boring), day by day tale of life in Oklahoma in the 1920's from the perspective of a Cherokee woman coming of age. It doesn't focus on whether things are right or wrong, or whether justice needs to be served. Sad to read what was tolerated in terms of how Native Americans were treated, but that seeps in through the telling of everyday life, and to me, is more powerful for it.Maud is smart and young and beautiful and limited by the time and place she inhabits. But she is not a whiner and her stoicism was really compelling to me in showing her life. The book IS slow, I guess, but I wasn't bored for a minute. Plenty of drama, but realistic, I did not miss CGI nor melodrama. Most of all, it is about family and the resilience of this young woman, whom I admired very much.My only complaint is that the ending is pretty abrupt....more

review: I really enjoyed this recounting of a son's 18-year quest to understand his father, who was a WWII veteran and had survived the Battle of Okinawa. MahI really enjoyed this recounting of a son's 18-year quest to understand his father, who was a WWII veteran and had survived the Battle of Okinawa. Maharidge's research was guided by curiosity about a picture of one of his father's fellow Marines who died on Okinawa - in following that thread, the author accomplished two important things: (a) a probable answer to the cause of his father's behavior/rage/anger and (b) locating the remains of his father's friend on Okinawa and bringing them home for burial 70 years after he died.This was a pretty emotional read, and it can only add to both the admiration I have for the men and women who served in that war and my hopes that we never do this again....Audible freebie, btw....more

review: I loved Children of Time. Children of Ruin is a very worthy sequel. In Children of Time, I fell in love with sentient spiders. In Children of Ruin, I I loved Children of Time. Children of Ruin is a very worthy sequel. In Children of Time, I fell in love with sentient spiders. In Children of Ruin, I got very irritated with sentient octopuses (or octopi or octopodes - a running gag in the book). As it turns out, humans and (uplifted) spiders have much more in common than either of them do with octopi. Especially regarding thought and memory and problem solving: essentially, they both use an analytical/structural scaffolding. Octopi, however, base their problem solving with visual constructs. If that doesn't make much sense, trust me, Tchaikovsky explains it is a way that makes sense.Impossible to describe, and overly dense at points, I got lost enough several times that I had to go back and re-read many sections. But it was worth it. Adrian Tchaikovsky is a genius....more

title: The Winter Queen        (Erast Fandorin Mysteries, #1)
author: Akunin, Boris
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm conflicted on this one. It was sort of a mashup of Agatha Christie (which I generally don't like very much) and a nice satire of the Russian bureaI'm conflicted on this one. It was sort of a mashup of Agatha Christie (which I generally don't like very much) and a nice satire of the Russian bureaucracy. The protagonist - Erast Fandorin - is a bit of a bumbling idiot; not full-on goofy like the Pink Panther, but just slow on the uptake. Nonetheless, he is perceived by many of his superiors to be brilliant because of his insights. That is more of a diss on his superiors than a compliment to him. His "insights" are as subtle as a whack to the head, but at least he finally recognizes them when they do whack him in the head, as opposed to his superiors who are oblivious to clues even when served for supper...The Russian-ness played both ways for me. I loved the weird precision of the ranking systems for authority, especially since the ranking has absolutely nothing to do with competence. But the physical descriptions of Moscow were quite lovely, and the time period (1876) was one in which the politics and events for Russia were quite interesting, as the country was evolving into an industrial power, but before everything blew up. And the revolutionists/anarchists play a large part in the plot of this book, although their particular politics seemed muddy to me.The book has a lot to recommend it, but I felt like I was pushing through it too much to truly enjoy it as much as it deserved....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Searing and painful. A really complicated and insightful memoir about growing up mixed race but with a lot of privilege. If you are white and think yoSearing and painful. A really complicated and insightful memoir about growing up mixed race but with a lot of privilege. If you are white and think you understand, you don't. Read this. The frustrating part is that I still don't know what to do about it all, but I feel like I have a much better notion of the poison in all of us because America was built on the blood and sweat of others. A particularly important part of this for me was the exploration of self-loathing, and what it does to a person. Self-loathing is not limited to race - it is something many of us experience, whether due to being overweight, not knowing what to say at the right moment, being the "other" in any given situation. In short, that feeling of not fitting in, but taken to the level of pathology.Sometimes being in a book club really pays off....more

title: The Graveyard Book
author: Gaiman, Neil*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Cozy, compelling, creepy, confusing, and wonderfully full of whimsy. And read by Neil himself. For instance, the man combines some Lovecraftian creepiCozy, compelling, creepy, confusing, and wonderfully full of whimsy. And read by Neil himself. For instance, the man combines some Lovecraftian creepiness ("We are the Sleer [with creepy slithery sound effects]), a moving tribute to 'Dans Macabre', and my faves the ghouls who kidnap our young hero and are named the Duke of Westminster, the Honorable Archibald Fitzhugh, the Bishop of Bath and Wells, the Emperor of China, the 33rd President of the United States (Harry S. Truman, so you don't have to look him up), and Victor Hugo. Now, just for clarity, the ghouls aren't the remains of those men - it just means the ghouls have "partaken" of their remains.Our hero is Bod - short for Nobody, who grows up in a graveyard. He is the only living occupant of the graveyard. And he has many adventures and questions.The circumstances of his situation are not particularly important. Gaiman doesn't really deal in plot. He writes wonderful scenes that he stitches together into a whole, of sorts. For instance, the interlude of the dans macabre really doesn't work as a plot device, nor does it "move" the plot forward. It just IS, and is a wonderful moment to savor. I normally need more structure in a novel, but I have been able to just relax into it. And with Gaiman narrating, it is even easier.This is a story about community, and how everyone has some part to play.The Graveyard Book won't be for everyone, but for those it works for, it really works. I am one of those....more

title: American Gods        (American Gods, #1)
author: Gaiman, Neil*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Generally, I find Gaiman's work wildly uneven. Sometimes I really like it, sometimes I really get bored, sometimes both in the same work. But this parGenerally, I find Gaiman's work wildly uneven. Sometimes I really like it, sometimes I really get bored, sometimes both in the same work. But this particular "novel" (there is sort of a structure of a novel, i.e. beginning, middle-ish, and end) very much got under my skin. Wildly inventive and endearing characters - many of whom had no business being endearing (Chernobog, do you hear me?). The premise is that there is about to be a war between the old gods and the new gods. The old gods came to America with immigrants, who brought their folklore/gods (e.g. Irish leprechauns, Odin, Jinns) with them. But over time, these gods faded in the memories of the descendants of those who brought them to America and new gods have replaced them - such as technology and media. The old gods, led by Mr. Wednesday (Odin) have decided to fight back. This premise is either very appealing or silly as hell depending on your ability to suspend disbelief. I had purchased the book many years ago, but had not gotten around to reading it. When Starz announced that it was bringing it to the small screen, I decided to read it. I only got through the first third of the book before the first season aired, but luckily, it was fairly congruent with some notable exceptions. For instance, I like the character of Mad Sweeney in the book, but I love him in the TV show - evidently the showrunners did too, because he got a lot more coverage than in the book. As notices came around that Season 2 was coming up, I decided to finish the book. I don't know if this is the best way to absorb content, but it sure worked for me.I know this isn't a TV  platform, but Starz went all out for this series. The casting is just fabulous: Ian McShane for Mr. Wednesday, Ricky Whittle for Shadow Moon, Pablo Schrieber for Mad Sweeney, Orlando Jones as Mr. Nancy, and on and on. The lesser known actors have been a revelation to me - I am scouring IMBD to find content with some of them.So I hope others get as much out of this as I did. Part of the secret for me was to not rush, and sit awhile with the stories - many of which are wonderful novellas in their own right....more

And it is wonderful. We have not one, not two, but three fantastic female protagonists. Ice kings and queens, princesses, tsars, demons (Chernobog!!!).This is not your childhood Rumpelstiltskin, but it is a third cousin of his.Whenever I thought of the ice king (who is NOT a nice guy), I went here:(This was supposed to be copy of image of Lee Pace as Elvish king, but I can't figure out how to paste it in.)The demon Chernobog:(And this was supposed to be a copy of an image of Peter Stormare as Chernobog from American Gods...) I'm going to be living here for a while. Get this book and read it. And anything else Naomi Novik has written - the Temeraire (dragon) series, which one wag described as a cross between Patrick O'Brian and Jane Austen - and I can't argue with that assessment; Uprooted; and now this. title: Isaac's Storm: A Man, a Time, and the Deadliest Hurricane in History
author: Larson, Erik*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: He's done it again. Taken a really interesting story and turned it into a muddle. His writing is terrible. After I finished The Devil in the White CitHe's done it again. Taken a really interesting story and turned it into a muddle. His writing is terrible. After I finished The Devil in the White City, I steered away from Larson, but this was for book club. So many fascinating topics, but I got more out of perusing Wikipedia than reading this. So many interconnected bits that aren't connected, list making kind of stuff without referencing meaningful antecedents, and when the flood hits, he goes on and on with people and how they died - smashed by a falling ceiling, crushed under a moving wall of debris, decapitated by flying slate, but they are all people you haven't heard of before and won't again. There are several main characters that are carried through the story, but so many at the end aren't it drove me crazy. It is clear that his research is stellar -- but he needs an editor to help him organize that research. As with The Devil in the White City, the last 20-50 pages are just there to put in all the stuff he wanted to say but didn't get a chance (or didn't remember until the end) to write about them. So jumbled. Clearly, a lot of people disagree with me, but I just don't get it. Anyway, no more Erik Larson for me....more

review: Well written and terribly frustrating. Book written in the first person exclusively - so you wander along with Cedar Hawk Songmaker (aka Mary Potts) tWell written and terribly frustrating. Book written in the first person exclusively - so you wander along with Cedar Hawk Songmaker (aka Mary Potts) through the damaged world - 90 degrees is a "cool" day in Northern Minnesota and there hasn't been snow for a long time. Cedar is pregnant and it isn't clear what that means anymore, other than it is unsafe (women are dying in childbirth at fairly high rates). She is pursued - pregnant women are being rounded up for their "safety" and being kept there against their will. So. Cedar's perspective is limited - no larger world view, unclear future. She hides but is caught, escapes and is caught again. I realize I needed a larger world view with some answers. This is a very moving story, just frustrating in its lack of resolution.I have heard so many good things about Erdrich's books that this was disappointing experience, but I have been assured that many of her other books are more satisfying. So, maybe I'll get to The Round House or LaRose. This book does have one of the most haunting sentences I've ever read:"The first thing that happens at the end of the world is that we don't know it is happening."But I needed more resolution in addition to the wonderful prose (some of it is like a fever dream)....more

title: The Soul of America: The Battle for Our Better Angels
author: Meacham, Jon
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Jon Meacham takes the long view of American history in an attempt to put our current turmoil in context. While it is painful to remember just how awfuJon Meacham takes the long view of American history in an attempt to put our current turmoil in context. While it is painful to remember just how awful previous historical periods were, he also reminds us that we climbed out of those low valleys. And although his overall construction is one of two steps forward, one step back, he does remind us that the overall trajectory over time is that we have improved. I generally accepted his thesis, with one big caveat. The most comparable disruptors and leaders of our downward trends in the past century were Huey Long and Joe McCarthy. We've never really had that in a president before, so I'm not sure how to project how low the valley will get, and if we can get out of it in a generation, or if the destabilization of the world order will have to be measured as more like three steps backward, two steps forward before the course correction begins to restore the balance toward evening out and then ultimately the upward trend restores itself.That said, I gained an appreciation of Lyndon Johnson and Andrew Jackson I had not had before. Reading the section "Have You No Sense of Decency?" made me weep. Having lived my most formative years in the 1960's, it was stunning to remember how low we were, and how we soared by the end of that decade.A remarkable book....more

review: Fascinating book about big data and why the government is the only realistic collector, manager, and analyst for such voluminous information. There waFascinating book about big data and why the government is the only realistic collector, manager, and analyst for such voluminous information. There was some alarm raised about how the current administration doesn't know what it has, and generally has the wrong reflexes to use it well. Lewis' point was that the data should be used for the collective good, and not for profit making by a handful of individuals. However, the other important part of the book was in how to understand what can be done with the information for the betterment of humanity generally, and in the case of tracking weather (not climate change, but hurricanes and tornadoes), figuring out what was going on, and how to alert the population in the path of some disastrous weather headed their way.I think I might have appreciated this more in a print version, just because I can ingest and process information better in a written fashion. title: Mercy Falls        (Cork O'Connor, #5)
author: Krueger, William Kent*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: **spoiler alert** I don't want to give up on this series, but I'm sorely tested right now. First of all, I hate books that end with basically a "to be**spoiler alert** I don't want to give up on this series, but I'm sorely tested right now. First of all, I hate books that end with basically a "to be continued" and in particular in this case. Cork O'Connor has been constantly presented as a man who has (over and over and over) put himself and his family in danger in pursuit of his notion of justice. I don't fault him because his sense of justice is written in such a way as to compel the reader to share that same sense of justice. Further, I can imagine Cork cutting and running in order to keep his family safe, but I have two problems with the way he does it here - first of all, the creeps who are after him are said to be after his family also so if he runs, who will protect them; secondly, leaving without letting his family know anything seems very wrong to me and inconsistent with the pig-headed Cork that I have come to know.OK, so I don't like "to be continued" as a general rule. My larger issue:Krueger writes about the natural world in a way that is wonderful. I am often transported to his North Woods by his prose. Example: thanks to William's  on Goodreads, I could cut and paste this pretty easily... "He could have told her. How the Canadian Shield, the stone mass that underlay everything there and broke through the thin topsoil in jagged outcroppings, was the oldest exposed rock on earth. How the glaciers two miles thick had crept across this land over the centuries, scraping everything down to that obdurate rock and leaving, as they receded, lakes as numerous and glittering as the stars in the night sky. How the land was still lifting itself up, released from the weight of that continent of ice, rebounding, a living thing unimaginably patient and enduring."That is writing to die for. However, his character development often frustrates me. His sexism frustrates me (I am hanging on because this book is somewhat dated [2005]; the ongoing joke about Dina's push-up bra made me want to throw the book across the room (well, I was reading on a iPad and I'm not very likely to throw it across the room...). I have never found his kids very convincing. Or his wife. The Anishinaabe, however, he does wonderfully. Maybe they don't feel that way, but I find Kreuger's depiction of them to be masterful. He conveys a real reverence and depth of understanding that you don't often find (Tony Hillerman's Navajo are even better, but that is a VERY high bar).I picked these up because I was truly impressed with his Ordinary Grace (2013). I have been hoping that as these books (O'Connor) progressed, I would see his development as a writer begin to match that standard. So far, it has been very mixed. I'm beginning to believe that the more his true heart is in something, the more compelling the prose. But at this juncture, it almost seems that two different writers are at work here - the natural world and the Native Americans are written by someone with exquisite prose; his characters and their relationships, not so much....more

title: Barracoon: The Story of the Last "Black Cargo"
author: Hurston, Zora Neale
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a remarkable book. And not what I expected. "Cudjo" Lewis has a very singular place in the history of the United States. Brought over from AfrThis is a remarkable book. And not what I expected. "Cudjo" Lewis has a very singular place in the history of the United States. Brought over from Africa on the last voyage of the last ship to bring slaves to America, he also was the last man alive to have have come to America as a slave. Born in 1841 and transported in 1859, he died in 1935. One of the most amazing achievements of this book is that Zora Neale Thurston insisted that the printed word reflect Cudjo's vernacular, delaying its publication from 1931 when she tried to get it published until 2018 - well after her death as well as Cudjo's death.The first person narrative of the middle passage and living in slavery was much mellower than the typical treatment given to the subject matter. Not rainbows and ponies, but Cudjo considered his owner to be a fair man (as these things go) and the far greater trauma was inflicted by the rival tribe in Africa that captured him and sold him to slave traders, not his owner in America. But the greatest trauma of all was the loss of his wife and 6 children, who all died before he did. Only one of his sons produced a lineage that survives to this day.Definitely worth reading and mulling over quietly....more
