title: Every Heart a Doorway        (Wayward Children, #1)
author: McGuire, Seanan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I always saw myself as someone who loved science fiction -- not fantasy. Magic and fairy dust weren't for me - give me a rocket ship and inhospitable I always saw myself as someone who loved science fiction -- not fantasy. Magic and fairy dust weren't for me - give me a rocket ship and inhospitable planets to be conquered and I was in my bliss. There were cracks in that armor - Anne McCaffrey's Pern series, Ursula LeGuin's Wizard of Earthsea, Tolkien. But those had a few elements that have always drawn me to them, most notably dragons, elves, swords, historical fiction, and other such elements. But my rationalizations pretty much went by the board with Dune, Mists of Avalon, and of course, Game of Thrones and everything Naomi Novik writes. Finally, I just had to acknowledge that I was a sucker for a good story. Preferably one with richly drawn characters with wit."Every Heart a Doorway" meets those tests, and with an ache that took me back to the anguish of adolescence. I do believe that everyone has a memory storeroom of childhood fantasies that house an alternative childhood. In my case, it was one where I could fly, with or without dragons or Pegasus. This story is about other lives that are not fading fantasies, but where the experiences were real. (And by extension, perhaps so were mine....) A sampling of wonderful writing:"Narrate the impossible things, turn them into a story, and they could be controlled.""She was a story, not an epilogue.""Hope hurts. That's what you need to learn, and fast, if you don't want it to cut you open from the inside out. Hope is bad. Hope means you keep on holding to things that won't ever be so again, and so you bleed an inch at a time until there's nothing left.""You know, I read 'Alice's Adventures in Wonderland' when I was a kid, and I never thought about what it would be like for Alice when she went back to where she'd started. I figured she'd just shrug and get over it. But I can't do that. Every time I close my eyes, I'm back in my real bed, in my real rooms, and all of this is the dream.""That's the thing people forget when they start talking about things in terms of good and evil," said Jack, turning to look at Lundy. She adjusted her glasses as she continued, "For us, the places we went were home. We didn't care if they were good or evil or neutral or what. We cared about the fact that for the first time, we didn't have to pretend to be something we weren't. We just got to be. That made all the difference in the world."I loved this story so much I promptly re-read it as soon as I finished.8/6/2018: Editing, because I cannot believe that I left out Ray Bradbury, possibly my favorite of all, who was pretty completely fantasy (yes, he used the term Martian, but his Mars was not exactly scientifically based....). He was also one of the best writers who ever lived. So, mea culpa. My embarrassment is complete, but necessarily acknowledged....more

title: The Great Alone
author: Hannah, Kristin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I love Alaska. Its magic captured me over 40 years ago and has never really left. When I read a book like this, I spend some time reminiscing and pondI love Alaska. Its magic captured me over 40 years ago and has never really left. When I read a book like this, I spend some time reminiscing and pondering “what if?” My experiences were in roughly the same time frame - 1970/72 and much of the description rings true. But I wasn’t subjected to abuse by someone who purportedly loved me, and I had a much cushier existence. Sure, it hit 60 below. We had “moose alerts” and that unbelievable ice fog and the occasional dumpster diving bear. But I was in an apartment in Fairbanks that had running water and electricity. However, Hannah gets it right about the unbelievable quality of the light during the summer, and the oppressiveness of the dark in winter (if you are prone to seasonal affective disorder, you will find out in Alaska). And the joy of the ice breakup and the Northern Lights. While I liked the story itself and the readability generally, I always felt at a bit of a remove. I had the same problem with The Nightingale. Somehow, Hannah’s writing doesn’t emotionally connect with me as much as I think it should. But this is probably a book worth reading....more

review: Winner of both the Nebula and the Hugo for 2016. What could go wrong? Nothing, exactly. I can see why it got a lot of praise and awards, but it just sWinner of both the Nebula and the Hugo for 2016. What could go wrong? Nothing, exactly. (The protagonist, Binti, is 16, however, so maybe not a surprise.)The writing is good, especially the harmonic/mathematics/fractal etc types of discussion/descriptions. Very inventive and brought out nicely an artistic appreciation of mathematics/physics. Binti is very likeable, first in her family/community/tribe/country to attend prestigious university (in space!). Very good start in the "girl leaves home, hearth, culture, and leaves stultifying community to explore the universe" story. It was proceeding nicely when all of a sudden it became a different story. And one I had a lot more trouble buying into - still interesting, just too far off the tracks to get back on for me. But it was nice and short, and the fish-out-of-water start was really good, so 3 stars....more

title: The Little Book of Hygge: The Danish Way to Live Well
author: Wiking, Meik
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Well, certainly worked as a palate cleanser for my last book about murderous mermaids. But I got tired just reading it. Who can keep up with all the sWell, certainly worked as a palate cleanser for my last book about murderous mermaids. But I got tired just reading it. Who can keep up with all the suggestions? And don't the Danes work? (Well, yes, they do, but they all leave at 4pm if they have kids, and 5pm if they don't. Who has jobs like that and can still afford all the candles? And ski trips in the mountains with your friends?) I did my usual thing of what could I (minimally) do to achieve this bliss? Not a very good book for those of us who are always looking for the easy way out...Was befuddled on how I could possibly write a "" and looked up other people's s and found a perfect one - credit to Lily, wherever you are. Here is her :"Lifecycle of an idea:1) hear about it on NPR2) identify with it. tell friends about it.3) buy book about it.4) begin reading book.5) realise there are suddenly *a lot* of books on this topic.6) start to suspect book is just a big advertisement put out by one of those agencies that determines what will be trendy for next season.7) book seems to really want you to buy woolen socks.8) book is poorly written and repeats itself.9) see a new twee danish crap store in your big mall.10) reach peak despair.11) burn book. the crackling fire, you are told, is very hygge.12) find peace with the ease with which the corporate world manipulates your interests and desires.13) write a goodreads ."Clearly, Lily put more thought into this than I did - and I never would have BOUGHT it. That is what libraries are for. So, I'm bidding the candles and warm socks good-bye without having to burn a book.......more

title: The Whore's Child and Other Stories
author: Russo, Richard*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Russo's writing is meant to be savored. I forget that sometimes, and try to rush things along. And then I remember and go back and take my time with eRusso's writing is meant to be savored. I forget that sometimes, and try to rush things along. And then I remember and go back and take my time with each word and phrase and I am moved. As I was making my way through this collection of stories, some short, some not-so-short, I was becoming overwhelmed with the morose and beleaguered sensibility that Russo's work is often steeped in. And then I remembered.... "slow down, you move too fast." While these stories are not generally imbued with the slapstick observational humor I so adore in his writing (and which serves to leaven the woebegotten nature of some of his observations), they are full of wistfulness. And they are lovely gems. But if you read them, slower is better. Savor. And, of course, the last story made me weep. As your guitar gently does....or young boys and baseball. A few comments on each, with some lengthy quotes: 1. The Whore's Child - an ancient nun joins a creative writing class, and pretends she is writing fiction. Russo's introduction to the story, humor and despair paired together: "Sister Ursula belonged to an all but extinct order of Belgian nuns who conducted what little spiritual business remained to them in a decrepit old house purchased by the diocese seemingly because it was unlikely to outlast them." 2. Monhegan Light - Many years after his wife's death, Martin sees her through the eyes of her former lover, and finally understands how much he squandered. But first, a slice of that wicked observational humor regarding his wife's sister, whom he loathes: "Of all the things that Joyce's sort of woman said about men, Martin disliked the he-just-doesn't-get-it riff most of all. For one thing it presupposed there was something to get, usually something obvious, something you'd have to be blind not to see. And of course the reason you couldn't see it -- as women were happy to explain -- was that you had a dick, as if that poor, maligned appendage were constantly in a man's line of sight, blocking his view of what women, who were not similarly encumbered, wanted him to take notice of, something subtle or delicate or beautiful, at least to their way of thinking. If you didn't agree that it was subtle or delicate or beautiful, it was because you had a dick. You just didn't get it." 3. The Farther You Go - A man finally realizes the true depth of his wife's understanding of him. A strange, but ultimately beautiful, trip. Literally.4. Joy Ride - The most depressing of the lot. A child's first person experience with his parents' dysfunctional relationship.  5. Buoyancy - A sad, confused tale of a long and passionless marriage that ends with sunshine and unicorns. And you are made happy. But only after a lot of confusion and sadness.6. Poison - if you have read much of Russo, you probably know about his rage at the poisoning of the rivers and streams in his home town by a chemical company with the usual corporate greed. While all of Russo's writing never seems too far from his own experiences, this one is particularly and sadly close to the bone. The poison of the title is both for the actual poisoning of the town he grew up in, and the poisoning of his relationship with a boyhood friend who is also a writer, whose rage exceeds his own. I suspect Russo is both characters....7. The Mysteries of Linwood Hart - Ten-year old Linwood Hart, who has been described by school personnel as "possessing an active interior life", which as all who have been trained in edu-speak, correctly translate as "he doesn't pay attention." His father is a jerk ("Slick" is his nick name), but sadly, his mother can't quit him. A lengthy passage, but one that puts you into Linwood's first person, and one, I have to admit, I greatly identified with... Someone asks him, what do you think you are? Special?"Lin understood that this was a rhetorical question whose answer was supposed to be "No," even though most of the time, he thought it might be "yes." It was hard to imagine that all of his personal thoughts had already been thought. When he lay on his stomach in the grass and watched an ant climb up one side of a blade and then down the other, his truest sense of things was that in the world's long history, no one had ever witnessed this exact event, and he couldn't help feeling special to have done so. Why shouldn't his thoughts be special, too? What if he was right to think them, even if no one else had?For instance, why shouldn't inanimate objects be capable of desire? Take leaves. They wanted to dance, didn't they? He understood that it was caused by wind, of course, but this didn't explain why they didn't all get up and dance with each new gust, instead of just certain ones. Leaf A would rise and do its jig while Leaf B, right next to it, wouldn't even stir. The ones dancing in this gust might rest during the next, and to Lin, this meant they were expressing a desire. And Wiffle balls. Their frantic wiggle after leaping off a plastic bat suggested a similar desire, though his father, who at the moment wasn't living with Lin and his mother, explained that the symmetrical holes cut into the plastic sphere were responsible for the ball's erratic and exciting flight. Okay, but to Lin's way of thinking, the holes merely set free the inner spirit of the ball."Having spent a lot of my elementary school days in such contemplation, I was all in with Linwood....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A fantastic book. Not quite as good as Children of Time, but right up there, and a lot of echoes. Instead of falling in love with Portia, a VERY smartA fantastic book. Not quite as good as Children of Time, but right up there, and a lot of echoes. Instead of falling in love with Portia, a VERY smart arachnid, I became attached to Stevland, a rainbow colored bamboo. As a small group of humans, fleeing a ravaged earth, attempt to colonize a planet they will name Pax (yeah, I know, not the most inspired choice, but it works) they become aware that the plant life on Pax is manipulating them. Actually, and more accurately, trying to domesticate them. So, first plant/person POV is a bit unnerving, but you get used to it.Since the bamboo/Stevland pretty much thinks all animals are hopelessly stupid, it/he/she isn't very concerned with the survival of the humans. The ability to exploit them is its goal. Of course, dear reader, you probably have a reasonable idea of how smart most humans think plants are. So - failure to communicate, and humans unknowingly in a death spiral. Very creative and enjoyable....more

title: All Systems Red        (The Murderbot Diaries, #1)
author: Wells, Martha*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really enjoyed this book. Actively. While reading. Told from a first person POV, or first robot POV, a Sec-bot (security robot) who calls herself MuI really enjoyed this book. Actively. While reading. Told from a first person POV, or first robot POV, a Sec-bot (security robot) who calls herself Murderbot has achieved sentience. Or free agency. Of course, to maintain that freedom, she must conceal that fact from her clients/employers or risk dis-assembly and brain wipe (I'm paraphrasing, but you get the gist). When we meet her, she is busy watching soap operas on a back feed while guarding some clients on a planetary survey. They are attacked by something with a large mouth and very big teeth; not to worry, Murderbot saves the day, but the real question is "what was that thing and why were they not warned of its existence in the background information about the planet"?And we go on the ride while Murderbot and her human companions set out to find out why/how their expedition has been sabotaged. Lots of technical details and problem solving of the kind I really like. But the best part is getting to know Murderbot, because she is smart and snarky.Another thing to like is that it is pretty short - actually a novella - and that is nominated for the Hugo for 2018. And deservedly so.I've already pre-ordered #2 in the series. That's how smitten I am.P.S. I'm calling Murderbot a "she" because I can. There is no actual gender specification in the book.May 1, 2018I am updating this  because I realized I left out a very important component of why this book is so special. Murderbot is not really a robot, she is a cyborg. Part organic, part machine. And that complicates things, mostly from the human point of view. As a machine, she is part of the furniture - a useful tool. As they interact with her more (and she with them) and they begin to realize something is "off", the interactions become much more awkward. Sort of like junior high school, but with implications of "is this a slave relationship"? This question is explored somewhat, but at a remove because from Murderbot's POV, it isn't very interesting. When she's not in active saving-all-their-asses mode, she just wants to get back to her soap opera programs.So, on top of the thrilling adventure part, a real exploration of what it means to be human (or not) is beginning. Luckily, Murderbot will be back....more

author: Locke, Attica
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Very interesting mystery. Incredible sense of place. Not a place I want to spend a lot of time in, but enough for me to "get" why people who grew up tVery interesting mystery. Incredible sense of place. Not a place I want to spend a lot of time in, but enough for me to "get" why people who grew up there miss it, and often go back. Lots of food (BBQ, oxtails, grease, salt, bourbon, beer) and vehicles (mostly trucks - the BMWs are for the outsiders) in extensive and loving detail. The characters were very detailed, but sometimes not very likeable. I'm sure the author knew she was using what are usually perceived as virtues and showing us how they are "virtuous to a fault". And I am tired of heroes who drink too much and end up in the middle of - well, what that usually brings - violence and mayhem. And while I know the overwhelming racism is the point, it isn't casual, and it can get overwhelming and painful. Again, I know that is exactly what the author intends, but unrelenting misery takes its toll.So, a five-star book wrapped in pain, without quite enough redemption for me to give it the five stars it probably deserves....more

title: A Natural History of Dragons        (The Memoirs of Lady Trent, #1)
author: Brennan, Marie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is probably not really a five star book based on the factors I usually use - the quality of the prose, character development and the plot, but I'This is probably not really a five star book based on the factors I usually use - the quality of the prose, character development and the plot, but I'm awarding five for the wonderful nostalgia and emotion I experienced whilst reading. Yes, whilst. That is a clue. The story and mystery are modest. But the person of Isabella, aka Lady Trent, evoked my childhood reading in a powerful way. This book purports to be a memoir of her first adventure that involved dragons.By the standards of her day, Isabella was what in my day was referred to as a "tomboy". It was not a compliment. The setting appears to be a sort of Victorian England in a parallel universe. The major difference is that in this world, dragons exist. They are not romantic or friendly or even fire-breathing. And the idea of riding them is not even remotely considered. The nostalgia comes from such things as:(A) the naming of chapters and parts and their descriptions, e.g. "Part One - in which the memoirist forms a youthful obsession with dragons, and engineers an opportunity to pursue that obsession". Each chapter has many subparts and every page is subtitled in the same way as the parts and chapters are. Examples: p. 19 header: "My obsession with wings"; p.21 header "My family"; p.23 header "The influence of Sir Richard Edgeworth". (B) The pages are yellowed in a way found in books that have been in the attic for forty years, or at a used book store for ten. It even has a faint whiff of those books. I don't know how. This was published in 2013.(C) Fussy, fusty, formal speech. Here is an example, wherein Isabella is about to (illegally) participate in a dragon hunt wearing trousers: "To his credit, Jim blushed when he saw me dressed so scandalously. He was a good lad. But he helped me bundle my hair up under a cap, and with it hidden, I believe I made a passable boy. I was not done growing then, and was all coltish arms and legs, with not much to speak of yet in the way of hips or breasts. (And why is it, I ask you, that my editor should complain to me of such words when I have written several books discussing dragon anatomy and reproduction in far more frank terms? He will not wish to leave this aside in, I predict, but I shall make him. There are advantages to my age and status.)"(D) There are illustrations. Of dragons. Pencil sketches! (See the cover.) They are wonderful.Isabella, Lady Trent, is a spunky heroine in the manner of Jo March in Little Women. Reading this book took me back to my early tween years (8-13 or so) when I would take ten library books on a one-week vacation with my family to Cape Cod or camping in the Adirondacks. Those were the years when my mother would be constantly exasperated with me because I never responded to her calls for help, or for coming to dinner, or going to bed, because I was in other worlds. Those were the years when one summer I read every Nancy Drew book in print. And all of the Black Stallion, Big Red books. Not to mention Jules Verne, or Marguerite Henry's horse books. And Edgar Rice Burroughs. And Dracula and Frankenstein. I could go on, but I'm assuming, dear reader, you get the point....and I am beginning to irritate even myself.So, yes, I was reliving those years when I read "A Natural History of Dragons". And I had a wonderful time....more

review: Definitely a step down from Pillars of the Earth and World Without End. Same devices used - star-crossed lovers, bad guys are very bad. However, it moDefinitely a step down from Pillars of the Earth and World Without End. Same devices used - star-crossed lovers, bad guys are very bad. However, it moved along and was nice historical fiction coverage of the religious wars in the late 16th century. And one highlight for me was a very nice blow-by-blow of the English fleet and the Spanish Armada encounter. The English didn't exactly "win", but they controlled the battles and strategically kept the Spanish from using their strength. And more importantly, prevented them from invading. Better than a draw, and total humiliation for the Spanish. I loved the fire-ships (Game of Thrones, anyone?) and the scrappy undersized merchant ships used by the English. The writing was clumsy. The characterizations were weak. I never really cared about the protagonists, and disliked, rather than hated, the bad guys.Glad I read it, but the thrill was definitely modest compared to the first two....more

title: Homegoing
author: Gyasi, Yaa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is a stunning achievement. But it is brutal. While brutality can bother me, it doesn't usually get in the way of my ability to appreciate soThis book is a stunning achievement. But it is brutal. While brutality can bother me, it doesn't usually get in the way of my ability to appreciate something, but it did here.The concept - the lives of two half-sisters and their descendants are traced across generations for a total time span of some 250 years, beginning around 1760 and ending in the modern day - is brilliant. Their respective villages are on the western coast of Africa in what is modern-day Ghana, near the infamous Gold Coast Castle, a major port of departure for the slave trade. But one side remains in Africa, and the other is sold into slavery and transported to America.Through eight generations, the book alternates between Effia and Esi and their descendants. Bad things happen to both lineages. In the end, a connection is made between the two lines by their modern day representatives, but they have no idea that they have a common ancestor, Maame, who is the m0ther of Effia and Esi. But both Marjorie and Marcus, the current day descendants, are free and self-determining in a way that would be unimaginable to virtually all of their ancestors. They both have issues, of the type most of us can identify with. But more importantly, they still carry forward the damage done by the slave trade and colonialism over the generations. They are doing their best to understand their historical pasts. Marjorie, in particular, is a not-very-thinly-veiled stand in for the author. So it would appear that this novel is the fruit of the research she undertook to understand her roots. Her deep roots.A well done book. But I am exhausted from the heartbreak and unfairness that has existed, and continues to exist in the world....more

title: Artemis
author: Weir, Andy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Can't finish. This is a real disappointment for me. I loved The Martian so much - I badgered friends and family to read it. But all the things that woCan't finish. This is a real disappointment for me. I loved The Martian so much - I badgered friends and family to read it. But all the things that worked so well in The Martian aren't here. I want to give the author credit for trying a female protagonist, but it doesn't work. This is more like Mark Watney, but not funny and not likeable and with a female voice, but not really. The Martian was a page-turner - it started off with a bang and never let up. Every minute, every day was a fight for survival and science was his friend. A compelling, exciting story. This one is a weird heist novel, confusing and a caper for money - basically so she afford to buy housing that has her own bathroom. Pretty weak tea compared to staying alive as a motivator. Maybe that changes as the story develops, but I'm not going to stick around to find out. It is too painful. And the science in this book is a bore. It feels more like Jazz is showing off, rather than the way Mark needed (and loved) science to survive.At first I thought it might be the reader in the audiobook, so I switched off to the print version. Didn't help.I hope others like it, because I feel like Andy Weir deserves it as recompense for giving us The Martian. But I can't go on with it....more

title: Al Franken: Giant of the Senate
author: Franken, Al
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Not a lot of surprises, but very enjoyable. I already knew he was smart and thoughtful, and also knew he had to severely restrain his humor in order tNot a lot of surprises, but very enjoyable. I already knew he was smart and thoughtful, and also knew he had to severely restrain his humor in order to run, get elected, and serve effectively. Or as he characterizes it, he (and his staff) need to run everything through a “de-humorizer”. But not to write a book. Nonetheless, he still has some guard rails up.What I found most interesting is his determined optimism. As a former government employee, I am dubious about the ability of someone who has no government experience to be effective in an elected position. (See, for instance, our current president.) But he has proven to be the exception to the rule. In addition to the aforementioned smart and thoughtful, he has a work ethic that is amazing. Further, he also is always searching for common ground on policy issues, without giving up any of his progressiveness. He admits this sometimes means he is limited to the small, yet important pieces. But he never stops looking. And he seems to have good personal relationships with all of his fellow senators. Well, except for Ted Cruz... If you are interested in public policy, especially as pursued by a talented individual, you should enjoy this, even in these dark days....more

title: Going Into Town: A Love Letter to New York
author: Chast, Roz
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I grew up in New York State. Upstate. Which bears about as much resemblance to New York City as Ukiah does to Los Angeles. But since we were only abouI grew up in New York State. Upstate. Which bears about as much resemblance to New York City as Ukiah does to Los Angeles. But since we were only about 75 miles away, I did have occasion to visit New York City. I seldom liked it (it was dirty, it was loud), but I have wonderful memories of the Museum of Natural History (dinosaurs, whales, dioramas galore), the Museum of Modern Art (weird, wonderful stuff - a trip without drugs!), and a couple of Broadway plays - "How to Succeed in Business without Really Trying" with a very young Robert Morse, and "You Know I Can't Hear You When the Water's Running" - if my mother had known how bawdy it was, I don't think she would ever have agreed to let my grandmother - yes, my grandmother - take me to see it.So, I read this memoir-ish graphic novel with a fond eye - both for the dirt/dog poop as well as the culture that were EVERYWHERE. Side-by-side.However, for me, this collection suffers in comparison with Chast's "Can't We Talk About Something More Pleasant?". This was a pleasant, fun, two hour stroll down memory lane. "Can't We Talk.." was a gut punch - I had been immersed in end-of-life books/articles etc at that time due to my own personal situation my father, and it RESONATED. I recommend both - but they are very different experiences, depending on your own personal journies... Chast is a remarkable observer and chronicler. Enjoy!...more

title: The Western Star        (Walt Longmire, #13)
author: Johnson, Craig
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Well, hell. Not really boy howdy. I enjoyed this book, don't get me wrong, but not a strong entry in the Longmire saga.Good stuff: (1) explores Walt'sWell, hell. Not really boy howdy. I enjoyed this book, don't get me wrong, but not a strong entry in the Longmire saga.Good stuff: (1) explores Walt's early days as a deputy with Lucien Connelly (two weeks in) and his struggles with his marriage (four months in). I would have liked more Martha, but interesting to have her fleshed out at all. (2) Also the usual good stuff of spending time with Walt and the Cheyenne Nation, but not enough. (3) An interesting aspect was the split nature of the novel - half in modern day, half in 1972. (4) The usual side trips into details about some interesting topic - in this case, passenger trains. I love trains in general, but passenger trains have such a romatic lure. I happily eat up Craig Johnson's side trips.Problems: (1) I hate cliff-hangers, and this is where boy howdy is appropriate...it is a very frustrating cliff hanger. (2) The movement between the time splits was sometimes narratively confusing - it happened with no warning and often there wasn't enough context to have the light bulb go off until I was a few paragraphs in and muttering what just happened until "oh, we're back in 1972" or vice versa. (3) The mystery that WAS solved had a problematic basis - very dated psychologically...seemed very un-Walt like. (4) The structure of the mystery was a salute to Agatha Christie - murders on a train, red herrings, etc. Walt was even reading "Murder on the Orient Express" during the happenings. Have I mentioned I'm not a fan of English murder mysteries - overly complicated, overly populated with possible murderers, and the solution comes as a result of something that was not reasonable to my American (simple) mind.Overall, I am starting to believe that Johnson is being pushed too hard by his publishers. The need to have a new Longmire "something" is interfering with the quality of the product. I will always buy whatever Johnson writes, but I would rather wait two years between books than have a rushed incomplete (which is what cliff-hangers are to me) novel, two years in a row. I probably should have rated this one 2 or 3 stars, but the goodwill earned over the years still compels my rating it 4 stars. Besides, the parts where Walt and Vic and Henry are working something out (otherwise known as bickering) haven't lost the magic....more

title: Beartown        (Beartown, #1)
author: Backman, Fredrik*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Beartown is a very, very good story with compelling and vividly drawn characters. The prose can wander a bit, but those digressions seldom interfere (Beartown is a very, very good story with compelling and vividly drawn characters. The prose can wander a bit, but those digressions seldom interfere (much) with the story. And, in the end, the digressions are purposeful, just sometimes too easy to get lost in them.There is a major moral dilemma at the beating heart of Beartown. While there is a clear right and wrong side of that issue, Bachman is masterful at dissecting the human frailties that make the right and wrong less clear - not as an outside observer/reader, but as a member of a tribe. The tribe is literally a hockey team; at one remove is the secondary tribe of the team's supporters, who live in the small isolated town that the team comes from.As you grow to know the characters, you are made to understand what it means to step outside and/or to exist outside of the tribe. And how punishing and unforgiving that position can be, and how powerful the yearning to belong is. Humans are tribal, morality is not. I picked this book up because the author wrote A Man Called Ove. I will now read whatever he decides to write.May 22, 2018Just finished re-reading for book club. Laughed, cried all over again. Just a fabulous book....more

title: The Late Show        (Renée Ballard, #1; Harry Bosch Universe, #30)
author: Connelly, Michael*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Well, Connelly introduces a new character, Renee Ballard, and I like her a lot. She has several through lines with Harry Bosch - smart, obsessive, priWell, Connelly introduces a new character, Renee Ballard, and I like her a lot. She has several through lines with Harry Bosch - smart, obsessive, prickly, rules are for others, social life will always be stunted because the job comes first, second, third, you get the drift. Also appears to not need sleep or food, a la Harry. Where Bosch is sort of a deep growl, Renee is a bark often with a bite. As one of her co-workers remarks after getting his head handed to him, "(t)ake it easy, Ballard. Sometimes you're like a feral fucking cat...". As I said, I like her a lot.She is clearly damaged goods, but that is something to look forward to exploring in future books.As a Connelly novel, the clues add up and puzzles are solved. Three cases are presented on the first night (the late show, get it), and all three are more complicated than first presented, and all are doggedly pursued to the finish. Admittedly, one is dealt with more completely than the others.Connelly also uses the casual sexism of law enforcement types to make several points, and does it well. For starters, one reason Ballard is on "the late show" is as punishment for bringing charges of sexual harassment against a supervisor - the charges were dismissed as the boys in blue closed ranks around her supervisor. But, again, that doesn't stop her. Since she is willing to work almost 24/7, the only problems posed are with the practicalities of her assignments. Most people, including her partner, aren't interested in 24/7.If you like Harry, you'll probably like Renee. It would be interesting for Connelly to pair them up sometime... one of her cases spilling into one of those cold cases Harry sometimes works....more

title: The Nix
author: Hill, Nathan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It was the best of writing. It was the worst of writing.Hence, 3 stars, using the averaging method of A+F=C.Tortured son. Tortured mother. And the fatIt was the best of writing. It was the worst of writing.Hence, 3 stars, using the averaging method of A+F=C.Tortured son. Tortured mother. And the father of the mother may be/have been the most tortured soul of all. This is a book of contradictions. Stunningly well written, yet I felt crushed by its dense prose by the end of the book. If one were able to read a 600 page book at a slow rate, say 20 pages a day, so one could savor the depth of the writing without becoming overwhelmed by its denseness, I think it would be a joy. Alas, I am not such a reader. And yet. I am glad I read this book, and even happier to have finished it. But about a third of the way in, I realized that it was going to be a tough slog.Literary fiction ers compare this to the works of David Foster Wallace and Jonathan Franzen. I dunno, don't really read them. For me, it sometimes soared up there with Richard Russo and John Irving, two of my favorite writers. And I liked the plot. Just waaaaaay too long in coming.Ranting, rambling, run-on sentences/paragraphs. Hilarious. Exhausting.A nice summing up of my frustration from Goodreads Q&A page:Q: I've only started reading but I'm curious: do we ever find out why Faye leaves?A: Matt: by the time you find out, you will have ceased caring.Well, I did care, but man, I still would have cared if the book had been half the length....more

review: Well written, but I had to push myself to finish it. The book does such a good job of putting you in the middle of the action/nonaction that when the Well written, but I had to push myself to finish it. The book does such a good job of putting you in the middle of the action/nonaction that when the protagonist is brutalized, you feel brutalized. Unfortunately, it does such a good job of describing the fog of war, the horrors of refugee situations, etc that I became numb and just wanted it to end.I can see why this has gotten some rave s. But I can't give it high marks, because I need to get some enjoyment out of reading, no matter how bleak the circumstances. No humor. No relief.The best part of the book was the setup and the occasional faux syllabi (or court testimony from 2123, etc) recapping the dates, causes, and major events of the civil war, which is/will be/was from 2074 t0 2095. And a nice little map to go with it, showing what damage climate change has/will/had done to the Gulf Coast - most of foot of the Louisiana boot is gone, and well as pretty much all of Florida. title: The Long Way to a Small, Angry Planet        (Wayfarers, #1)
author: Chambers, Becky*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really enjoyed this despite a somewhat thin plot, and good, but not great, character development. (Also, if you are a science nerd, this one uses maI really enjoyed this despite a somewhat thin plot, and good, but not great, character development. (Also, if you are a science nerd, this one uses many common tropes that undermine its credibility.) However, this novel explores an area that is one of the best uses of science fiction that there is: the understanding of humanity by using a lot of not-humans. The crew of the Wayfarer is species divergent - humans, sure, but also a reptilian pilot (but don't use the term publicly - it is very speciest, kind of like the N-word to one of that species), a cook with 6 legs/arms and 5 vocal chords who has to do all the work in communicating with humans, and an especially endearing A.I. Of course, one of the humans is a nasty racist speciest, so everything is not all unicorns - hmmm, am I mixing metaphors, or just babbling?Lots of other species in their travels, too. And, lest I forget, humans are pretty low in the prestige chain, galaxy-wide speaking. Evidently a lot of disagreement about allowing them into the Galactic Commons, the governing body for everyone/body/thing.A lot of this book works on how such divergent beings can get along. And it does it by exploring the various cultures and their value systems through human eyes, and vice-versa (although not everyone/body/thing has eyes...). Kind of a galactic anthropology course through story telling.I am/was surprised how much I liked this book, because I value plot and character development above all else, and this wasn't especially strong in those categories. But it is a great exploration of how culture shapes values, and how species characteristics shape the perceptions that create those cultures and values in the first place.A quote that might sum it up: "Harmagians had money. Aeluons had firepower. Aandrisks had diplomacy. Humans had arguments."...more

title: Seven Stones to Stand or Fall        (Outlander 0.5, 2.5, 7.5 & 8.5)
author: Gabaldon, Diana*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Seven novellas from the Outlander world. Five have been included in previous anthologies, two new ones, "Fugitive Green" and "Besieged". Gabaldon tendSeven novellas from the Outlander world. Five have been included in previous anthologies, two new ones, "Fugitive Green" and "Besieged". Gabaldon tends to feature John Grey in her "non-big books" in the series. I adore John Grey, but not necessarily in these novellas. He seems to work much better when paired against Jamie or Claire or Bree. In the two new novellas, he is featured in "Besieged", which I honestly didn't like much. Whole bunch of to-ing and fro-ing, bit of focus on the zombie stuff (which I've never been a fan of) in a mission to rescue his mother (whom I like a lot). When the plot leaves something to be desired, the amount of verbiage dedicated to tastes and smells stands out, not in a good way. So, maybe two stars for that one. Maybe one."Fugitive Green" was more enjoyable, and tells the tale of how/"when Hal met Minnie". Hal is John Grey's older brother (there's the JG connection), who is a minor, but important character in the main books. Gruff and cranky, he was responsible for Jamie being sent home alive after Culloden as a debt of honor John Grey owed to Jamie. Hal and Minnie (and their fascinating marriage) are nice interludes in the main books. While there was a lot to like in this telling of their meeting and "courtship", it does stretch credulity that a strong marriage would be the result of these interactions, but still, I enjoyed the story, more of a 3/4 star story.One of the nicest features of the book is the author's pretty detailed chronological outline of all her Outlander works - the big books, the novellas, and what she calls "the bulges", which approach more short story length. This includes the years covered as well as a bit of a description for each. Oh, as for the other five previously published works, by far my favorite (of all seven, for that matter) is "A Leaf on the Wind of All Hallows", which tells the tale of Roger MacKenzie's parents, and how/why he was orphaned, especially with respect to his father. Roger had been told all of his life that his father had "gone down" over the English Channel during World War II. Well, as it turns out, not exactly........more

I could never have imagined a not-exactly-first-person narrative from inside a spider's mind, but I now believe. This is one of the best books I've read in a while. Imaginative, detailed (who knew arachnids and insects could be so interesting) and a hell of an action story. And when Portia and her folks face off against the last humans in the universe, let's just say I wasn't rooting for the humans.If you like good sci-fi and lots of detailed explorations of biology, ecology, as well as an explanation of how ants are not anything like spiders, topped off with a very MAD SCIENTIST, you must read this book....more

title: News of the World
author: Jiles, Paulette*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Beautifully written story of a 70+ year old man who assumes responsibility for returning a 10 year old girl to her estranged family. It is set in a veBeautifully written story of a 70+ year old man who assumes responsibility for returning a 10 year old girl to her estranged family. It is set in a very specific time and place - 1870 Texas - a very dangerous time and place. The girl was captured by the Kiowa at the age of six, and witnessed the slaughter/violation of her parents and sister. Four years later, she has no (or very little) memory of her life before the Kiowa, and is violently opposed to her separation from them.For his part, Captain Jefferson Kidd reads the "news of the world" for audiences up and down the state of Texas. He rents out a hall, and for a dime, people are admitted to hear him read somewhat dated news from newspapers of London, New York, Chicago, etc. He is careful to avoid anything about the politics in Texas, since post-Civil War Texas has not yet been re-admitted to statehood following its secession in 1861. Reading anything about that topic seems to be is a fairly certain way to be attacked if not killed. He reluctantly agrees to take the girl across the state to return her to her aunt and uncle, knowing it is not a good idea. If nothing else, the girl is fully capable of killing him in his sleep. Communication is impossible, since she remembers no English and his Kiowa is similarly non-existent.What follows is a beautiful, if violent and frightening, travelogue across Texas and the slow but growing bond between them.Read it.(Teaser: you will never view a roll of dimes the same way again....)...more

review: This book took a long time to read - some of that was because of the utter strangeness, but I suspect more was due to my trying to read it at bedtime.This book took a long time to read - some of that was because of the utter strangeness, but I suspect more was due to my trying to read it at bedtime. Never a good idea. A spectacularly bad idea with a book like this. It is hard to convey very much without entering spoiler territory. But...The blurb on the back says "a mash-up of Margaret Atwood and Roald Dahl". That's not a bad descriptor, but I might describe it as Boko Haram in Wales... and a bit of the Wizard of Oz.At any rate, this is one of those books where you begin by saying WTF? many, many times. Who are these girls? Is Calamity just the most unreliable narrator that has ever existed, or is she so damaged she might be acting rationally under the circumstances?The creativity of the author is best described as layered, multi-faceted, take your pick. The underlying architecture/narrative of the story is amazing in and of itself. But the details. There are so many pop cultural references woven in that it took me a while to realize how dense and deft they were. For instance, some of the girls' names (in addition to Calamity Leek, which is pretty clever) are: Annie St. Albans, Dorothy Macclesfield, Truly Polperro, and a trio of younger girls: Adelaide, Cinderella, and Fantine... you get the picture. A lot of googling on my part. And many, many rose varieties. WTF?The head of this operation is "Aunty" who is a cross between Miss Trunchbull from Matilda and Norma Desmond. Your introduction to her comes when several of the girls are somewhere they are not supposed to be, and you know Aunty is getting closer to their hiding place because they can hear her singing softly, "I feel pretty, oh so pretty.." then as she gets closer, "I feel charming", followed by "see the pretty girl in the mirror there". I cannot tell you how creepy this scene is.There is a Creation story, and Calamity helpfully writes a"A Book on How to Be Beautiful (Unless You're too Cooked Already)". And you're only 50 pages in at this point.I will say that I almost gave up several times because it was so hard to make sense of it. But hang on and when you are done, re-read the first 50 pages or so to really appreciate the genius.Not recommended for those who don't like world-building. Or puzzles....more

title: The Tsar of Love and Techno
author: Marra, Anthony*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Astonishing. It is hard to imagine how a book so dark and disturbing can also be so hilarious. First, there are the settings: (a) 100 miles north of tAstonishing. It is hard to imagine how a book so dark and disturbing can also be so hilarious. First, there are the settings: (a) 100 miles north of the Arctic Circle in Siberia, and (b) Chechnya. And if Siberia isn't bleak enough for you, wait until you get a load of how much fun those it was during the height of the Stalinist purges (circa 1937) and then when the USSR collapsed and the economy went completely into the toilet (1990's). And, of course, we visit Chechnya during the Chechen-Russian "conflict" in the early 2000's.It is also hard to believe that an American could write such a book. The book is steeped in Russian culture/history and with the characters imbued with the DNA of the Russians that populate Dostoevsky's novels. That is, a general sense of doom and a sense that suffering is the national pastime. I don't mean to make light of it, because this is serious stuff. And yet. As I was writing this , my assessment changed. I now regard it in light of recent events, which changed my overall takeaway to one in which this book is disturbing. And still brilliant.The passage that follows might serve as an example of all of the above. The setup is that we have a young man trying to make ends meet through criminal (but nonviolent) activity. He is working the phone lines trying to bilk gullible Americans out of information that he can then "monetize", as in credit card numbers. When he is asked how he targets specific people (because, even if we are gullible, not many of us are that gullible), the exchange goes like this: [Vladimir is Sergei's father.]Vladimir: "Why do these foolish Americans believe you?"Sergei: "When I first started, they didn't....took a long time to understand the American mind-set. The fear of their cruel and capricious government weighs heavily on their psyches. They're more inclined to believe they'll lose what they have than receive what they want. Better to be the tax man than the sweepstakes, I decided. But it wasn't good enough. Too many skeptics, still. Then I remembered something you told me. Because your dad was an enemy of the people, you and your mom were on a special list. I figured that somewhere online, there must be a list of Americans who will believe anything, no matter how implausible or insulting to their intelligence."V: "Is there such a list?"S: "Tom Hanks' Facebook fan page."V: ?? (my translation)S: "You remember how Mom had that embroidered pillow? When she got upset, she'd shout into it and no one would hear her. That's Facebook. And Forrest Gump, you must have seen Forrest Gump?"V: "Is it a nature film?"S: : "No, no. Classic cinema. About how every achievement in American society over the last fifty years was really just the dumb luck of a mentally challenged man."V: "This was a Soviet propaganda film?"S: " No, it's a big Hollywood movie.... so I cross-reference the names and birthdays pulled from Tom Hanks' Facebook fans with White Pages. Why, you might ask, would they put their birthday right there on the Internet when it's one of the three pieces of information necessary to steal their identity? So that strangers will wish them a happy birthday! It's incredible, I know. When I called up Mrs. McGlinchy, I had her name, address, and birthday, told her I was from the IRS, and asked that she provide the necessary information to prove her identity. The trick is to make the American feel he must convince you of his identity, rather than the other way around. Tom Hanks' fans are maybe ten times more likely to fall for this than the average American."V: "Because there's something wrong with them?"S: "I wouldn't go that far. I'd just say that those who enjoy his acting are unfamiliar with human nature."So - there you have it. Given the events of the last few weeks, this is insightful. But very disturbing. And, nonetheless, hilarious. Darkly.I would also like to thank my book club - this is not a book that would ever have come to my attention in the normal course of events. I am so glad one of the members recommended it....more

title: Commonwealth
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ann Patchett is a wonderful writer. This particular book is built on a framework that is a bit disjointed (intentionally) in time, but ultimately, it Ann Patchett is a wonderful writer. This particular book is built on a framework that is a bit disjointed (intentionally) in time, but ultimately, it is about people and their ability to love, to hurt, to reconnect with others and self, and nobody does that any better than Ann Patchett. Two families are brought together in a harmful way (an affair between a two people who are married to other people), impacting not only the four adults in the mix, but the six children they have between them.The adults have problems which are not unusual - e.g. the mother who emotionally can't handle her own two children, let alone the other four brought to live with her for the summers, in the guise of visiting their father who promptly abandons her and the kids while he goes to work, and she in turn abandons all of the kids. Bad things happen.This book could have been titled "Collateral Damage", but that would have been trite. Patchett doesn't do trite. We spend time with all of the characters - some much more than others, but through them we go on their emotional journeys over a 40 or 50 year period and see how the repercussions ripple through individual lives.As always, Patchett's writing is so lovely that no matter the subject matter, I feel that whether or not I'm interested in the story, I am transported....more

review: Overall, I am left somewhat disappointed. There are some remarkable insights into the institution of slavery - such as there would be no America if itOverall, I am left somewhat disappointed. There are some remarkable insights into the institution of slavery - such as there would be no America if it weren't for the slaves that built it - a point that he makes very compellingly, but somehow, the emotion I needed to bring it home wasn't there. I need to have some relationship with the characters, but I never developed them for Cora, his main protagonist, or any of the others in her story.Her interiority was emotionally flat. If that was deliberate, and a demonstration that a person who is systemically denied personhood has no capacity to be otherwise, then he succeeded brilliantly. But that's probably a bit too esoteric for me to appreciate.Well done, just no connection for me. I don't think I will ever think of these characters again. And that's a shame....more

review: Weird and wonderful. You have to just jump in on this one. It was difficult and ugly to start and I had no idea WTF was going on. As it starts to eke Weird and wonderful. You have to just jump in on this one. It was difficult and ugly to start and I had no idea WTF was going on. As it starts to eke out clues, you are pulled along, sometimes inside out, sometimes horrified, a lot of times both, BUT NEVER BORED. A group of kids have been trained, each specializing in a discipline, such as languages, warfare, engineering, etc, but to what end? And is there a plan, or have these kids just shown up for a season of American Horror Story? I hate horror. I hate having kids be instruments of psychopaths, but I loved this book. I really don't understand. But it is one of the most creative novels I have ever read.I really need to read something quietly literary now, but if you are in the mood for a wild ride where you don't see what is coming, try this one on. Just don't give up early. The difficulty of the first parts are rewarded handsomely....more

review: In this, the fifth entry in the Expanse series, I have come to the conclusion that I want more and more of the series because I've fallen in love withIn this, the fifth entry in the Expanse series, I have come to the conclusion that I want more and more of the series because I've fallen in love with the characters. Good science fiction but - oh, the characters. Best crew since Firefly, and maybe better.Nemesis Games does have a plot, but really, the novel is making a pivot/course correction in the universe of the Expanse, and setting up the path to the final showdown with the real Bogey Monster. (The ones who killed off the monsters who created the protomolecule.) I'd guess the next book will be about the protomolecule creators. But I don't care. As long as I'm on the Rocinante, I'm good.Ever since the second book, Amos and Avarasala have been my favorite characters. Now, Alex has joined them. He is the true conscience of the crew - the understated glue for the rest of them. So, I've preordered Babylon's Ashes. Finally, a modest suggestion for Daniel Abraham and Ty Franck: put out a side book devoted to Avarasala's insults. Just pull them all together as a small book of gems such as:"..(She/Avarasala) threatened to massage my balls with a paint scraper.""Call me that again and I'll have an officer beat you gently with a cattle prod.""..as a community, Mars has got its collective asshole puckered up so tight it's bending light.""Realizing you've got shit on your fingers is the first step toward washing your hands.""...(he's) going to be monitoring anything we fucking say. If you wanted to discuss menstruation at great length and detail, this is probably our best chance. He's always been squeamish about women, and no one likes a Peeping Tom, even if he is Prime Minister."Please please please collect them. Over and out....more

title: The Fifth Season        (The Broken Earth, #1)
author: Jemisin, N.K.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Fascinating book. Fractured in time, characters, place and structure. And what characters and places! Probably set on our own Earth, after we have ruiFascinating book. Fractured in time, characters, place and structure. And what characters and places! Probably set on our own Earth, after we have ruined it, somehow. Fiercely drawn characters in terms of race/ethnic history/sexuality, much of which is foreign to a resident of Earth in 2016, but very much echoing mankind's own history and cultural splits and dysfunctions. There are three story lines, following Essun (woman in early 40's), Damaya (young girl), and Syenite (late teens). Over time you suspect they are one and the same, but that would probably qualify as a spoiler. An interesting approach the author takes is that Essun's story is told in sort of a toggling between first and second person (it is never clear who is telling the story or who the second person is until the end), whereas Damaya's and Syenite's stories are in third person, but switching on and off into first person reactions inside their heads). It was confusing at first, but a steady rhythm of narration took over. I don't know when it happened, just realized at some point that I didn't need to think about it anymore. The other major character (totally third person narrative), Alabaster, is my favorite. He is critical to the story in ways that aren't obvious at first, but he is truly the fulcrum of the story (that is a pun you will get if you read the book).A major development vis-a-vis "normal" humans is the appearance of "orogenes" - clearly a mutation of some kind which allows those who possess that gene to manipulate earth. Literally, as in stones, tectonic plates, etc. using a sort of telekinesis. Those who possess this ability are viewed with hate and suspicion by those who don't. And frankly, someone who can cause earthquakes when they get upset can be a bit dicey to be friends with. Especially if they have not been trained in controlling it yet...So, the novel is quite the puzzlebox. Very rewarding if you like this kind of thing, possibly totally frustrating if you need to be grounded in reality. Filled with its own mythology ("stonelore") and history curated by those who rule - which ain't the orogenes, in case you were wondering... but I loved it.This is not an easy book to read. Not just because of the fracturing, but because of the content. (However, if you can deal with the violence and heartbreak of Game of Thrones and Outlander, you will be OK.) But it is SOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO worth it. (I would note that I consumed this novel in what is becoming my favorite method of "reading". Listening to an audiobook version for a couple of hours, then re-reading it in print until I catch up to the audiobook. That way I can reinforce what I heard, spend more time with the details I may have missed, and skim over most of the print.)P.S. While I was frustrated to find out at the end of the book that it is Part 1 of a planned trilogy, the story arc is reasonably complete - or at least complete enough I can stand the wait for the next two._________________________________June 2019Just finished a re-read. Even better the second time around, because I "knew" more about the stuff that confused me on the initial read. Picked it up again because it is NPR/NYT Book Club selection for this month. Also, so I can go on to the next two which are now done.......more

title: The Boys in the Boat: Nine Americans and Their Epic Quest for Gold at the 1936 Berlin Olympics
author: Brown, Daniel James*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: At least four stars, and another star just for the narrator, Edward Herrmann. An inspirational story of nine young men who beat unimaginable odds to wAt least four stars, and another star just for the narrator, Edward Herrmann. An inspirational story of nine young men who beat unimaginable odds to win gold in the 1936 Olympics. Hardscrabble, mostly dirt poor, these young men took on a sport that melded them into a single unit as they showed the world what they could do. While you find out about all nine to some degree, this telling focuses on Joe Rantz, not because he was any better than the others, but because the author found him and the story in his own backyard.But while Joe's story may or may not be that different from the others' stories with respect to what they had to contend with, it surely is not less. Literally abandoned by his family at the age of 10, in a half finished cabin in the woods, where he learned to forage for mushrooms and poach fish, to his summer job building the Coulee Dam (hanging over the side of the cliff upside down in a harness while busting up granite with a jackhammer - OSHA was nowhere in sight in 1936), and always, always, always never enough to eat. And even more amazing, he continued in school and excelled there.And then the Olympics, with Hitler and Berlin in 1936....Anyway, reads like a novel with a wonderfully satisfying ending. Another Greatest Generation story that needed to be told....more

If I have a real complaint about the book(s), it is the naming of the characters and places. Very unwieldy. Something leftover from the old Eastern European (esp. Russian) monarchies, which matches the class structures she employs in the novel, but it gets difficult when a dozen or so of the main characters have names starting with "Vor"... title: The Beautiful Struggle: A Father, Two Sons and an Unlikely Road to Manhood
author: Coates, Ta-Nehisi
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Not exactly a companion piece or a precursor to Between the World and Me, but maybe a bit of both. An uncompromising father and two of his sons: one dNot exactly a companion piece or a precursor to Between the World and Me, but maybe a bit of both. An uncompromising father and two of his sons: one drawn to the streets and violence of West Baltimore, another more interested in Dungeons and Dragons but needing to know how to survive the streets. A father who was determined to know everything he could about the black diaspora in America, African roots, and dedicated to making that alternative to the usual rendering of American history available through his own basement publishing efforts. He was a Black Panther and an autodidact. He was also determined to keep his sons from succumbing to the violence and the crack epidemic that was the plague of West Baltimore of the late 80's and 90's. That he did some of that through considerable violence to his own children was not ironic, but not without cost, either.This book is somewhat rambling and anecdotal, but not unfocused. It remarkably powerful prose, delivered in such complicated, situational, and from a specific point of view and community that I do not share, that I needed a lot of extra time for looking up things that I simply had no context for. A dictionary probably would have helped some, but Google was a much better friend for this trip.Anyway, not easy, occasionally hilarious, often horrifying, but always honest. Coates as a writer is so well read and has integrated so much knowledge from such different universes that he is a wonder to experience.My only complaint, such as it is, is that I would have liked to know much, much more about his mother, who clearly was/is? extraordinary in her own accomplishments....more

title: The Bone Labyrinth        (Sigma Force, #11)
author: Rollins, James*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I had such high hopes for this one.. As always, Rollins starts with an interesting scientific premise and then turns it on its head to produce an amazI had such high hopes for this one.. As always, Rollins starts with an interesting scientific premise and then turns it on its head to produce an amazing, page-turning thriller. However, I was really excited about this one because I coincidentally was also reading a nonfiction book ("Sapiens", Harari) about the same scientific puzzle regarding a period of accelerated growth in human intelligence. That is, by complete chance, I was reading a novel and a nonfiction book about the same phenomenon. As it turns out, about 100,000 years ago there were several hominin species living around the world at the same time - sapiens, erectus, Denisovan, neanderthal, australopitheus, floresiensis, maybe more, but you get the picture. Then something happened. Somewhere between 70,000 years ago and 30,000 years ago, most of those species disappeared, and homo sapiens began to thrive dramatically, both in numbers and in geographic coverage. The questions both authors explore are (a) why, and (b) is this necessarily a good thing for the ultimate survival of the sapiens species. Based on the evidence from that period, homo sapiens did not appear to have any particular advantage over the other hominins. But all of a sudden, sapiens began to differentiate itself in several ways such as art (think cave paintings in France) and the ability for abstraction, such as burial rites which indicate the contemplation of things that are not concrete, such as an afterlife.At this point, the books take different paths. This book is a thriller and examines the acceleration of human intelligence via Rollins' good ole Sigma Force v. evil-doers. Which, for the record, I am getting tired of. You read Rollins for the adventure, not the character development. He has created this Sigma Force group which is an efficient way to not have to spend time on who they are. You get to know them by what various expertise they have in the context of the team.There are two parallel investigations - one scientific, the other historical. The science track is what Rollins (and Crichton before him) does best. The historical goes around the bend in this one, consisting of many features more likely to be found in the DaVinci Code - consipiracies, numerology, and mathematical coincidences that are unrelated (in my mind, anyway) which purport to provide support for some fantastical theories. He even drags poor old Neil Armstrong into it at one point, for chrissake.....So. Interesting scientific jump-off point, great thriller pacing and utter nonsense for historical component. I like Rollins, but this seems to be formulaic, and not in a good way.I am, however, enjoying Sapiens, and look forward to continuing it now....more

title: Iron Lake        (Cork O'Connor, #1)
author: Krueger, William Kent*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: About a year and a half ago, I read a wonderful novel titled "Ordinary Grace" by this author. It is a special book, and it made a real impression. I wAbout a year and a half ago, I read a wonderful novel titled "Ordinary Grace" by this author. It is a special book, and it made a real impression. I was vaguely aware that Krueger had written a series of books with a protagonist named Cork O'Connor, and made a mental note to try one out. That is this book.As a first novel in a series, it is remarkably good. I do like murder mysteries, and this is a pretty good mystery, albeit overly complicated. Cork O'Connor is a deeply flawed man, an ex-sheriff who still acts as if he is still the sheriff. And dogged in the way Harry Bosch is dogged, as in obsessive. In fact, this book reminds me somewhat of Harry's adventures, but Krueger's prose (in this book) is not as cleanly elegant the way Michael Connelly's is. Still, the fact that I would even compare them at this point is remarkable in and of itself.I also like the way Krueger weaves in the native american (Anishinaabe/Ojibwe) history/culture throughout the book. (O'Connor is one-fourth Anishinaabe.) The first murder mysteries I read were the Joe Leaphorn/Jim Chee books by Tony Hillerman, which got me hooked on the genre. And similar to those (and Craig Johnson's Longmire series), this book is a valentine to both the cultures and the setting (northern Minnesota) that go a long way with me. Another similarity is the notion that justice and the law are two very, very different things, especially for these communities.However, one similarity to the Longmire books that I find difficult is the horrific beatings, shootings, etc that the protagonist (and others) suffer. Most normal human beings would be damaged for life, probably in a wheelchair, and requiring a LOT of personal nursing care. I find this problematic, but I guess it isn't any more unrealistic than some of the plot elements, just far more unpleasant.And where O'Connor comes up short, especially compared to Longmire and others, is that he has absolutely no sense of humor. At any rate, a great first novel, but with enough flaws to keep me from giving it 4 or 5 stars. I expect that will change with his subsequent novels, because by the time he wrote "Ordinary Grace" his writing was wonderful....more

title: Ammonite
author: Griffith, Nicola*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A semi-fabulous book. Loved the beginning, the middle, but the ending faded a bit for me. Still a great book. And if I had read it when it first came A semi-fabulous book. Loved the beginning, the middle, but the ending faded a bit for me. Still a great book. And if I had read it when it first came out in 1992 or so, I'm sure it would have been 5 stars then. It felt very much like the first time I read something by Ursula le Guin. Wonderful world building - mythology, anthropology, ancestral memories, incorporation of a planet's interplay with the individuals who inhabit it.The protagonist is part of an expeditionary group that lands on a planet which has a "lost" colony of humans that have been there for a few hundred years. Lots of natural resources (of great interest to the "Company"), but one big drawback. A virus that kills all men, and about 25% of all women. But somehow, the lost colony has managed to survive and the surviving women have been able to reproduce. The protagonist's job is primarily to test a vaccine against the virus. However, she is also an anthropologist and is driven to understand the culture and to try to understand the "how" of their survival. Adventures ensue.A real page turner for a good two thirds of the book, interesting even when it slows down. The conclusion was a bit soft, but still compelling. As I said, it would have been much more compelling if I had read it 20 years ago....more

title: The Last Policeman        (The Last Policeman, #1)
author: Winters, Ben H.*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I feel like I should have really, really liked this book instead of just really liked it. But I did really like it.The novel is a mashup of two of my I feel like I should have really, really liked this book instead of just really liked it. But I did really like it.The novel is a mashup of two of my favorite genres: science fiction (end of the world coming, compliments of asteroid "Maia" on a collision course with Earth) and murder mystery (did the hapless insurance actuary commit suicide or was he murdered?). The policeman of the title is Detective Hank Palace, who is endearing and irritatingly earnest in equal measure...you know, the kind of guy who (sincerely, not being a smartass) calls you "Miss" even when you are clearly of an age to be collecting Social Security.The mystery is tricky for several reasons. First, the notion of motive is seriously skewed when the earth is supposed to end in six months. Answering the question of why do people do what they do is tough in "normal" circumstances, but in this case, suicides are pretty frequent and even expected. Second, the work ethic is not quite what it used to be for much of the population (including the police force) for the same reason - many people find bucket lists and drugs much more interesting than working - especially the nitty gritty of police work. And one of the best reasons that this one is tricky is that the author steps you through all of the investigation, including many, many wrong alleys/red herrings/choose your own trite phrase. As frustrating as this is, I think it is much truer to actual police work (not that I know anything about actual police work), and ultimately more rewarding than following the bread crumbs that are the usual puzzle of murder mysteries.All that said, it seemed to drag at times, which is why I can't give it five stars. But it deserves at least the four stars for its clever premise.(Another note: this is the first of a trilogy - if I read the other two, perhaps I will change my mind. There is a lot of cleverness in this book, but maybe not enough for me to read the other two.)...more

title: The Gunslinger        (The Dark Tower, #1)
author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Disappointed is way too gentle a word. I was so looking forward to this because so many people whose opinion I respect really love this work (in all oDisappointed is way too gentle a word. I was so looking forward to this because so many people whose opinion I respect really love this work (in all of its many pieces). For me, I have always been conflicted about King's work. His prose can soar. He can evoke place and nostalgia with the best. But his tendency to wander into the dark places for no reason and at great length have always put me off. And that is all this book is. At some point, it stops being horror and just becomes horrible.This probably has as much to say about me and my need for clarity and motivation with which I can identify. review: I really enjoyed this book, but it was a bit too pulpy for me to give it 5 stars. Who doesn't enjoy werewolves tearing the shit out of Nazis? As politI really enjoyed this book, but it was a bit too pulpy for me to give it 5 stars. Who doesn't enjoy werewolves tearing the shit out of Nazis? As politically correct as this world has become, you can still hate on Nazis guilt-free... The more interesting question for me focused on the author. This same author wrote one of my favorite books (Boy's Life), in which I compared him to Ray Bradbury. That is as high as my praise can go. No pulp in that book. So. How does this happen? I don't have any answer except to speculate that this guy has full command of his writing - and chooses to deploy pulp when it suits him.I read a lot of books by James Rollins, which are good for satisfying that action/adventure itch I need scratched once in a while. If you like Jim Rollins, this is similar in pacing. It lacks Rollins' scientific underpinnings (a la Michael Crichton), but has similar bright lines between the good guys and the bad guys, and the same lack of character depth. Enjoyable rides, but rides that won't stick for very long....more

title: The Curse of Chalion        (World of the Five Gods, #1)
author: Bujold, Lois McMaster*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The s of books I fall in love with are much harder to write up than the "pretty good" ones. But here goes.I feel like Stefon from SNL. "This booThe s of books I fall in love with are much harder to write up than the "pretty good" ones. But here goes.I feel like Stefon from SNL. "This book has everything.... middle ages swordplay, slaves on oar ships, fair maidens who are tough broads disguised as springtime and flowers (and their mothers and grandmothers are even more so) , dueling religions, evil conspiracies, royal court treacheries".... all delivered in some of the most brilliant writing I've ever read, with a protagonist that has resulted in my greatest crush on a fictional character since, well, forever.There is more wit and substance per page in this novel than I can adequately describe.But probably the thing that surprised me the most was the thoughtful dissection of religion. If anyone had told me that religious belief was at the core of this book (or any book), that would normally be enough for me to never read it. What a treatise on free will vs. fate it turned out to be. And without telling you what the answers are. Or should be. That the most important god (and certainly the most interesting) is the Bastard, who is responsible for balance in the world of Chalion, is more than just clever and double-sided. It is meaty food for thought.Lest anyone be put off by this sounding like a treatise for IMPORTANT THOUGHT, please don't be. It is there, but it is a rollicking good ride, sort of Lord of the Rings style, with a lot more humor - self-deprecating and otherwise. This is a writer who is in full command of her craft.I'm just going to savor this one for a few days. Don't really think I can read another book until the glow fades. It would really be unfair to the next book.P.S. I listened to the audiobook (fabulous narrator) and followed it up with print book every few chapters, which turned out to be a really good way to go. I missed some things, and also appreciated the secondary digestion that helps dense (in a good way) prose....more
