title: Matterhorn
author: Marlantes, Karl
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Heart-breaking. Stunning. An amazing "you-are-there" novel which brings home the horror - and camaraderie - and sheer adrenalin - of combat. Clearly tHeart-breaking. Stunning. An amazing "you-are-there" novel which brings home the horror - and camaraderie - and sheer adrenalin - of combat. Clearly the author-was-there and this book, among other things, is his declaration of the bonds and the love and respect he had for the men he served with. (And maybe the not so much respect for the higher ups calling the shots.) Vietnam was probably the United States' last war where service in the armed forces was considered an obligation to be shared by all segments of society. There was a draft and everyone was subject to it. While deferments were plentiful and the poor have always been overrepresented and the rich underrepresented, service was still pretty universal. And while that plays a part in this story, the story is really about the horrors of combat and the toll it takes.A secondary, but no less powerful, theme was how race relationships were a deadly addition to the mix. This was the 1960's, and civil rights in this country were marching up the road at the same time as Vietnam played out. It is painful to read about how raw all of that was; but interesting to note that all of that friction disappeared in combat - it was in the down time that the problems really boiled up.Interestingly, I think the two best books I've read this year are about war - this one and "All the Light We Cannot See". But this one is really about combat, and All the Light is more about societal collateral damage as well as the sheer destruction of war....more

review: Reading these books is always such effortless pleasure. It reminds me of the satisfaction I used to get solving geometry proofs. For those of you who Reading these books is always such effortless pleasure. It reminds me of the satisfaction I used to get solving geometry proofs. For those of you who do not have such happy memories of geometry proofs, think of it as a very satisfying trip where you move one step at a time, turning things over and having the "aha" moment that leads you to the next "aha" moment. By now, Harry Bosch is an old friend, and while this particular entry in the series is not strong with respect to delving into Harry's personal issues, that's OK too. I like those aspects, but don't need them every time out.This one involves a cold case that turns into an active murder investigation when a bullet lodged in a victim's spine 10 years ago finally leads to his death. And while each step moves toward a conclusion, it is nothing like the conclusion you might think it will lead to when you start on the journey.(Additional thought: I get the same sense of satisfaction from reading a Michael Connelly book as I do when I hear the "snick" of a perfectly fitted drawer closing, or the snug soft chunky sound of my car door closing on my well-designed Camry, when I know there will be no window whistling noises, or odd rattling sounds from somewhere in the trunk. It is called craftsmanship, and I appreciate it in whatever form it presents itself.)...more

title: Time and Again        (Time, #1)
author: Finney, Jack
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Well, this is one of those averaging an "A" and an "F" to get a "C". I almost gave up on this book several times. The first half (two-thirds?) draggggWell, this is one of those averaging an "A" and an "F" to get a "C". I almost gave up on this book several times. The first half (two-thirds?) dragggggggggggggggeeeeeeeddddddddddddd. I kept picking it up, reading a couple of pages, and then found other more interesting things to do, like the laundry. I know (and knew while I was reading it) that the author was working hard to establish texture for the translation in traveling into 1882 from 1970, so that the reader would really feel/smell/see the differences. But it was sooooo boring. Under normal circumstances, I would have quit, but several people whose opinion I value thought it was a wonderful book, so I kept telling myself to keep slogging on, since there must be a payoff. I also had problems reading something written from a 1970 mindset - for instance, in the introductory pages where you meet Simon Morely (protagonist) at work, all the men have first and last names and titles and all the "girls" only have first names. And the men like to wander through accounting [or wherever], because that's where the "cute" girls work. Now, this IS how it was. I was there, all right? But it was just so startling. And awful. (Full confession: some of the 1960s and 1970s is so painful to recall, that I also can't watch Mad Men, no matter how good it is.) But. I digress. And the good news is, there is indeed a payoff.The last half/third all of a sudden slammed into gear, and was wonderful. And very, very clever. Several twists I didn't see coming, painful choices made with a recognition that living with those decisions wasn't going to be easy, and the plot moved like a runaway freight train headed for disaster into the terminal. So.The moral to the story is - if you are going to have a bad half and a good half, always go with the good half last (kind of like this )....Just thought of a way to make my point: the first half/two-thirds of the book took me two weeks; the last half/third took one day. I'm just saying......more

review: If you like snark, this book gives full measure. But, pleasingly, it is more than just snark. I had avoided this book since it came out, largely becauIf you like snark, this book gives full measure. But, pleasingly, it is more than just snark. I had avoided this book since it came out, largely because of the cover. It just looked like a beach read to me.The construct of the book is both non-linear and epistolary, yet it is never (really) confusing. But as the book moves from "just" laugh out loud episodes, it becomes a real exploration of how what you see depends on where you sit. Bernadette starts off as a bat-shit, defiantly NOT-hipster mother who over time gains your sympathy. She is very disturbed, but it turns out, she has reason to be. At any rate, you can read the book just for Bernadette's rants. They are worth the price of admission by themselves. But the nice thing is, the book turns out to have much more depth than that.(Note: I originally gave this 4 stars, but after thinking about it over time, I think it is actually 5 stars. review: This is a book that, before I read it, I assumed would have a predictable plot. Maybe, to some extent, it does, but it is much more than a plot.The moThis is a book that, before I read it, I assumed would have a predictable plot. Maybe, to some extent, it does, but it is much more than a plot.The most interesting aspect for me was that it evoked a sense of my own childhood, thrilled and reading my way through Nancy Drew's adventures in the 1950's and 1960's. However, this book is well written, and whoever Carolyn Keene was, she was not a very good writer. What evokes the memory is that sense of alien-ness of another era. Nancy Drew, in her sporty blue roadster, was definitely a creature of another time - the 1930's and 1940's; daughter of Carson Drew, prominent lawyer (I hope these references are accurate, just operating off of memory), and a crime-solving wonder.Maisie Dobbs is definitely a young woman of a long gone era also. In this case, World War I in England and France, and the years before and immediately following. In contrast to the well-born Nancy, she is a young woman who has risen above her class due to a brilliant mind and some devoted mentors.It was a decent mystery, but for me, the biggest enjoyment was that the time and place were characters equal to Maisie....more

title: A Canticle for Leibowitz        (St. Leibowitz, #1)

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read this book as a teenager, and it always stuck with me. It is just as powerful the second time around 50 years later. Miller's view of humanity iI read this book as a teenager, and it always stuck with me. It is just as powerful the second time around 50 years later. Miller's view of humanity is not a particularly sanguine one. In short, mankind is fatally flawed and doomed to destroy itself.Lest this sound all doom and gloom, it isn't. There is a lot of humor (very pointed humor), and if Miller doesn't like humanity, he does have a lot of affection for his monks of the order of St. Leibowitz. Doltish, stubborn, yet compelling for their unquestioning faith, many of them have a goodness that makes them a pleasure to spend time with.I have re-read several books that made an impression on me many years ago. This one holds up better than almost all of them and was well worth the re-read....more

title: Under the Wide and Starry Sky
author: Horan, Nancy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A book club book that I didn't finish. A recap of the courtship and marriage of Fanny Osbourne and Robert Louis Stevenson. They were both interesting A book club book that I didn't finish. A recap of the courtship and marriage of Fanny Osbourne and Robert Louis Stevenson. They were both interesting people - but her greatest contribution seems to have been keeping him alive long enough for him to write some of his masterpieces, such as "Jekyll and Hyde" and "Treasure Island". (That is one of the points of contention for those who read this book - did she suppress her own contributions in order to make sure he could make his? Or was she just a force of nature applied to a very high purpose?) Nonetheless, she did/was and he did write many and varied novels, poems, and essays.Overall, it amazes me that the same adventure story/thriller author wrote what he did as well as "A Child's Garden of Verses", and much more.But, setting all of that aside, and for whatever reason, the stongest emotional resonance for me is in the piece used in the title of the book:'Under the wide and starry sky,Dig the grave and let me lie.Glad did I live and gladly die,And I laid me down with a will.This be the verse you grave for me:Here he lies where he longed to be;Home is the sailor, home from sea,And the hunter home from the hill.'(Requiem, Robert Louis Stevenson)I have always been moved by that poem/requiem and never known why. I still don't really know why, but it is very satisfying to think that this man wrote it as his own epitaph....more

title: Doomsday Book        (Oxford Time Travel, #1)
author: Willis, Connie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A really good 200 page book that goes on for a lot longer. Seemed like 1000 pages, but was probably 500. And I often like 1000 page books. A very frusA really good 200 page book that goes on for a lot longer. Seemed like 1000 pages, but was probably 500. And I often like 1000 page books. A very frustrating read. Good story about a time traveler sent back to 14th century who misses the target date by some 28 years and ends up in the middle of the Black Plague.And (almost) everyone dies. I just got worn out by repeated descriptions of suppurating buboes and festering, oozing sores. After the first half dozen or so, I GET IT. I don't need to do it over and over and over and over. I was very disappointed, because I had such high expectations. This should have been a five star, and in some ways, it was. But I just felt like I was pushing, pushing, pushing myself to finish. And that is not how I like to feel when I read. So averaging a five star and a one star - voila! Three stars....more

title: A Prayer for Owen Meany
author: Irving, John*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Meandering, repetitive, and stunning. Irving has the same ability as Richard Russo to depict events that are tragic in nature, but the descriptions arMeandering, repetitive, and stunning. Irving has the same ability as Richard Russo to depict events that are tragic in nature, but the descriptions are so observant and particular that he can render them comical while making your heart ache.This is a book about faith, and the redemptive nature of faith. Faith with or without capital letters. And something I don't dwell on if left to my own devices.There is no way to summarize this novel meaningfully, but if you want to read about two boyhood friends who are destined to share a particular and remarkable fate - a fate that one of them believes in ABSOLUTELY, and the other does not see coming at all - I can't think of a better way to do it.Brilliant and absorbing. And meandering, repetitive, and stunning. This is right up there with The World According to Garp....more

I've read most of the Longmire novels, love the TV series (and was thrilled to find out that Netflix has optioned a season four).These are three (or maybe four) dimensional characters, including the state of Wyoming as a character.Walt Longmire is to Absaroka County, Wyoming what Jim Chee and Joe Leaphorn were for the Four Corners area. review: One of the best uses of a graphic novel format that I've seen. I suppose it helps that Roz Chast is a professional cartoonist (there may be a more digOne of the best uses of a graphic novel format that I've seen. I suppose it helps that Roz Chast is a professional cartoonist (there may be a more dignified term, just not as apt).She covers the same terrain that I have explored recently because of my own particular situations with caregiving and aging, but in a wonderful way. The format lends itself to discussing VERY UNPLEASANT topics - dementia, frailty, and god help us, money - in a way that is instantly identifiable (is that even a word??).Very tough terrain, no excusing herself, but also forgiving herself, I think. Perhaps I'm projecting here....At any rate, can be read in an afternoon, and if you are struggling with these issues, very helpful....more

title: A Town Like Alice
author: Shute, Nevil
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A wonderful read. The casual racism of the 1940's and 1950's in Malaya and Australia is quite jarring, but I'm sure it is an accurate reflection of thA wonderful read. The casual racism of the 1940's and 1950's in Malaya and Australia is quite jarring, but I'm sure it is an accurate reflection of the times.I watched the miniseries adaption by PBS/BBC in the 1980's, and was absolutely enthralled. I had always meant to read the book, and now, only 30 years later, I have.There are two distinct, but related, parts to this book: first, a truly harrowing tale of a group of British women who were captured by the Japanese in Malaya in 1942, and second, the reunion of two of the protagonists from the wartime event and their efforts to build a town in the Australian outback.Shute is a master of narrative detail: you sweat, starve, and are eaten alive by mosquitoes along with the women (and children), who suffer the ultimate humiliation of not even being wanted as prisoners by the Japanese, but not allowed to leave, either. Shute draws a surprisingly sympathetic picture of their "guards", the equivalent of enlisted men, while clearly condemning their superior officers.The lovingly detailed descriptions of the Australian outback are similarly well drawn out. Where Shute gets into a bit of trouble is over-killing on the details of things like lists of items needed to construct a workroom for manufacturing items made from alligator skin, or long, drawn-out exchanges of a dozen or so folks providing necessary communication by radio... it was sort of like reading the transcripts of a police scanner's exchanges without any edits. Kind of reminded me of the irritation I had at times with Stieg Larsson's "Girl With the Dragon Tattoo" and the itemizations of what the characters had for breakfast, and the brands of their clothing and kitchen appliances. So, some editing wouldn't have hurt.But those are quibbles. Still a great story....more

review: Remarkable book. Both profoundly funny and tragic at the same time. Reaches deeply into the notion of what it means to be human, and whether that entiRemarkable book. Both profoundly funny and tragic at the same time. Reaches deeply into the notion of what it means to be human, and whether that entitles us to do unspeakable things to other beings who aren't human.It is a very painful topic and it is explored seriously and deeply, but the writing for at least the first half of the book is so hilarious, that you don't want to have liquids in your mouth.Reading it results in more questions being asked than answered, and I'm not sure we are better for it. But it should be read. And someday (sooner rather than later) those questions deserve to be answered....more

review: Interesting, but not compelling. Nice construct of alternative chapters narrated by slave and slave owner. I was truly swept up by the Secret Life of Interesting, but not compelling. Nice construct of alternative chapters narrated by slave and slave owner. I was truly swept up by the Secret Life of Bees, but not so much this one. I think part of the problem might be that this book tries to have it both ways, as an historical novel but about a real person as more of a biography. I suppose it had to be classified as historical fiction because she altered several documented facts (largely timeline collapsing and extending to suit the novel's narrative, and, oh yeah, the fact that the slave owner/budding abolitionist is a real person but the slave she is given for a birthday present is totally fabricated).So, it was OK, and if you are interested in this time period in US history vis-a-vis the abolitionist and women's rights history, it is informative. review: A very well written coming-of-age-in-small-town-America-in-the-60's story that also has a decent mystery gluing it together. Very reminiscent of The BA very well written coming-of-age-in-small-town-America-in-the-60's story that also has a decent mystery gluing it together. Very reminiscent of The Body (Stephen King) and the movie made from it, Stand By Me. The time, mood and place were very effectively drawn.While I (sadly) followed the defining events that will forever change this thirteen year old boy from your standard callow youth to someone who experiences the beginnings of hard won wisdom about life, family, and self understanding, I very much wanted to take him in my arms and let him cry. Or vent. Heart-breaking and beautiful, with an exploration of faith that is quite touching. And I'm not one for exploring faith, but if all ministers/priests/rabbis/imams/whatever were anything like this boy's father, the world would be a much better place. As the book unfolds, I went from impatience with his character to a true appreciation of what strength he embodied. ...more

review: A truly grim recounting of a woman's experience as she was held captive in Somalia by radical Islamists (although not the MOST radical, evidently) forA truly grim recounting of a woman's experience as she was held captive in Somalia by radical Islamists (although not the MOST radical, evidently) for 15 months. While she was incredibly foolhardy, she is clearly made of pretty stern stuff just to have survived. Evidently, the motivation behind her capture (as well as that of her friend, Nigel) was a fairly straightforward kidnapping for ransom scheme that got terribly prolonged due to the respective families' inability to pay.I would never have read this if it weren't selected by my book club. I am not sorry I read it, but the grimness will be tough to shake off. I'm not sure I learned anything, either, except to reinforce my belief that I'm happy being an armchair traveler.It is very well written, and surprisingly full of forgiveness - for herself, her captors, and her family.I hope the author finds peace and a fulfilling life....more

OK, yeah, I'm too lazy to do the work, but when someone writes about it in great detail, I'm thrilled to be along for the ride.)Lots of boat-y stuff. Overarching plot line is a condemnation of England and the East India Trading Company (in the book the Pendleton Trading Company) and their role in China and the opium trade.This is also set in that wonderful period, early 19th century, with all that British fustiness, mashed with Treasure Island type adventure. McMurtry miI do love McMurtry's writing, especially his dialogue. I really enjoyed this book, although it is not the comedy that it starts out to be. McMurtry mixes comedy and tragedy while taking you on one of his literary explorations. This particular journey is about 62 year old Duane Moore's attempt to find meaning in his life. Speaking as one who has suffered from depression, Duane's behavior rings true. As with the other books I have read by this author, you just get on and go for a ride with him. And you will be entertained, and you will have your heart broken. But no matter how many losses stack up over the telling of the tale, somehow you remain hopeful and a sense of redemption is always around the corner....more

If this is meant to be a stand-alone book, it has a really weird ending. If it is yet another series, IT SHOULD SAY SO. I was willing to give it the benefit of the doubt for the interesting ideas (although not well executed) and the beginning of the book when you are with the protagonist, Juneau, trying to figure out what is happening. The alternative POV provided by Miles, the city boy and - gag me with a spoon - romantic interest, was not interesting unless you like spending time with spoiled rich boys with behavior issues.All that said, I would have at least given this two stars, if it weren't for the open-endedness (and not a good open-endedness) of the ending.If you are twelve years old and all these ideas are new to you, and you don't mind the new ideas or underlying plot never being explained, I could see liking this book. review: I picked this up because I had loved his previous novel, The Dog Stars so much. This one doesn't disappoint. A lot of what made the Dog Stars such a cI picked this up because I had loved his previous novel, The Dog Stars so much. This one doesn't disappoint. A lot of what made the Dog Stars such a compelling read is here - wonderful prose, a strong sense of grief mixed with moments of joy, and, oh yeah, violence.Heller's ability to describe activities is so strong, that when the protagonist is fly fishing, you are fly fishing. And I've never gone fly fishing nor had any interest in doing so, but while reading Heller's descriptions, I love fly fishing. And painting. And hunting and being hunted - of course, those are accompanied by horror and fear, but what this guy can do is make you FEEL.I've never studied art (you know, I'm one of those 'who knows what I like' types), but I now have an appreciation for what the craft entails. Or at least what the author says it entails. But again, I come to an appreciation of a craft for which I have no aptitude nor interest in by reading his words.Hope he keeps doing this, but I hope his publishers don't push too hard in the name of greed....more

title: A Single Man
author: Isherwood, Christopher
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is why I like book clubs. If I had chosen to read this by myself (I wouldn't have), I probably would have been less than impressed. Probably onlyThis is why I like book clubs. If I had chosen to read this by myself (I wouldn't have), I probably would have been less than impressed. Probably only rated it 2 stars.But the beauty of talking to others about a book you have all read is that you find out how little you got out of it compared to others. Or, sometimes, how much more you got out of it than others did. In this case, being forced to think about what I had read prior to the discussion made me appreciate it more than I had; actually discussing it in a group made me really appreciate it.I had already liked the clean, dispassionate (well, to be fair, occasionally passionate) prose. And the cynical, observational style. And how a book written in the 1960's by and about a gay man held up so well. This was/is a gay man comfortable in his own skin, which I don't think was very common then. Not that his world view, as well as his assumptions about what others thought of him, wasn't heavily influenced by being gay, but that he didn't have any doubts about himself being gay - that's what he was, and he had no interest in anything else.But in the discussion I came to appreciate Isherwood's strong sense of place (geographical, macro and micro) and style, his appreciation of the beauty in the human form, and his ability to think in ways that all of us can identify with. (Yes, I'm ending a sentence with a preposition and I'm leaving it....)Anyway, maybe some of you can appreciate all that without help. I'm just not that reflective on my own. I'm just saying....more

title: The Good Lord Bird
author: McBride, James*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I finished (listening) to this over a month ago, but couldn't figure out how to write it up. Still can't really, but decided to purchase the book and I finished (listening) to this over a month ago, but couldn't figure out how to write it up. Still can't really, but decided to purchase the book and re-read to get a better (or at least more articulate) grip on how to convey how much this book moved me.The short version of this book is that it is a fictionalized account of John Brown and the buildup to his raid on Harper's Ferry, as told through the eyes of a young slave.I almost quit after the first twenty-five pages or so - the slave dialect was pure Amos and Andy, and it really is shocking at this point in my life. And impossible to take. But the narrator, Michael Boatman - who I now believe to be incredibly gifted - switched gears effortlessly to John Brown and as the narrator begins to change while in the company of Brown, loses the shuffling massa speak and becomes a whole person - childish and selfish [he is very young]. His voicing of John Brown is remarkable.As I said at the beginning, I cannot meaningfully capture my reactions to this book. But it definitely deserved the National Book Award, and whatever other honors have been bestowed on it.I have the highest recommendation for The Good Lord Bird. Not an easy read, but a wonderful coverage of a period of our national history that deserves a wide audience....more

title: The Sense of an Ending
author: Barnes, Julian
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm of two minds on this book. On one hand, the writing is superb. Almost unimaginably precise, yet fluid at the same time. Beautiful conceptualizatioI'm of two minds on this book. On one hand, the writing is superb. Almost unimaginably precise, yet fluid at the same time. Beautiful conceptualizations of fairly sophisticated ideas about self and memory and aging. How reliable are we as witnesses to our own history? And does that change with age? There are many discussions of a philosophical nature that are attributed to the protagonist's recollections of his secondary education in England during the 1960's. Those discussions are elegant and fascinating.Where the book bogged down for me was in the plot narrative. Plot may be too strong a word. But many painful events are recalled from the trials of adolescence and early adulthood as the protagonist is looking back forty years and becomes involved in a mystery of sorts. Someone leaves him money in a will that comes as a complete surprise - having last seem the woman who left him the bequest over forty years before. In trying to unravel why the mother of an old girlfriend left him money, he wanders down memory lane and discovers to his chagrin that his memory is a bit faulty and pretty self-serving. That's as it may be, but the real problem for me is that there is considerable ambiguity with respect to the motivations of people from that distant past who figure into his search for an explanation. Nasty people did nasty things to each other and one of his old friends even committed suicide, but I never could decide why. There are possible explanations that wend around the class system in England, sexual repression in the 1960's, and the bitterness of betrayal in virtually every case. The mystery itself is fairly tidily resolved, but the "why" as to what people did what they did is left to the reader's interpretation. Not my favorite situation. I can tolerate some ambiguity, but the gap here was a bit unsatisfying.So - raves for the writing - easy to see why it won the Man Booker - but points off for not satisfying my need for resolution. If you have no such need to have things tidied up, this is a great book! Actually, it is a great book in any case....more

review: I thought I would never finish this book. I felt like I was trapped in the puzzle book nonsense that constitutes the "plot" of the Anubis Gates. It shI thought I would never finish this book. I felt like I was trapped in the puzzle book nonsense that constitutes the "plot" of the Anubis Gates. It should have worked. Time travel, visiting with Lords Byron and Samuel Taylor Coleridge in early 19th century London.... what's not to like? But now I know where Coleridge's opium fueled discourses must have come from... and I think Lovecraft snuck in there somewhere too - or at least his visions of evil seemed to be crawling and snuffling around.There were some protagonists, but they were mostly ineffectual, and they succeeded in thwarting evil almost by accident - except for Jacky, who, as it turns out (gasp) is a girl.It was really hard to keep track of the action and the characters - not just because there were so many, but because they kept switching bodies.Sigh. I had seriously hoped for more. No more "classics" for me unless someone I really trust recommends one....more

review: I love the Longmire TV series, and decided to explore the books behind them. Most of the earlier books have been incorporated into episodes in the TV I love the Longmire TV series, and decided to explore the books behind them. Most of the earlier books have been incorporated into episodes in the TV shows, but this one hasn't (yet?). Actually, the plots/mysteries are pretty good in and of themselves, but the reason you spend time with Walt Longmire and his friends are that they are such interesting, honorable, and terribly flawed characters. These stories are very steeped in place - Walt is the sheriff of Absaroka County, a fictional county in a very real Wyoming - to the extent that the place is as much a character as any of the people are.Listening to this was such an enjoyable experience, I think I'm going to read/or listen to all the books Johnson has written to date. The reader was good also, but seemed a touch old to be Walt.If you like complex, intelligent characters and interesting mysteries that explore the new West (Wyoming, in particular), you should enjoy this. Or, at least check out Longmire on TV! Walt Longmire is a person worth knowing.PS If you like the TV series Justified, or conversational prose that is somewhere in the same spare, clever vicinity as Elmore Leonard or Robert B. Parker, get acquainted with Longmire....more

title: Dangerous Women
author: Martin, George R.R.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Well, this is a bit unfair, since I only read the two stories I was interested in - the ones by Diana Gabaldon and George RR Martin. The Gabaldon was Well, this is a bit unfair, since I only read the two stories I was interested in - the ones by Diana Gabaldon and George RR Martin. The Gabaldon was fine, not great, but the Martin was awful.The Gabaldon story (Virgins) is one of Jamie and Ian as 17 year-olds, on an adventure while they were mercenaries in France. It was a nice visit with the boys, but didn't shed much light on anything. I mean, if you have read the books you already know about Jamie's status when he meets Claire, and you probably don't really care about Ian's virginity. So. The back and forth between the two of them is - as always - enjoyable. Just not very illuminating.The Martin story (The Princess and the Queen) is just dreadful. Set in Westeros about 150 years before the events in Game of Thrones, it does answer the question "where did the dragons all go"? Not very surprisingly, they all (well, not all, but damn near) kill each other as weapons in battles that are held in a dispute over who is next in succession when the king dies. The two sets of offspring of the dead king - one side from his first wife, the other side from his second wife go at it. We move from one battle to another, one assassination to another, in about the same scintillating style as the Bible enumerates all the begatting that takes place. To add to that, for those of you familiar with the Targaryen style of naming themselves, this gets very tedious and confusing. I guess since most of the offspring is the product of brothers and sisters, it's not surprising that the names would be repeated (A LOT), but it is confusing. We have several Viserys, Rhaenyras, Aemons, Aemonds, Dameons, Aegons, well you get the picture. I kept losing track of who was on which side, and finally realized I didn't care. There is NO character development to speak of. I love the Song of Fire and Ice books because I care about Tyrion, Arya, Jamie, etc etc. and what happens to them. There is nothing here to care about.I don't know what the quality of the other stories is, but this sort of anthology has become a very lazy way of living off of previous good work. I am SO glad I borrowed this from the library and didn't waste my money.Note: the first of these anthologies (or at least the first one I read), Warriors, was very good. And I read all the stories. While they varied in quality, it was a nice way to introduce a lot of writers I would not have otherwise known. So, if you're in the mood for an anthology, get Warriors. Don't waste your time with this.P.S. The only reason this is two stars instead of one or none, is because of Diana Gabaldon coming through - sort of half-heartedly, but still.......more

title: The Language of Flowers
author: Diffenbaugh, Vanessa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A remarkable first novel. I can't remember the last time that I read a book that truly explored new territory for me. This book had two such areas: foA remarkable first novel. I can't remember the last time that I read a book that truly explored new territory for me. This book had two such areas: foster care and the language of flowers, which was a Victorian notion of communication by using the meaning of flowers. (It isn't only a Victorian notion, but it seems to have had a heyday back then.)The story is told from the point of view of a young woman who is aging out of foster care at 18, and who is very emotionally fragile. It was tough going in the first few chapters because the first person point of view feels like an alien mind, and also because the chapters flip back and forth between current day and a period about ten years ago.My main difficulty with the book, however, is that it was uneven. The first third was powerful and moved along quickly. The middle third slowed down, but was still compelling. The last part of the book felt forced into an ending - not so much because it ended up where it was headed, but more because it just ran out of steam. And the ending was also a bit contrived.Nonetheless, a good read, a heartwarming book, and a truly impressive first novel....more

title: Five Days at Memorial: Life and Death in a Storm-Ravaged Hospital
author: Fink, Sheri
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The mother of all Monday morning quarterbacking stories. A fascinating, horrifying account of what happened in Memorial Hospital in New Orleans when HThe mother of all Monday morning quarterbacking stories. A fascinating, horrifying account of what happened in Memorial Hospital in New Orleans when Hurricane Katrina hit and the events afterward as families and law enforcement officials tried to piece together why certain patients at Memorial had died. Or had possibly been murdered.The underlying problem with a forensic analysis of these kind of events is that the circumstances cannot, or at least should not, be ignored. A hospital that is flooded, has lost power, and is housing 7 or 8 community residents for every hospital patient (not to mention hundreds of their pets) is not a hospital anymore. Yet the staff of Memorial were held to a legal standard as though they had been able to continue functioning as a normally operating hospital would, and three staff were arrested on (second degree) murder charges. There were mistakes made. Tragic mistakes, and errors of judgment. However, there were other hospitals that had equally difficult and tragic outcomes, but no staff from those hospitals were arrested.It isn't an easy retelling, but it is thorough. And it serves to make you think about not judging before you know the fuller story. ...more

title: MaddAddam        (MaddAddam, #3)
author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wonderful series. This has been billed as part three of a trilogy, but I don't think this is your normal trilogy. Instead of a chronological series, tWonderful series. This has been billed as part three of a trilogy, but I don't think this is your normal trilogy. Instead of a chronological series, this is more of a layering of information series. The first, Oryx and Crake, was enjoyable but had a very frustrating/ambiguous ending. The second, The Year of the Flood, was pretty much the same series of events, but told from a different set of characters' points of view. The ending was at the same plot point as the first, but with a bit more information. The third, Maddaddam, filled in lots of spaces and enriched the entire story. While it picked up where the first and second had ended, it had a lot of flashback information that again filled in many gaps in the main characters' histories.Taken together, a fabulous read. I feel comfortable now saluting Margaret Atwood. This is a masterful cautionary tale filled with rich characterizations, as well as a strong sense of place and time as humanity disintegrates (literally and figuratively).If you have the patience for it, this series is second to none. And, by the way, the prose is remarkable. Even if it weren't, these would be worth reading, but the writing is a wonderful bonus....more

title: Knocking on Heaven's Door: The Path to a Better Way of Death
author: Butler, Katy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A well done analysis of how medical technology is driving our medical system, which often results in horrific situations in end of life care. In thoseA well done analysis of how medical technology is driving our medical system, which often results in horrific situations in end of life care. In those circumstances (which are by no means rare), very little "nursing" goes on. It is one medical intervention after another, leading to something akin to torture for the person undergoing such "care", and destroying family and friends' attempts to allow a loved one to have a peaceful (but not necessarily painless) death. The toll in human suffering (in particular, for the family caregivers, usually an elderly spouse) is enormous -- not to mention the unbelieveable demands and consumption of Medicare and private/family resources.What I found instructive was that while I thought my family and I had covered most of the bases in planning for this - advanced directives, DNRs, etc., it turns out that once you make that 911 call, the medical establishment will in all likelihood ignore all your careful plans. This book has some useful specifics about how to combat that probability.The author recognizes the good that many of these devices have achieved, but makes a good case that the incentives for their use have been manipulated to result in their overuse.If you care about these issues, I'd recommend picking up a copy (or borrowing it from the library as I did)....more

title: The Year of the Flood        (MaddAddam, #2)
author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Well, that was interesting. It seems that Atwood got a lot of feedback about the ambiguous ending to Oryx and Crake, which she addressed by writing thWell, that was interesting. It seems that Atwood got a lot of feedback about the ambiguous ending to Oryx and Crake, which she addressed by writing this book. As such, the Year of the Flood is not really a sequel, but a different and deeper look at the events that unfold in Oryx and Crake. While the first book focuses primarily on two young boys/men, this book takes a much broader perspective with several different points of view of the events in Oryx and Crake.That said, I found the Year of the Flood much more satisfying. It unfolds in the same way, but instead of one unreliable narrator, there are (at least) two.One of the things I truly enjoyed was the development of the culture and mythology of the God's Gardeners sect, which was a counter-culture movement/group that despaired of the havoc that humans have visited on our planet. Atwood develops poetry, speeches, and a sense of the politics of that group which serves to deepen the story. It reminded me of the approach that Ursula LeGuin often takes - creating whole societies with their unique anthropological and ethnographical(?) roots.In this world, God's Gardeners recognize every day as a Saint's day. Some of the saints are obvious - Rachael Carson, Dian Fossey - but most are not. I really enjoyed visiting Wikipedia at the beginnings of every chapter to find out what a particular "saint" had contributed to a body of knowledge, usually environmental/green causes.I still remain puzzled by the impact Atwood's books have on me. While they are brilliant and often compelling, they are still somewhat remote, as though intellectual thought can create an almost physical barrier. Amazing writing, but not very accessible in the traditional sense.On to Maddadam....more

title: Endurance: Shackleton's Incredible Voyage
author: Lansing, Alfred
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A fabulous book. It shouldn't be. Books about unimaginable, longer-than-you-think-possible misery shouldn't be page turners. Especially when it is nonA fabulous book. It shouldn't be. Books about unimaginable, longer-than-you-think-possible misery shouldn't be page turners. Especially when it is nonfiction and you know how it turns out (presuming you avail yourself of Wikipedia).Ernest Shackleton was one of those intrepid British polar explorers that always begs the question, for me anyway, "Why?". What could possess a person to want to cross the continent of Antarctica (because Amundsen had already beaten him to the South Pole), and why would thousands of people compete for the privilege of accompanying him? [I do feel a bit disingenuous saying this, because earlier in my life, I would have given much to be a colonist on Mars or even the moon. But the poles never beckoned, even then. Now, I much prefer my couch and fleece blankets.]The author did a masterful job of extracting information from the daily journals that were kept by several of the crew, and even though I "listened" to the book, I raced to the library for the print copy when I realized that many, many pictures were included that had actually been taken by the expedition photographer. The narrator is also superb. Reading the journal entries by different authors, he does wonderful British posh, British workingman, soft Scottish burr, and nasal Aussie voices equally well.Even now, it is hard for me to believe that anyone actually survived this expedition, let alone the entire crew (well, minus some bits and pieces). These guys were perpetually wet in temperatures below zero. I did live in Alaska for a while, and I was given to understand being wet was death at sub-zero temperatures. So I still don't get it. But the fact is, they did survive. Somehow. Reading the book is like being there - except, as I mentioned, I was dry and warm and on my couch, not wet - damp or soaked, trying to sleep in a rotting sleeping bag, on starvation rations (of dog kibble and seal meat), day after day, month after month - watching the ship get crushed by the ice, then drifting on ice floes, with hurricane gale winds, etc etc.I'll never make fun of British fops again. Well, until I watch Monty Python again....more

title: Oryx and Crake        (MaddAddam, #1)
author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Truly conflicted on this one. I enjoyed reading it, but not for (I suspect) the reasons the author had in mind. While the characters were repellent, ITruly conflicted on this one. I enjoyed reading it, but not for (I suspect) the reasons the author had in mind. While the characters were repellent, I found myself sucked into the adolescent humor and the silly naming of various products....Oryx and Crake is a horror story about (what could possibly go wrong?) genetic manipulation/engineering, wrapped around a (not believeable) love triangle. There is much wonderous word-smithing in pursuit of this cautionary tale. But what ultimately captured me (in contrast to another horror/dystopian/more famous novel by Atwood - A Handmaid's Tale) was the humor. The two adolescent (and no, they never really grow up) boy/men are disgusting and hilarious in their pursuit of empty pleasures. A Handmaid's Tale had no humor, at least that I recognized.(Could I possibly throw in more parenthetical asides....sheesh.)At times it was a page turner. At times it was just depressing. But I kept coming back and I kept enjoying reading it. So that's probably enough for me to read the next two in this (loosely defined, I think) trilogy....more

title: A Cold Day for Murder        (Kate Shugak, #1)
author: Stabenow, Dana*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I've always been intrigued by this series, but had never gotten to it. Now I have, and I'm glad. The crime mystery was decent in its own right, but foI've always been intrigued by this series, but had never gotten to it. Now I have, and I'm glad. The crime mystery was decent in its own right, but for me the payoff is that this is a valentine to Alaska with its beauty as well as its harshness as reflected through the people who live there.I lived in the Fairbanks area for a short time a long time ago. I had never seen such natural beauty (nor have I since). And the people - aboriginal, Russian fur trader descendants, lower 48 transplants, and their intermixed offspring make for an interesting, frustrating brew. Shy, retiring types need not apply.This novel explores the tensions between cultures and the various assimilations of all groups toward an Alaskan "type" that is played out through the architecture of a murder mystery, and does it well. Stabenow has created a wonderful protagonist and surrounded her with a terrific and colorful supporting cast. Here's to Kate Shugak.... I intend to visit her again.PS While I listened to this as an audiobook, I noticed that it is a free Kindle book. At least for now it is....more

review: In addition to the beautiful prose, I simply loved the author's sly observations about people, life, dogs, and nature.Reading this book was like listeIn addition to the beautiful prose, I simply loved the author's sly observations about people, life, dogs, and nature.Reading this book was like listening to a comedian who loves people. All kinds of people. Don't get me wrong, he has disdain for some, but of course, they deserve it!Here's the publisher's blurb - I usually don't agree with them, and I could quibble with this, but you'll get the gist:"Donald Atwell didn't want a dog. He already had an ex wife, a balky truck, and a cat that was part Persian and part Taliban. But when a whiskery Blue-Ridge hillbilly put his puppy out on the side of the road, Donald didn't have much choice but to pick her up and take her in. Jerusalem Gap is the story of what happened next. Of how, in saving a mutt, one prickly old cuss saved himself a little as well. An Old Yeller for the 21st century, Jerusalem Gap is for anyone who's ever loved a four-legged pal."Besides, you can get it on Kindle for 99 cents. I will be reading more T.R. title: A Walk in the Woods: Rediscovering America on the Appalachian Trail
author: Bryson, Bill
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A fun listen. Especially on a long drive to the woods. Or, more accurately to the northern California coast so we can stay in the woods (sort of) withA fun listen. Especially on a long drive to the woods. Or, more accurately to the northern California coast so we can stay in the woods (sort of) with a full kitchen, wonderful bathrooms, and breath-taking views of the ocean.Bryson is an amazing writer with an amazing mind. His story-telling consists of humorous observations, broken up with 10 minute explanations of things like the complete history of the geology of the earth beginning with the Big Bang, and then further punctuated with rants about the National Forest Service and the nonprofits that "service" the AT. The recounting of his experience in the REI-like store to be outfitted for hiking the Appalachian Trail is worth the price of admission (or the book, if you pay for it). He was completely unprepared for the hike, and clearly the staff of the equipment store saw him coming a mile away.And of course, his hiking companion, was even less prepared. His friend's first trauma was coming to an understanding that he couldn't bring his Little Debbie baked goods - nor would they be available at the rest stops planned throughout the trip. But Snickers, now, that's a different story.Listen (or read) and enjoy....more

review: Always hard to put words to thoughts about Gaiman's writing. The usual - brilliant, insightful, poetry, scarier-than-shit childhood memories - all fitAlways hard to put words to thoughts about Gaiman's writing. The usual - brilliant, insightful, poetry, scarier-than-shit childhood memories - all fit here. He always captures time and place better than almost all writers - YOU ARE THERE, even though the places are usually heavily magical (in both good and bad ways).He writes so convincingly that you begin to wonder if you too have experienced horrific events in your childhood that you cannot, under normal circumstances, retrieve through your memory channels, and that only further trauma will expose them.That said, this is not a horror story, just stomach-churning at times. If you like Gaiman, you will like this. Also, a very quick read - nice to read a book that is less than 200 pages in contrast to my usual 500-800 page novels....more

review: This is a novel about the grace of simple things, and the peculiarhuman qualities that fight that notion. Harold Fry is approaching the end of his lifThis is a novel about the grace of simple things, and the peculiarhuman qualities that fight that notion. Harold Fry is approaching the end of his life - he has a loveless/actually hostile marriage, and he is full of disappointment in himself.Surprising himself, and all others who know him, Harold begins a walk from southern England to visit a friend in northern England. That friend, Queenie, was possibly the only real friend he has had in his life. He doesn't intend to do such a walk, but decides to do it after some odd happenstances.While it is an actual journey, it is more importantly a spiritual journey. In addition to journey with its lovely descriptions of England - in all of its floral, green beauty - Harold's inner journey is even more powerful.A lovely read. I would especially recommend it as an audiobook, because Jim Broadbent is the narrator. A perfect Harold in every way....more

title: Life After Life        (Todd Family, #1)
author: Atkinson, Kate
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is an amazing book. Just the prose alone would make it worth reading, but Atkinson has developed an idea I have seen before, but never delivered This is an amazing book. Just the prose alone would make it worth reading, but Atkinson has developed an idea I have seen before, but never delivered so well.The "gimmick" is that the protagonist of the book - Ursula Todd - is born, dies, is born again, dies again, over and over and over. That sounds depressing, but it isn't. What is really explores is how slightly (or not-so-slightly, in some cases) different factors/events/reactions can result in vastly different lives going forward.Over time, Ursula begins to realize that she has lived these lives before, and as she approaches a life-changing event, can sometimes alter the outcome. And sometimes that works, and sometimes it doesn't.However, that's just the gimmick/framework for the novel. What is draped on that frame is an amazing journey through World Wars I and II, as seen through British (middle upper class, not aristocracy) eyes and history. The impact of those wars, the outright horrors experienced by Londoners during the Blitz are visited and re-visited through Ursula's experiences. There are also segues that explore Germany between wars, the differences between living in London v. the country during World War II especially, and so much more.Definitely a book worth all the praise. And certainly a book worth reading....more

review: Loved the characters. Didn't love the story, such as it was. Good writing, good dialog. But it was a chore to finish. Sort of zombie or vampire hunterLoved the characters. Didn't love the story, such as it was. Good writing, good dialog. But it was a chore to finish. Sort of zombie or vampire hunter, but with eastern sensibilities. Don't like zombies, don't like vampires, and now, I don't like ghuls, and I don't like manjackals.Loved the idea that the protagonist was a sixty-ish, overweight, ready-to-retire ghul hunter. Loved it when he visited old friends and with affectionate exchanges such as "You may look like the son of the bear who screwed the buzzard, but you're the only real ghul hunter left in this whole damned-by-God city, O Great and Virtuous Doctor". In reply - "How would you know what I look like, Six Teeth? You whose crossed eyes can see nothing but the bridge of your own nose!"I could have read that kind of stuff for a very long time.Oh yeah. The protagonist (can't quite call him a hero) wears a snow white kaftan that can't get dirty. Food, blood, slime, hurled excrement - all just slides off. I'd like to get me one of those...But the story was tedious, plodding, and had the main problem that such types of books have - evildoers who don't die.... you cut the head off, and the hands go searching for the head to put it back on. I really don't like reanimations that are so formulaic. (Note: a big exception for Thoros of Myr....)...more

title: A Week in Winter
author: Binchy, Maeve
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is one of those days I truly loathe Goodreads. Somehow my writeup was deleted after I finished it but before it was posted. Sigh. Once more into This is one of those days I truly loathe Goodreads. Somehow my writeup was deleted after I finished it but before it was posted. Sigh. Once more into the breach.A lovely book. The first I've ever read by Binchy, but based on this, probably not the last, especially since her long time fans seem to indicate that this is not the best. Great characters, very little plot. The novel is organized around one Chicky Starr, and her efforts to restore an old estate and convert it into a full service inn. The first third or so is devoted to meeting Chicky and the small community of Stoneybridge on the west coast of Ireland. The balance of the book is developing the backstories, joys, and heartbreaks of two sets of characters: those who work at Stone House and the set of guests who come there in its first week of operation.While the setting and the cultures are very different, this nonetheless reminded me very much of the Ladies No. 1 Detective series. The same gentle and mostly kind observations about people that serve to remind us of our similarities as human beings, and how petty are most of the things that divide us. Not to overlook or downplay the petty, but just to serve as reminders that very few of us are perfect.A good read for anyone who wants a bit of light and kindness, triumph over adversity, and a protagonist who shows us what true strength is, and what community is all about....more

review: A pretty good book, but uneven. An emotionally abused protagonist who works herself through a miserable childhood, and even worse adulthood. But that A pretty good book, but uneven. An emotionally abused protagonist who works herself through a miserable childhood, and even worse adulthood. But that wasn't the problem - it was the writing that was uneven. A lot of lovely prose that occasionally went off the rails... Probably the main problem for me was the characters. While sympathetic, they never got my sympathy - I saw them, rather, as pathetic. That held for the nasty characters also - pathetic, rather than evil. The strong components were lovely imagery and (the flip side) was the characters' resiliance. Although, in the end, what that resiliance bought them was more abuse. Until the very end, when the sun peeks through the clouds....more

title: Elsewhere
author: Russo, Richard*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a memoir for anyone who has enjoyed Russo's books. I find him to be an extraordinary writer - his small towns and the people who populate themThis is a memoir for anyone who has enjoyed Russo's books. I find him to be an extraordinary writer - his small towns and the people who populate them belong to my history, not just his. His ear for dialogue is second to none.This book is a memoir, but for those of you who have read his stories, you will recognize Mohawk, Empire Falls, North Bath and other locales that are thinly veiled disguises for his real home town of Gloversville, New York.But what this book is really about is his relationship with his mother. Poignant and horrifying at the same time, Russo explores his childhood, coming of age, early adulthood, and his marriage, all through the lens of his co-dependence with his very needy mother. It is a relationship that is always shifting, but never changes. Russo examines it, warts and all, with the clear eye and clean prose we have come to expect from him.He doesn't disappoint....more

title: The Dog Stars
author: Heller, Peter
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Simply magical. This is a journey you go on with the protagonist. In his head. And his head makes beautiful music. About loss, about love, about frienSimply magical. This is a journey you go on with the protagonist. In his head. And his head makes beautiful music. About loss, about love, about friendship, about the world around him. This is the book I had hoped The Road might be. And wasn't. The protagonist is a survivor of a disaster - not sure if man-made or not, but a flu viral type that wipes out 99.99 percent of humanity. And the humanity that is left is not a fun bunch. Surviving takes away a lot of humor and lightness from life.But our man Hig did survive, and isn't sure he is happy about that. The prose is some of the best I've ever read. And the stuff I learned about:Hunting FishingGardeningFlyingHow to Kill People and Avoid Being KilledHow to Love Your DogHow to Appreciate the Stars at NightHow to Live with a Gun Nut Homicidal Type and Learn to Love HimI just don't know what to say without prattling. I am still somewhat dumbfounded. This book will stay in my head for a very long time. And it is going on my list of books to be read again....more

I have never before read anything by Wodehouse. Found this on audiotape while making a basement cleaning attempt recently and thought, Why Not? Have no idea how it got into my basement, but I have made similar improbable "finds" in the past - who knows what treasures you will find in boxes that haven't been opened in 20 or 30 years?Wonderful snide/snark/silliness. Sort of a mashup of Downton Abbey and the Marx Brothers. Ridiculously convoluted plot, but only reason for plot was to advance conversations between addlepated upper class Brits and other assorted twits, imposters, thieves, as well as star-crossed lovers. Some characters are many of the above. A few Americans thrown into the mix, and of course, the butler (not Jeeves), who is the only one with any sense. Or at least doesn't make a fool of himself.Just a whimsical delight. I've found a trove of them at the library, so I will be listening to more of these....more

title: Suspect        (Scott James & Maggie, #1)
author: Crais, Robert
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Not a bad book. But not a good book. Disappointed, because I have come to expect so much more from Crais. I adore the Elvis Cole books, and grew to reNot a bad book. But not a good book. Disappointed, because I have come to expect so much more from Crais. I adore the Elvis Cole books, and grew to really like his sidekick, Joe Pike. But this book and his last (Taken) seemed flat to me. Well written, clean prose, decent plot, just...flat. (I will concede the second half of the book was much more of a page turner than the first half.)About halfway through this book I hit upon a passage that reminded me of what I was missing - the humor. Best delivered by Elvis Cole, but humor in general. There is virtually no humor in this book. All right, it IS a murder mystery, but humor goes a long way for me, and its absence leaves me...flat.So, to give an example, the point at the halfway mark that reminded me of what I had been missing (the setup is that the protagonist cop and his K-9 companion pull up to a valet station in his ratty, unmarked car):"Two attendants were on duty in the parking lot. Scott parked across their entrance, and got out. The older attendant was a Latin man in his fifties with short black hair and a red vest. He hurried over when he saw Scott block their drive, but pulled up short when he saw Scott's uniform. This was the cop effect.He said, "You wan' to park?"Scott let Maggie out. The man saw her, and took a step back. This was the German Shepard effect."See what I mean? (And if not, you don't have to read any more.) I love these dry observations. And I miss them.I can see that Crais may feel that his Elvis Cole/Joe Pike stories have been played out. And god knows the abuse (gunshot wounds, maimings, etc) they have been through probably doesn't allow for any more damage to be visited on them. But I miss them. And their wisecrackin ways. Well, Elvis' wisecracks and his great straight man, Joe Pike....more

title: Wild: From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail
author: Strayed, Cheryl*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm conflicted. Good writing, easy to read, read it almost straight through. I also identified with a few of her issues, primarily unresolved mother iI'm conflicted. Good writing, easy to read, read it almost straight through. I also identified with a few of her issues, primarily unresolved mother issues. And Lord knows, she was unflinchingly truthful about her bad choices and bad behavior, which always makes for fascinating, if painful, reading. But I wanted to slap her a lot of the time. While she did have a lot of "outdoorsy" experience from being raised on 40 acres without running water, electricity, etc, she had never done any hiking or backpacking. And obviously she survived, but there were close calls, and she could have fairly easily died on this trek.She clearly was having some severe mental issues, and while I guess deciding to backpack 1000+ miles in some very rough wilderness might not be the best option for therapy, it probably was a better choice than continuing on the heroin spree. From the author notes on the jacket, it appears that she is no longer so self destructive, and clearly she believes that this trek was instrumental in that aspect. Probably was. At least it helped her start the real trail back to self-respect and off the trail of self-loathing she was so determinedly following prior to this "adventure".But I feel like the book should have a warning label - DON'T DO THIS AT HOME, KIDS....more

title: The Moon Is a Harsh Mistress
author: Heinlein, Robert A.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Another audiobook. During the 1950's, I "discovered" science fiction, and a major influence was Heinlein's juvenile series, e.g. Red Planet and Have SAnother audiobook. During the 1950's, I "discovered" science fiction, and a major influence was Heinlein's juvenile series, e.g. Red Planet and Have Spacesuit, Will Travel. I loved them.I remember being thrilled by this book (Moon is a Harsh Mistress) when I read it, no doubt in the 1960's when it was published. Then I read Stranger in a Strange Land, and decided Heinlein had lost his marbles. It wasn't so much that it violated cultural norms, which it did, it just seemed like pointless ramblings. Didn't read much Heinlein after that. Along the way I became convinced (don't know exactly why) that Heinlein had gone crazy. Like batshit, Howard Hughes crazy. Now I don't know why I thought that. But back to Moon is a Harsh Mistress.In some ways, this book holds up better than many others written fifty years ago...my god, can it really be that long ago? Because Heinlein was smart and an engineer, his scientific underpinnings were unusally strong and have held up fairly well over time. And he could always tell a good story. Re-reading this book, I wonder what I got out of it before - other than a good revolution always makes for a good read.Now his writing strikes me as quite didactic. His philosophy is a mashup of several different belief systems and is strongly underpinned by his libertarian stance. Using the convention of a new society that has evolved in the lunar colonies out of necessity (such as a scarcity of women), he fools around with family structure, governmental organization and general cultural norms. It is really quite interesting, but at times feels more like a how-to manual for revolution, or just creating a new society free of previous conventions. And sometimes the lectures go on a bit.I am glad I re-read the book, but realized I had no real memory of what I had read before - just that I had enjoyed it as a story of throwing the bastards out. Never really appreciated the clever, well-thought out strategies and tactics that were used in the revolution, or recognized that the real heart of the book was a condemnation of most of the forms of government used by humans....more

review: Was interested to see the "early" GRRM, i.e. pre Song of Ice and Fire. Wasn't blown away by stories like I was by the Game of Thrones, etc, but the auWas interested to see the "early" GRRM, i.e. pre Song of Ice and Fire. Wasn't blown away by stories like I was by the Game of Thrones, etc, but the autobiographical bits were really interesting. Lots of early fanzine info, petty rivalries in the 60's and 70's. His early exposures to Heinlein's YA, e.g. Have Spacesuit, Will Travel, echoed some of mine, but he was WAY WAY more into fanboy stuff. As in I wasn't, at all. (And again, it is all about me, right?) But it provides a nice framing for his evolution via short stories and TV work leading to Ice and Fire. I haven't read any of his novels, other than Ice and Fire series, maybe I will. Maybe.Of the stories included in this anthology, A Song for Lya was very moving. All of the rest had some interest (well, most of the rest), but the real reason to read this compendium is to get inside GRRM's head.I will definitely pick up Volume Two - noticed my library has in Kindle format, so I'm going for it....more

title: Still Alice
author: Genova, Lisa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Very well done exploration of Alzheimer's, as told in first person voice by a woman who has been diagnosed with early onset Alzheimer's at the age of Very well done exploration of Alzheimer's, as told in first person voice by a woman who has been diagnosed with early onset Alzheimer's at the age of fifty. It is a novel, but the author has a familiarity with the disease based on her grandmother's experience.As difficut as the topic is, the book is not a downer. In fact, even as she itemizes her losses, the main character comes to terms with her fate with more grace than might be expected. Not in a simple-minded "it's god's will" kind of thing, but with an actual resorting of her priorities, and her ability to enjoy what is left to her at each step of the way. She is certainly angry and afraid, yet somehow the author imbues her character with an inner strength that is life-affirming, even as her "life" slips away.And yes, it is horrifying as you-the-reader recognize certain behaviors that make you wonder about your own possible approaching dementia, but it is a healthy and good introspection. Or, at least it was for me....more

title: The Big Rock Candy Mountain
author: Stegner, Wallace
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A stunning book. I finally understand the phrase "deathless prose". I remained glued to this book/(audiobook) even though the story was painful. The eA stunning book. I finally understand the phrase "deathless prose". I remained glued to this book/(audiobook) even though the story was painful. The events in this book closely parallel Stegner's own life, and a tough one it was (or at least the first 30 or so years of it covered here). Born to two remarkable, if deeply flawed parents, this story follows a younger son in a family that survives, but does not triumph in the early 20th century. Some of this was due to the economic situations of the era, but most was undoubtedly due to the father's endless get-rich schemes that inevitably failed - either outright or because he would ride the scheme through early successes until it finally busted.The book begins with a quick overview of the father's own childhood, and sets the table for his impulses and drive to succeed. The courtship of Bo and Elsa Mason (the parents) is probably the most purely enjoyable section of the book. While the events that take the reader through the courtship, early marriage, parenthood, and finally the coming of age of the two sons produced in the marriage can be enumerated fairly easily, what makes the book stand out is the prose. Even at the depths of the worst situations, the prose held me in thrall. Lucious, overdone, discriptive beyond any need to advance the story, the prose just sings.The reader of the audiobook is also fabulous, and I will try to get my hands on other books he has narrated, not the least of which is Stegner's Angle of Repose.This is a classic in every sense of the word that I can think of....Note: there are several phrases/word usages that we have grown past - politically incorrect in today's world - that are a bit jarring, but it needs to be remembered that this book was written in the 1930's....more

title: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time
author: Haddon, Mark
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The narrative in the book is first person POV of one Christopher Boone, a teenager who is undoubtedly somewhere on the autism spectrum. In many ways hThe narrative in the book is first person POV of one Christopher Boone, a teenager who is undoubtedly somewhere on the autism spectrum. In many ways he is what people in the trade refer to as "high functioning", since he is brilliant with respect to math and science, and is able to interact with other people in accordance with a set of rules and stylized rituals. However, the author asserts he is no expert on autism - I don't know, much of the narrative seemed right to me, but I also am processing the novel's presentation with what are conventional wisdoms about autism.I was really affected by the inner dialogue of Christopher. So much so that a few times when I would put the book down to do something else, I realized I was translating my own experiences of the moment in the same fashion that Christopher did in his narrative. (On the other hand, I am the type of person who often "sees" information in charts and graphs and patterns and puzzles, so the exposition seemed very clear to me. The digressions seemed right also, don't you know....?)The story told, however, was the tragic tale of the impact of Christopher's needs on those who care about him - parents, teachers, neighbors. And much of the time, it isn't a pretty picture. And I was so hoping (I know, stupidly) for some sort of happy ending. While I knew better than to expect it, I still hoped. But that would have been the wrong ending for a book like this. So, after spending time with Christopher and his pet rat, Toby, the particular adventure ends, and life goes on. Awkwardly, I'm sure, but it goes on....more

title: The Handmaid’s Tale        (The Handmaid's Tale, #1)
author: Atwood, Margaret*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm sure that if I had read this when it came out some 25 years ago or so, it would have knocked my socks off. But it has a bit of a dated feel now, aI'm sure that if I had read this when it came out some 25 years ago or so, it would have knocked my socks off. But it has a bit of a dated feel now, although having seen how the Taliban (not to mention the Saudis) treat women in those intervening years, it also has a bit of a prophetic feel to it. The first half or so of the book was riveting, because it is told from that first person POV where you as the reader don't really know what is going on, and you have to figure it out from the contextual clues the author spreads around. But once you figure it out, it begins to drag, the only real question is whether or not it will end as badly as it probably will. Actually, that was a nice touch by the author to maintain the ambiguity past the end of the book. Don't think that is a spoiler alert, but maybe.....Well written, poetic at times - which only emphasizes the horror - but by the end of the book, I was ready for it to end. I'm glad I read it, but it will never be one I'll be tempted to re-visit....more
