title: Mugabe and the White African: Dostoyev
author: MBE, Ben Freeth
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am reluctantly giving this book 3 stars, to average out the one star and five star ratings that it truly deserves. Absolutely compelling subject matI am reluctantly giving this book 3 stars, to average out the one star and five star ratings that it truly deserves. Absolutely compelling subject matter about how Mugabe has destroyed his country under the guise of throwing off the colonial yoke of Dutch/Scottish/British settlers in Rhodesia/Zimbabwe by murder, theft, intimidation and just general thuggery. And a first person account, no less.But the writing. After slogging through the first 100 pages, and skipping through the rest (while checking Wikipedia about some stuff), I understand why editors are important. The writing is deadly awful. Still could mostly forgive that, but the writer ends up justifying his stubborn refusal to leave Zimbabwe because he believes that is what God wanted. Maybe. But having three kids under the age of 10 and a wife subjected to being shot at and having their home burned around their ears, hard for me to stomach. OK to risk your own skin, but not OK to risk kids.Zimbabwe is a human tragedy of the first order, and it is rare to get such a close-up of a madman and his minions. That said, the prose almost killed my ability to get through it....more

author: King, Stephen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Stephen King can write. Sometimes I really don’t like what he writes, particularly when he doubles down on the horror aspects. After reading Cell a feStephen King can write. Sometimes I really don’t like what he writes, particularly when he doubles down on the horror aspects. After reading Cell a few years ago, I swore I would never read another Stephen King book. Well, so much for my principled stances…In 11/22/63, his writing skills are employed to his fullest and best use. While he still occasionally meanders too much in the yuk factor, for the most part he tells a compelling story based on the premise of a time traveler’s attempt to stop the assassination of JFK. (Given the title of the book, don’t think this qualifies as a spoiler…)While dealing with all the paradoxes introduced by time travel events in more or less standard fashion, the heart of the book is about star crossed lovers -- the protagonist, and a woman from the time he travels to. It reminded me emotionally and thematically of the Star Trek episode “The City on the Edge of Forever”, possibly the best Star Trek episode ever done. (Notwithstanding Harlan Ellison’s complaints about Roddenberry screwing up his script.) He makes you care about the characters, and evokes the past in a way that you can smell it and taste it (often, but not always, a good thing). King and I are only about a month apart in age, and he brings back the 1950’s and 1960’s so hauntingly that my own memories were triggered. One of his best.I will say I think it could have been shorter, but that was OK. I enjoyed my time in the past…....more

title: Tracker
author: Rollins, James*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am just using this to bitch. A ripoff is a ripoff, even if it's only 99 cents. This was dangled out there when I was looking at Rollins' new book, BI am just using this to bitch. A ripoff is a ripoff, even if it's only 99 cents. This was dangled out there when I was looking at Rollins' new book, Bloodline. Advertised as a short story to introduce two new characters who are in Bloodline, Tucker Wayne and his faithful, exceedingly well-trained, dog Kane. Like the idea, like the dog, as usual hate the stupid name that Rollins gives his protagonists, I mean, come on. Right out of the Hollywood naming conventions of the 1950's....Liked the idea of a short story blah blah blah. Well, of the estimated 69 pages (this is only available in ebook), about 15 or 20 are the short story - no plot to speak of. Lovely damsel in distress being chased by cartoonish bad guys, Tucker and Kane dispatch quickly, find gold worth about $200 million from old Jewish cemetary hidden there by Nazis, blah blah blah. You get the picture. The rest of the book is the first chapter or so of Bloodline, which I think you can read on the amazon page for free anyway.I like Rollins stuff because his books are action-packed page turners with a bit of interesting scientific extrapolation, a la Michael Crichton. Rollins doesn't write as well as Crichton because his character development is seriously deficient, but the roller coaster rides are fun.I expect Bloodline to be good fun, and will read it. Just wanted to complain because I felt like such a sucker. Not the best 99 cents I've ever spent. So I'm off to read and dawdle over a $2.25 pot of tea.......more

title: An Echo in the Bone        (Outlander, #7)
author: Gabaldon, Diana*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: All caught up now, and waiting for "My Own Heart's Blood" to come out next year. While I enjoyed this 'episode' of the Outlander series, it left a fewAll caught up now, and waiting for "My Own Heart's Blood" to come out next year. While I enjoyed this 'episode' of the Outlander series, it left a few things hanging in a way that I'm not used to from this author. As in cliffhangers. And I don't like cliffhangers. I guess I'm glad I didn't read this until now, because the wait shouldn't be too long.One of the things I really liked about this one is that it covers several important events in the American Revolution that occured in New York state, notably the Battles of Fort Ticonderoga and Saratoga, plus the travels down the Hudson Valley to New York and on to Philadelphia. This is pure nostalgia for me, having grown up in the Hudson Valley, and endured/enjoyed the family camping trips to Lake George/Lake Champlain/Fort Ticonderoga. Of course, what I remember about Ticonderoga was the awful stink of the wood pulp factories (check your #2 pencils, everyone, for that Ticonderoga imprint). I knew there was a fort there, but hey, when you are 12 or whatever, not so interesting... now I can't get enough of it. As I read the book, I was constantly flipping back and forth to Google maps and Wikipedia, checking out how many of the characters Jamie and Claire (and William) interact with were real. Quite a few, as it turns out.And Claire's medical adventures are pretty wild in this one. As if trying to practice medicine in the 18th century when you have 20th century knowledge wasn't challenging enough, now she gets to deploy her skills on the battlefields. Messy and nasty doesn't begin to describe it. And again, I can't get enough of it.OK, back to the other stacks and stacks of books that have been neglected whilst I have been traveling with Jamie and Claire.......more

title: The Secret River
author: Grenville, Kate
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Heart-breaking, difficult telling of the early settlment of New South Wales (now Australia) by English convicts. As horrifying as it gets at times, itHeart-breaking, difficult telling of the early settlment of New South Wales (now Australia) by English convicts. As horrifying as it gets at times, it feels like an emotionally truthful telling. The writer is especially good at imagery. She paints the landscapes - both the bleak, cold, wet London and the contrast of sunlight that is so bright it hurts the eyes and the starkness of the windswept territory that is New South Wales. The protagonist is William Thornhill, a riverman by trade, who knows every curve and current of the Thames, who is sent to a land with rivers that are unknown to him. And his ability to navigate by the stars is gone. He learns over time that the Southern Cross is as reliable as the North Star, but these are not easy lessons.The heart of the story is the clash between two cultures - the colonists and the native people. And, predictably, not all goes well. In fact, it goes horribly wrong. Some of the colonists are truly despicable people. Thornhill is not, but he is no paragon of virtue, either. He is very human. And while none of the aborigines are portrayed as bad people, it really doesn't matter. The clash between two cultures that are so different never goes well, so it isn't a surprise that it doesn't here either.I believe this is required reading in Australia's schools, and I can see why. A good read....more

Thank God.The subject matter should have done it - MURDER! MAYHEM! WORLD'S FAIR! FIRST FERRIS WHEEL! But at some point, I just felt like I was wading through lists. He murdered so-and-so, and then he murdered her sister, and then her children, and oh yeah, the friendly waitress, and the troublesome workers who helped him build his lovely kilns and other things that he used to dispose of the bodies.And the keeping track of the progress of the construction of the World's Fair. An amazing accomplishment. So why was I so bored?I'm glad I read it, always nice to add a little history to my knowledge base, but I'm going back to fiction for a bit.......more

review: Pretty remarkable book. All of the characters are damaged and/or broken. The purported heroine, Kathy Mallory, is described as a sociopath -- high funPretty remarkable book. All of the characters are damaged and/or broken. The purported heroine, Kathy Mallory, is described as a sociopath -- high functioning, of course. In fact, it is that quality that separates her from much of humanity which ironically makes her so good at what she does. (Homicide detective.) She comes across as a female Sherlock Holmes, as portrayed in the current BBC/PBS series with Benedict Cumberbacht (sp?).The general parameters of this mystery are a horror. Children torturing other children. Pedophiles. Corrupt cops and politicians. Not what I am usually drawn to, and probably wouldn't have read this, but something in a  somewhere sometime made me put it on a list and when it popped up, I read it. The first chapter is pretty mesmerizing. Horrifying, but mesmerizing, and I just had to see where it went.Glad I read it. I'll probably go back to the beginning of this series (this one is ninth Mallory book, I think) to see how Mallory was developed. But I found the plot satisfying and resolved nicely with just the right amount of ambiguity about a few things. Really about the characters, not so much the plot.If you like mysteries, and you aren't too squeamish, this might appeal to you. At the very least, it is very well written....more

The SoutI didn't hate this book, but it came close at times. Maybe I would have liked it better at another time, but I found myself terribly annoyed. The Southern Gothic wears on me a bit, especially when the cliches are so lazy and the stereotypes are so trite. Not all southerners are in-bred halfwits, but you might not know that from reading this book. And by halfwits I don't even mean dumb, just indecisive and dithering. Unless they were mean. And mean old Daddy who abused all of his family members in horrific ways has been done to death. Tennessee Williams at least made them interesting, if loathsome. Here they were just loathsome.I wanted to like this book, but I didn't. This was Hart's first book, so maybe he got better as he wrote, but I don't think I will bother to find out....more

title: Raylan        (Raylan Givens, #3)
author: Leonard, Elmore
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Reading this was a bit of an odd experience. If you are a fan of "Justified" (and if you aren't, what is wrong with you?), reading this book is a lot Reading this was a bit of an odd experience. If you are a fan of "Justified" (and if you aren't, what is wrong with you?), reading this book is a lot of deja vu. Only not quite. There are three (or so) loosely linked stories here, two of which are pretty much contained in a couple of Justified episodes. So it was like reading a couple of early drafts of screenplays for those episodes and maybe a rejected one. Or maybe more like a mashup of a few episodes from different seasons.What was disquieting was that several of the more colorful characters were included, but details were different. For instance, the story arc in season 2 of Justified was built around a wonderful character named Mags Bennett, a matriarch of one of the hollers and queen of potgrowing enterprises for most of eastern Kentucky. She has several dim-witted sons - Dickie and Coover among them - who float through several episodes. In the book, instead of Dickie and Coover Bennett, we have Dickie and Coover Crowe, dim-witted sons of Pervis Crowe, patriarch of one of the hollers and king of potgrowing enterprises for most of eastern Kentucky. Have no idea where Mags went, but she was one of my favorite characters, and Dickie in particular was one of her creatures...not just her son, but so much more/less.But Boyd Crowder is here, and Art, Raylan's boss is here, and kidneys are removed from living victims and those victims are left behind in bathtubs (just like in the first episode of season 3). Evil coal mining executive - in the form of blond sexpot Carol Conlon makes entrances and exits (just like in season 2).So it was a bit eerie - so close, but odd details changed for no reason that made sense to me.And there is the whole thing about how ethical it is to put a "new" book out there that is already out there in a mashed up TV version...but it is Elmore Leonard, and he deserves whatever he can milk out of this wonderful character, as partial payment for all the other wonderful stuff he has already given the world.So if you watch Justified, you can skip this if you need "new" stuff. If you just want to wallow around in the wonderful dialogue, go for it. Can't go wrong....more

title: The Knife of Never Letting Go        (Chaos Walking, #1)
author: Ness, Patrick
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I am really, really conflicted by this book. I was in a rage last night when I finished it, now just angry. This is a really unappealing story with unI am really, really conflicted by this book. I was in a rage last night when I finished it, now just angry. This is a really unappealing story with unlikeable characters (only likeable character gets killed, I guess to prove this is a really harsh world we've entered). The talent of the author, however, is considerable. The first third of the book flew by - first person narrative by illiterate protagonist is a device I like a lot, where you have to figure out what is going on by decoding the events as seen through the eyes of someone for whom communication is a stuggle. Lots of nifty stuff - talking dogs. I mean TALKING DOGS!!! Almost worth it just for that. Half the population (women) able to hear what is going on in others' (men) heads, and, in fact, can't shut it out as much as they would like to. Author does a really good job depicting the downsides of such a system - the trilogy is not subtitled "Chaos Walking" for nothing.But the big reveals were telegraphed early and often - very anticlimatic when ACTUALLY revealed. (Side note: annoyingly, when the narrator gets an important insight, it is not always shared with the reader. I mean, what's up with that? Part of the payoff of a first person POV is being in the character's head. So having a curtain drawn for big insights is truly mystifying, although, as I already commented, not much of a curtain, since the plot points were so obvious in coming.)And for anyone complaining about the violence in The Hunger Games, they should avoid this series. Graphic gore, and evil characters WHO WILL NOT DIE. The author might as well have made some of them zombies - I mean, when a bad guy loses an eye, and enough facial meat that you can see his jaw and teeth, hasn't bathed in probably a couple of years, and has lots of dried blood festooned all over his body, what is the difference between him and a zombie for general unattractiveness?And for the last third of the book, which is basically an extended chase scene (actually the whole book is an extended chase scene, but this part is one continuous one), the author uses his considerable writing skills to shamelessly create a page-turner. And every one of those mini-climaxes is culminated by yet another seemingly mortal wounding, where on the next page, THEY DON'T DIE. (Did I mention that already?)So I will not be reading parts 2 and 3, because it is hard for me to believe that such a sadistic writer will have the kind of payoff that keeps me reading.I'm going back to my safe world of Jamie and Claire and their world travels through 18th century European and American history for a while. Still think that series is one of the best of all time....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It was nice to visit with Will and Temeraire again. More travels on behalf of, or in spite of, the British Empire. This time to South America and the It was nice to visit with Will and Temeraire again. More travels on behalf of, or in spite of, the British Empire. This time to South America and the Inca. This entry in the ongoing saga was like those family trips from my childhood - all seven or eight of us jammed into the trusty station wagon, kids bickering and whining about someone crowding into their space, with Dad ineffectually threatening us with the old "Don't make me have to stop the car" and someone insisting every five minutes or so that she was going to pee in her pants if we didn't find a bathroom.Temeraire and Iskierka have regressed into petulant whining adolescents, and Will has become the ineffectual parent. I know this all sounds unlikely, but I love these characters. Somehow Novik continues to imbue them with personalities you want to spend time with, even as you tear your hair out. And not to worry, Napoleon shows up on cue, with the evil (hiss hiss boo) Lien at his side, but our trusty heroes outwit them again (mostly).Read these, but in order. The earlier books have more depth and take their social commentary much more seriously than the latter books in the series. Now for me, they offer the opportunity to visit with old friends....more

review: I decided to find out why Nora Roberts sells so many books. Having read the first in her "In Death" series, I still don't know, but I won't be readingI decided to find out why Nora Roberts sells so many books. Having read the first in her "In Death" series, I still don't know, but I won't be reading any more.While the plot, although predictable, was serviceable, the characters were one-dimensional and the descriptions of "relationships" or just how the characters were perceiving each other wore thin really fast. I guess her forte is romance books, but that is a genre that has never appealed to me overmuch. And while some people maintain that the Outlander series by Diana Gabaldon should be classified as romance, I would say that if these two are in the same genre, it is just because of the need for booksellers to categorize offerings. The Outlander series is rich with detail and full of characters that you wish you could be friends with and enjoy spending time with, and you are happy just to read their stories.I not only didn't care for the lead character (homicide detective Eve Dallas) or her "romantic" interest and murder suspect Roarke, I was hoping that someone (anyone!) would kill them....more

title: Death Comes to Pemberley
author: James, P.D.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Kind of fun. Shows how remarkable a writer P.D. James is, in case any of you were still wondering. This book picks up six years after the events of PrKind of fun. Shows how remarkable a writer P.D. James is, in case any of you were still wondering. This book picks up six years after the events of Pride and Prejudice, where Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy are blissfully wed with two young sons. It is a mystery, and not a bad one. The biggest problem is that James is so note perfect with respect to Austen’s original work, that it got boring. The same boringness of the original work is built upon – that is, wickedly funny observations planted scarcely among the rest of the story. About one witty remark every 50 or so pages…So high marks for James’ talent, low marks for bringing back the kind of worst aspects of Austen’s writing. I blame it on the period and English sensibilities of the time, rather than her writing. It is really hard to feel the anguish of an unpressed ascot from where I sit…....more

author: Lithgow, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have always been intrigued by John Lithgow, but I truly was amazed at his versatility when I heard some of his performances of children's songs thatI have always been intrigued by John Lithgow, but I truly was amazed at his versatility when I heard some of his performances of children's songs that he wrote. I grew up in a small town with one big celebrity - Pete Seeger, who is a master musical storyteller. John Lithgow can match him stride for stride with the songs he has performed/written for children. Anyway, I was curious when I saw this at the library, and I had been sort of casting about for something on CD to play in the car and I saw this.Well, I cried during the introduction. One of the most touching "bits" I've ever heard. I'm not a real theater person, but I have seen my share of plays and musicals (and wallowed in Rogers and Hammerstein stuff as a kid with my four sisters - prancing and dancing around in the living room to my dad's occaisional bellow "this ain't a goddamn gymnasium"). And I've been impressed with Lithgow since I saw him as Roberta Muldoon in "The World According to Garp" in the early 80's.This is just a marvelous telling of a remarkable life and how that life was shaped by many things, but most importantly, his father, Arthur Lithgow.I really recommend listening to this (it is probably a good read, also, but I can't imagine it being any better than as read by the author). You won't be sorry....more

title: All Quiet on the Western Front
author: Remarque, Erich Maria
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I can understand why the Nazis banned/burned this book in 1933. Wouldn't have been much help for young men to read this while the Nazis were trying toI can understand why the Nazis banned/burned this book in 1933. Wouldn't have been much help for young men to read this while the Nazis were trying to spur nationalistic fervor.May be the saddest thing I have ever read (or more accurately, listened to). Poetic, sad, sad, sad. The amazingly articulate (and this had to have survived a couple of translations for me to comprehend it, since my German doesn't exist) description of young men losing their humanity during World War I is very powerful. Its POV is a first person narrative of a 19 year old German boy/man/old man/human/not human who is so transformed by his experience of three years at the front of a most horrible war that he decides after his first leave home that he will never do that again. If he survives, and the war ends (something he really can't imagine) he will go home. Maybe. But for sure, not otherwise.The author's ability to articulate the disconnectedness of this young man to everything but his comrades on the front with him is incredible. And did I mention sad.This is an unrelenting tragedy as it unfolds. For instance, in contrast to the Killer Angels, a book about the Civil War battle at Gettysburg, this book takes you down early and never lets you up. The Killer Angels describes a tragedy, to be sure, but the attitudes of those fighting and the respect that many of the participants had for each other (across Blue/Gray lines), in addition to understanding the battle and its strategies and tactics has a glorious, if horrifying, aspect.In this book, the young men have no sense of what is going on outside of their pitiful patch of ground, which is probably not much different from the field at Gettysburg, over a three year period, as opposed to a three day period.And then at the end, they all die. The last one, the narrator, dies in October 1918, a few weeks before Armistice Day. I don't mean this as a spoiler, but to offer a sense of the hopelessness. It is probably one of the most powerful antiwar books ever written....more

title: Cleopatra: A Life
author: Schiff, Stacy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a bore. In fairness, I didn't finish it. Got through 2 discs out of 11 or 12 and just couldn't stand it anymore. Two problems - the substance of What a bore. In fairness, I didn't finish it. Got through 2 discs out of 11 or 12 and just couldn't stand it anymore. Two problems - the substance of the book, and the reader on the CD version I was listening to. The author starts off by telling you that very little real evidence exists about Cleopatra's life and that most of what we "know" was written by three biographers none of whom were born before she died and who (in the author's opinion) had agendas to grind with the idea of a powerful woman. So they created this image of her as a wanton, seductive teenager. OK, I can buy that. But as the book progresses, every time anything about Cleopatra's life is explored, many many caveats about the accuracy of the information is restated ad nauseam. The author tries a technique of trying to use the context of the times to paint a more realistic picture of Cleopatra. Not a bad idea, just becomes a boring lecture after a while. For instance, in describing Cleopatra's education, the author gives a description of what an education for a wealthy Alexandrian child would have looked like - OK idea, but then the overly detailed listing of curricula, down to what topics in geometry would have been covered, all the while stating over and over about how "we don't know what she actually received for an education, but a reasonable assumption would be that it looked like this"...You get the picture. It felt more like a thesis than a book meant to be read for pleasure. My mistake, I guess.And oh yeah - I really disliked the reader - one of those supercilious speaking styles that I find irritating - like the woman who does book s on NPR. I have real trouble listening to those book s....more

title: The Killer Angels        (The Civil War Trilogy, #2)
author: Shaara, Michael
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a profound, stunning book. The many voices all blending toward the cataclysm that was the Battle of Gettysburg are heartbreaking and inspiringThis is a profound, stunning book. The many voices all blending toward the cataclysm that was the Battle of Gettysburg are heartbreaking and inspiring. And by voices, I don't just mean the written word, because I listened to this book -- and the narrator was incredible. From the soft Southern cadences for Robert E. Lee (sounding eerily like Shelby Foote) to the gruff growl of Longstreet to the lilt of Buster Kilrain (Irish immigrant fighting for the Union), I was carried along. And all along, I knew I was headed for the waterfall. And when I went over, I wept. For the horrifying, stupid loss of life that somehow seemed necessary for the birth of our nation and the beginning of the eradication of slavery.I was so moved by this book that I am going out to buy it (for those of you who know how rare that is - I AM the queen of the public library) and I've ordered the movie from Netflix. I will be wallowing in this for a while. ...more

author: Hoffman, Alice*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The structure of this book was similar to a couple of books I've read lately - and in all cases, I did not realize that they were collections of looseThe structure of this book was similar to a couple of books I've read lately - and in all cases, I did not realize that they were collections of loosely connected stories, rather than a novel, until I had started to read them. In this book, the unifying theme(s) are the community, its original inhabitants and their descendants, and the effect of the land on them -- over a 250 year period.The writing is elegant. Lovely prose. And some stories were compelling, others not so much. What I really enjoyed about the book, though, was the use of quasi-magic -- not magic that could be controlled but magic that was organic to the land/community itself. It was a very gentle touch and very pleasurable to listen to (oh yeah, this was in audiobook form). Another personal bonus was that I am reasonably familiar with the geographic area where these stories take place, and there are many similarities to the geography and people who live there to the area where I grew up. ...more

title: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks
author: Skloot, Rebecca*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book should be required reading for anyone thinking about a future in medicine or medical research, or for that matter, a career in journalism. AThis book should be required reading for anyone thinking about a future in medicine or medical research, or for that matter, a career in journalism. And it should be read by anyone looking for an amazing detective story, combined with the chronicle of a daughter who ultimately transcends institutional indifference to establish the importance of her mother's contribution to medical research. It is also almost impossible to believe that this is the author's first book.The sociological subtext of the legacy of slavery also cannot be ignored in this story (and certainly isn't). Although what happened to Henrietta Lacks could conceivably have happened to any poor person, the time and place of the events described in this book were definitely more likely to happen to an African American still living on the remnants of an old tobacco plantation than to anyone else.A compelling read - good science, good story, will stick with me for quite a while. ...more

title: Let the Great World Spin
author: McCann, Colum*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is an amazing, amazing book. I listened to it, rather than read it, and it may be better as an audiobook than print, but I would certainly recommThis is an amazing, amazing book. I listened to it, rather than read it, and it may be better as an audiobook than print, but I would certainly recommend either version. There are many characters in this novel and each one has his/her own reader -- all of whom are excellent, but I have to admit my favorite was the reader for the Irish priest (whose character may or may not have been inspired by the actual Berrigan brothers).The construction of the story is built around events on August 7th, 1974 in New York City, "anchored" by Phillipe Petit, better known as the guy who tightrope walked between the twin towers in NYC on that date.The structure of the book takes narrative turns with a set of very disparate characters who appear absolutely unrelated at first, but whose fates are intertwined in the events of the day in ways that will surprise you. One of the s I read of the book compared it to the movie "Crash" and I think that is an apt comparison.Judges, Irish immigrants, hookers, bereaved mothers, drug-addicted (yet commercially successful) artists are all pulled together over the telling of the story in a series of wonderfully drawn character portraits. And NYC has to also be considered a character. McCann has the ability to draw word pictures second to no other author that I can think of... his scenes have so much texture - noise, color, scent, sweat that you are there.One of my favorites in a long time.October 2021: re-read for book club. Still fabulous.......more

review: OK, it is well-written. Franzen has a real gift for cutting prose -- he can level a culture in a couple of paragraphs... who could have ever imagined OK, it is well-written. Franzen has a real gift for cutting prose -- he can level a culture in a couple of paragraphs... who could have ever imagined damning the entire Millenial generation by their over-reliance on flip-flops? But talented as he is, essentially he is one mean-spirited SOB. Finishing the book was a real test for me -- found all sorts of reasons to not pick it up. In fact, I probably would not have finished it if I hadn't been on a vacation that involved a LOT of reading. I also had to bookend it with Pern dragonriders to make it through.Unlikeable people -- emotional cripples -- lashing out at each other, seemingly in a contest to see who could inflict the most pain. And they all won.Nonetheless, it was an amazing tour de force of well-written prose, so I am torn between 2 and 3 stars and gave the book the benefit of the doubt. However, I can't really recommend it unless you are one of my masochistic friends.......more

title: All the Weyrs of Pern        (Pern, #11)
author: McCaffrey, Anne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Anne McCaffrey's world of Pern is one of my favorite world-building series. I think as a girl growing up in the 50's and 60's, I was the perfect targeAnne McCaffrey's world of Pern is one of my favorite world-building series. I think as a girl growing up in the 50's and 60's, I was the perfect target for the Dragonrider books. Having been told I could not pursue either of my dream careers (astronaut or [large-animal] veterinarian) simply because I was a girl really crushed me. Along comes Lessa, destined to become the greatest dragon rider of all Pern. I was caught up and transported to this strange world where a girl beat the odds. And on dragons, too. (Yup, not a very subtle substitution for horses.) So I was enthralled. Now, some 30 or 40 years later, I am determined to conquer my generally-unused iPod nano by loading an audiobook from the library. And so, because I am more interested in the PROCESS of downloading, rather than caring WHAT I download, I begin my search with a parameter limitation to "books that are available", and I begin to browse in sci-fi and fantasy (as is my wont), and one of the first books up is "All the Weyrs of Pern" (as in starts with "A"). Pern. Happily, after much swearing and downloading of recalcitrant software, All the Weyrs of Pern is on my Nano. And what a good time I had. I love the fustiness of the society and its stilted language and customs, the silliness of descriptive prose that serves no purpose but to keep reminding you that you aren't on Earth anymore -- how many times can you be enticed by a "flagon of steaming-hot klah"...without laughing?? Descriptions of all the holds, weyrs, and halls (generally speaking, the structure of Pern society) - and the master craftsmen etc etc etc... are ridiculous and florid and detailed and wonderful (makes Steig Larssen seem like Hemingway in comparison). The victorian/almost dickensian mores and customs are so silly yet provide a real grounding in another civilization that echoes our own, but not.So, I've decided that I may re-visit the several series that have grabbed me and allowed me to escape into another existence - Diana Gabaldon's Outlander series, McCaffrey's Pern, Novik's Temeraire, the wonderful Jo Walton's Sulien books, Tony Hillerman's Joe Leaphorn and Jim Chee mysteries, and Alexander McCall Smith's Ladies No. 1 Detective books. And maybe work in some others along the way...happy reading!!...more

review: I really liked this book, but the ending fell a little flat for me. After thinking about it, I guess it has something to do with my American sensibiliI really liked this book, but the ending fell a little flat for me. After thinking about it, I guess it has something to do with my American sensibilities whilst reading British mystery writers. Dunno. But setting that aside, the writing is fantastic, the characters pop out of the book and run around -- in fact, sometimes you ARE the characters -- the humor is my cup of tea (so to speak), and the various "case histories" are fascinating and extremely well drawn. As the book progresses, the author takes what appear to be three/four unrelated "cold" cases, and as Jackson Brodie, our flawed self-flagellating protagonist picks up these cases and begins to investigate, the threads start to weave together into a tapestry, getting more drawn together and intricate as the pages fly by. And they did fly by. But the way the tapestry ended up being resolved left me a bit unsatisfied, and I won't say more in case some of you decide to read this. And I would encourage anyone who likes great character development, interesting/flawed protagonists, and mysteries to give this a whirl. And I believe that this is the first of a series with Jackson Brodie, so I will be looking for the others. ...more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: OK, first book was Temeraire's birth and early training in England (with his trusty sidekick, Will Laurence, British naval officer turned dragon captaOK, first book was Temeraire's birth and early training in England (with his trusty sidekick, Will Laurence, British naval officer turned dragon captain), followed by Temeraire's exploration of his "roots" in China, then Temeraire on the Silk Road, with special emphasis on Constantinople and other Balkan hot spots, and now in book 4, we have Temeraire in Africa!!As ridiculous as this sounds, these are more than just ripping good fantasy reads. There is a lot of history (and geography) wedged in here (with a lot of cleverness on the author's part to work the dragons into "real" history). And lots of detail of the kind I like -- how DO you really make a usable harness for a 20 ton critter and how do you get around while in flight? What kinds of ingredients do you add in to keep the dragon diet interesting? And how foul can medicinal poultices get before you actually prefer dying?I know this must sound even more ridiculous, but for me, the kind of texture and background in this series is what makes it so enjoyable. It is the kind of attention to detail and nuanced exposition that made books like Cold Mountain and Diana Gabaldon's Outlander series so wonderful. Good stories, but so much more than the plots and well-developed characters. In fact, this kind of detail is one good way of developing full character profiles.Anyhow, I'm gonna keep reading these as long as the author keeps writing them...next up, Temeraire (and Will) in exile (including, I think, Australia!!!).......more

title: Olive Kitteridge        (Olive Kitteridge, #1)
author: Strout, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Olive, Olive, Olive….hard one to rate, but decided on 4 stars because the book (actually a collection of related stories [all have Olive in them, someOlive, Olive, Olive….hard one to rate, but decided on 4 stars because the book (actually a collection of related stories [all have Olive in them, some bit parts, some as a major character] written over a period of 15 years or so) is exceedingly well written, but reading it was not a joy. Olive and her family, friends, and neighbors in the small town of Crosby, Maine live “normal” lives. Except … a fairly high number of them have parents who either committed suicide or were otherwise mentally ill, and almost all of the characters are emotionally abusive to their families. And the characters who weren’t, were the abused. I have a grudging affection for Olive – she is a community fixture; retired middle school math teacher, after all, and does often do good things – what I really can’t forgive her is the relentless nastiness she showered on her spouse, who was one of the sweetest characters in the book. Neurotic, yes, but also sweet. Her misguided devotion to her son only served to drive him away from Olive and the town of Crosby.But there is no doubt that Olive’s pain and aching for love and connection hits a nerve. Whether you like her or not, she is you -- especially if you are a middle-aged woman who has experienced some of life’s disappointments and loss.So, I would recommend reading it because it is so well written, but it isn’t an uplifting joy ride. However, I will be thinking about Olive for quite a while, which to me is one of the most important “tells” about whether a reading experience was worthwhile or not....more

review: Just remembered this book after watching the recent (awful, plodding too dark - literally) release of Jane Eyre. One of the most creative ideas I've rJust remembered this book after watching the recent (awful, plodding too dark - literally) release of Jane Eyre. One of the most creative ideas I've run across, ever. The protagonist is a "literary" detective who ends up chasing after a dangerous miscreant who has altered Jane Eyre! He has the ability to enter the pages of the book and mess with it, and he alters the fateful, first meeting of Jane and Rochester.. the horse doesn't fall. Jane doesn't help Rochester up. He goes on back to the homestead (yes, I know it has a proper name, but not coming to me now) and leaves without ever really talking to her. Or something like that. Anyway, Jane Eyre (the book) is ruined, and all the Victorian romance novels that were inspired by JE disappear from literary fiction. Or something like that. (It has been several years since I read it.) Since the literary detectives are fairly low-level in the MI branches (oh yeah, this all takes place in England), our protagonist, Thursday Next [see how clever! see how British!], has to team up with other low-level detectives, such as vampire and werewolf hunters.This is just fun and imaginative and well worth anyone's time. Anyone, that is, if you like Jane Eyre, or have never even read Jane Eyre, but you like creative, playful writers!...more

title: Throne of Jade        (Temeraire, #2)
author: Novik, Naomi*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’m beginning to think of this series as sort of eating M&M’s. That are good for you. I kinda want to give them 5-stars, and maybe I should, but readiI’m beginning to think of this series as sort of eating M&M’s. That are good for you. I kinda want to give them 5-stars, and maybe I should, but reading them tires me in some way. Maybe that is because I stay up late into the wee hours reading them. I really like inserting dragons into history, and this series does it well. But it is much more than just making sense (and fun) of Victorian sensibilities. Actually, the author does a very good job of putting you inside the head of someone who believes dearly in honor, the Crown, and the superiority of British civilization, while having him over time come to the realization that many of these very conventional foundations are rotten. Civil rights for dragons. For women. And he comes to realize that in this book via his exposure to Chinese civilization – which, if my stereotypes hold, was and is not the most favorable toward women…but in this book, women’s rights in China are a byproduct of the Chinese reverence for dragons…so, take it where you can get it.In between the (aerial, as in on the back of dragons in flight) swordfights is political intrigue – the rather obvious plodding politics of Britain in the Victorian age, the more sophisticated politics of the Chinese Emperor’s Court (which are complicated by the related dragon issues, as compared to the British who assume they are superior to dragons, just like they are to everyone and everything else on the planet) play out. (Someday, I’ll figure out a way to express my run-on parenthetical thoughts without destroying the underlying sentence, but obviously, that day is not yet here.)So, enjoyable and a lot of food for thought. Will Laurence, the annoyingly endearing British Naval officer converted to dragon handler, is moving through a lot of evidence to refute his heretofore unassailable belief in everything he has held dear and it will be interesting to see if he will use this knowledge to better the situation of dragons and women in Britain, or at least try. And for his dragon Temeraire, this is a nice if very unusual coming-of-age story….imagine a brilliant mind and adolescence in a 20 ton dragon and you get the idea….but Temeraire has a much clearer view of the world, and it is through his questioning of duty and Crown and everything else that Will is growing beyond what he has always “known” as the truth.I look forward to the other books in the series, but I need a break from dragons for a couple of days…the (necessary) slaughter of many beeves, sheep, and tunnies (tuna) that is required to sustain dragons wears on me. And I’m not even a vegetarian…....more

title: The Architecture of the Arkansas Ozarks
author: Harington, Donald
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don't really know where to start with this one. It was charming, informative (about things that are of little or no interest generally, but become sI don't really know where to start with this one. It was charming, informative (about things that are of little or no interest generally, but become so with this author), playful, snarky, and above all, affectionate in the portrayal of the settlers/citizens of the hamlet of Stay More, Arkansas. (Happily referred to as Stay Morons.) I have to admit to a personal bias here, having been born in northwest Arkansas to a native Arkansan and a DamnYankee (who had only ventured out of the Hudson Valley to attend the University of Arkansas). Although we left for the Hudson Valley when I was very young, I have always had a somewhat romanticized notion of my Ozarks roots, and this book addresses many of my preconceptions. But even without that, this is a gifted author who skillfully (and again, very playfully) recounts a fictional history of the Arkansas Ozarks. The gimmick he uses is to begin each chapter with an example of architecture associated with the characters and history to be covered in that chapter. The point isn't the architecture, other than as it reflects the life and times of the people in this historical (but fictional) narrative.Mr. Harington knows whereof he speaks as an architect (at one point he was on the faculty of the University of Arkansas) and as an observer of human nature. And his chapters all start with a drawing of the architectural example for the chapter.An overlay at the beginning of the book is a quote from Frank Lloyd Wright:"The true basis for any serious study of the art of Architecture still lies in those indigenous, more humble buildings everywhere that are to architecture what folklore is to literature or folk song to music and with which academic architects were seldom concerned....These many folk structures are of the soil, natural. Though often slight, their virtue is intimately related to the environment and to the heartlife of the people. Functions are usually truthfully conceived and rendered invariably with natural feeling. Results are often beautiful and always instructive."A wonderful book that I thought about a lot both while I was reading it and after I finished it. I hope to keep thinking about it for a long time....more

title: The Things a Brother Knows
author: Reinhardt, Dana
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a very well done young adult novel about two brothers, both of whom have been profoundly affected by the older brother unexpectedly joining thThis is a very well done young adult novel about two brothers, both of whom have been profoundly affected by the older brother unexpectedly joining the Marines after graduating from high school. The prose is uncomplicated and straightforward, with a good ear for dialogue. The book begins as the older brother returns home after three years of service in the military, a good deal of which was spent in combat. While unspecified, the desert played a large part, so you can infer where the combat occurred. And you realize it doesn’t matter. Combat changes people forever, whenever and wherever experienced. The characters are well developed, especially the younger brother and his two best friends.As the older brother struggles to come to terms with his experiences, he isolates himself from the world, locking himself in his room for days, refusing to ride in cars (or buses or taxis or trains), and rejecting overtures from his family and old girlfriend. The younger brother desperately wants things to be as they were “before”. The journey (literally and figuratively) to connect with his brother leads to his growing understanding, and finally acceptance, that the past is not recoverable. And the end of the younger brother’s journey provides for the beginning of the older brother’s journey to recovery.Another interesting point of contrast in the book is between this generation's experience of military service and the experience of the parents (and even grandparents) of the brothers. The brothers are modern day young adults, so military service is unevenly distributed across the population, and is very unusual in their middle class suburban existence. When the older brother made the decision to join the Marines, his family and friends were horrified...after all, he had been accepted at Cornell, Columbia and Berkeley. So why was it he joined the Marines? In contrast, the father and grandfather of the brothers were Israeli, and their military experience was culturally universal, one that everyone they knew had experienced. Nonetheless, after emigrating to America and raising a family, they were still dismayed that their older son decided to join the military rather than going off to the university of his choice. But the father and the sons actually talked about the differences in expectations and experiences and how that affected their re-entry (or difficulty in re-entry) into "normal" society.Finally, like many YA novels, it is also a quick read, and that helped me like it even more…....more

title: The Reversal        (The Lincoln Lawyer, #3; Harry Bosch Universe, #22)
author: Connelly, Michael*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: As much as I love Michael Connelly's writings, this one didn't hit the spot for me. It is so comfortable to read his stuff that it partially makes up As much as I love Michael Connelly's writings, this one didn't hit the spot for me. It is so comfortable to read his stuff that it partially makes up for some of the shortcomings. This book features a (relatively) new character, Mickey Haller, a defense attorney. (Haller is first introduced in The Lincoln Lawyer, which is evidently about to be released as a movie with, someone please save us, Matthew McConaughey as Haller. That, in and of itself, is enough reason for me not to see it...and I'm not a particularly discriminating movie-goer, as evidenced by the fact that I intend to see I Am Number Four tomorrow.) Sheesh. Back to the book.The story is tidy, well-laid out, and moves quickly to a reasonably satisfying conclusion. The real problem is that I don’t find Haller a particularly interesting or compelling character. Connelly’s Harry Bosch, however, is both. And he is also in this story, which only serves to make Haller even less interesting than he is.The plot explores the interesting games that defense lawyers and district attorneys play in their respective parts in delivering “justice”. And, just like a lot of Law and Order shows, justice is subverted by the complexities of real life and real people and real problems. Luckily, Connelly’s villain deserves everything coming to him – but it certainly doesn’t happen because of the trial process. I really like Connelly’s clean expository style (if memory serves, he was an LA Times reporter before he started writing full time). Anyway, an easy read, and satisfying – just not the best that Connelly has produced in the past with Harry Bosch. (I do have to acknowledge I almost gave up on Harry Bosch in Connelly’s last book – “Nine Dragons”, I think – because his self-destructive tendencies caused hideous collateral damage.. while his behavior often creates havoc, but it was to an extreme that made me a bit ill in that book.)...more

title: Moonlight Mile        (Kenzie & Gennaro, #6)
author: Lehane, Dennis*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This twelve-years-later sequel to “Gone Baby Gone” seems to be Lehane’s attempt to bring to some sort of more satisfying resolution to Amanda McCreadyThis twelve-years-later sequel to “Gone Baby Gone” seems to be Lehane’s attempt to bring to some sort of more satisfying resolution to Amanda McCready’s (the ‘Baby’ of GBG) life than how he left it at the end of GBG. The ending of that novel/movie was when his protagonist made an awful choice between two options (bad and much worse – he picked much worse) by returning four-year-old Amanda to her skank of a mother after taking her from a wonderful couple (that, it has to be noted, had kidnapped Amanda) who loved her and were raising her with love, affection, and stability -- circumstances her mother was notably unable to provide. Lehane is an incredibly skilled author – he specializes in exploring the uncomfortable seam between our system of justice and justice itself – and if you think they are remotely related, you haven’t read Lehane. His protagonist, Patrick Kenzie, is a “good” man who leaves a trail of grief and havoc wherever he ventures. Anyway, now-sixteen-year-old Amanda has disappeared again, and Patrick once again goes in search. In this search, he introduces his usual cast of thugs and psychos, some of whom are also “good” guys – a Russian hitman, who’d a thunk it? – and truly bad guys, who are often people in authority in various bureaucracies – cops, social workers, etc.I don’t know if Lehane takes all readers out of their comfort zones. He certainly does me. And while I rated this a four-star – as much for sentimental reasons about Amanda’s resolution as his skill, I do have to confess I am getting a bit tired with the “my Boston thugs are way tougher, meaner, more psychotic than your thugs”. Not to mention the unbelieveable skanks (I really don’t use that word a lot); maybe I saw this too soon after “The Fighter” which brought to the screen true skankiness in the form of the mother and the seven sisters of the titular hero. And again, from Boston (OK, Lowell, but close enough)….So, if you like Lehane and you can deal with his unrelenting violence, read this. Especially if you always wondered what happened to Amanda after she was returned to sweet Helene of Dorchester…...more

title: The Lost Gate        (Mither Mages, #1)
author: Card, Orson Scott
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Orson Scott Card is a very good writer. The man can tell a story. And one of the things he does best is coming-of-age stories, especially with adolescOrson Scott Card is a very good writer. The man can tell a story. And one of the things he does best is coming-of-age stories, especially with adolescent misfits as the protagonists. “The Lost Gate” has such a misfit, Danny North. Danny is the only kid in his village who can’t do magic. He is smart and athletic and funny, but he can’t do the simplest magic. Sadly for Danny, magic is not only the most valued skill, but also the ticket to success and status in his community. So Danny feels pretty sorry for himself until one day he figures out he CAN do magic – unfortunately, it is the one kind of magic that is forbidden; and they aren’t kidding around. If his elders discover he can do this particular kind of magic, he will have to be killed. So, of course, he is discovered and has to flee. And thus the story begins.I wasn’t as stunned by this book as I was by “Ender’s Game”, but not much has the kind of impact that book had. And I like that Card is developing this as a basis for a series – not dependent trilogies, but books you can read and not be pissed off because it ends in a cliff hanger.If you like fantasy, this is a nice easy, fairly quick read. And Card has a real ear for dialog, especially adolescent patter. And snark.Warning: maybe it was just me, but I did get a bit confused in the last third of the book when Danny’s skills are advancing so quickly I had trouble keeping up…but I think a lot of this is laying the groundwork for subsequent books in a “Mithermages” series. So it will be more familiar next time around. And I will be reading them....more

review: I wanted to really love this book, but I didn’t - quite. I did really like it, but I got bogged down at times, often for the good reason that the writI wanted to really love this book, but I didn’t - quite. I did really like it, but I got bogged down at times, often for the good reason that the writing was so amazing that I had to slow down and let it roll around in my brain for a while. I read it many years ago and had appreciated it as a sad, sweet fairy tale. It is that, but the writing is remarkable. Lyrical, funny, tender, and often heart-breaking. Some samples:“…the tiny, dry sound of a spider weeping…”“…but the coincidence trailed down (his) spine like wet seaweed…”“When you are old, anything that does not disturb you is a comfort. Cold and darkness and boredom long ago lost their sharp edges for us, but warmth, singing, spring – no, they would all be disturbances..”--The skull gave a rattling chuckle. “I’ve been up on this pillar a long time,” it said. “I was Haggard’s chief henchman once, until he smote off my head for no reason. That was back in the days when he was being wicked to see if that was what he really liked to do. It wasn’t, but he thought he might as well get some use out of my head, so he stuck it up here to serve as his sentinel. Under the circumstances, I’m not as loyal to King Haggard as I might be.”So… all told, witches and princes and magic, oh my! Enjoy....more

title: Fall of Giants        (The Century Trilogy, #1)
author: Follett, Ken*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A disappointment. I was so taken with The Pillars of the Earth, I really looked forward to this book. However, this has a real paint-by-numbers feel aA disappointment. I was so taken with The Pillars of the Earth, I really looked forward to this book. However, this has a real paint-by-numbers feel and while reading it was a notch above reading my high school history tomes, it wasn't by much. It was sort of interesting to have characters inserted into World War I events (pre- and a tiny bit post-), but it still felt like plodding through a textbook. And the Russian Revolution. Sheesh. What a bunch of ideological/philosophical claptrap... it reminded me of the worst of Kim Stanley Robinson's lecturing on not just forms of government but the actual forming of government in the Red/Green/Blue Mars trilogy. Whether or not you agree or disagree with Robinson's world view, I found it hard to appreciate 50 pages of dialog of actual floor debates. And now to my disappointment, Follett does the same thing with the Bolsheviks, the Mensheviks, the revolutionaries, the counter-revolutionaries, the Reds, the Whites.... I have a headache. Important issues of justice and civil liberties turned into an absolute bore.Nevertheless, I do feel I understand the whys and wherefores of WWI in much greater depth than I did before. And I can really appreciate the citation for bravery that my grandfather earned in France in 1917-1918 (signed by Pershing, no less). What a nightmare those never-ending battles were. So, while I can't recommend this book unless you are looking for a way to avoid reading an actual history text, I am glad I read it. And I'm really glad I'm done.As always, historical fiction is much easier to digest than straight history....more

title: The Passage        (The Passage, #1)
author: Cronin, Justin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Again, WTF? Why does this keep happening? I write a , and it disappears!!! Every time this happens, I think "bye bye" Goodreads. It's not like IAgain, WTF? Why does this keep happening? I write a , and it disappears!!! Every time this happens, I think "bye bye" Goodreads. It's not like I have such wonderful things to say that the world will be a lesser place without my s, it's just that same feeling you get when you forget to save a document and the power goes out..So, I'll try one more time.I must be the only person in North America who didn't know this was Part 1 of a trilogy. After slogging through 766 pages, there is this nonconclusive series of depressing events that happen to several of the main protagonists on the last few pages. Now I know they are cliffhangers...sheesh! However, I am a fan of post-apocalyptic survival stories (especially when we have done the damage to ourselves) and this is certainly that. And while I love sci-fi and mindless thrillers, I don't like horror, and this verges into that territory with the creatures (called smokes by the civilian survivors, and dracs by the military survivors) that prey upon our intrepid heroes and heroines. I DO love the geeky detail of surviving -- how will we keep the lights on, folks (and lights are VERY important to survival in this book)? The reason for the survival colony being near San Gorgonio Pass is that's where all those wind turbines are, and they keep on trucking (not without significant maintenance, mind you, but nonetheless). But OMG! Those batteries are not very good at holding a charge after 100 years, so a contingent of our plucky survivors must head out on a cross country journey where they will be snacked on by the smokes/dracs and have many, many close calls and assorted adventures!! My favorite character is Michael, a mechanical/electrical/computer programming genius, affectionately nicknamed "Circuit" by the civilian survivors, and "Lugnut" by the miltary guys. Turns out he prefers "Lugnut" to "Circuit". Who knew?Also, this is being marketed as a vampire book. And while the creatures certainly have some "classic" vampire qualities - fangs, sunlight kills them [into smoke - get it???] -- they seem more like (fast) zombies. And I really don't like zombies. Or reading about them, or watching movies with them. Vampires, sometimes yes. If they are witty and cultured... And no, I don't mean Twilight. I don't think much of sensitive vampires with teenage angst.So if I had known this was part 1 of a trilogy and about vampires, I probably wouldn't have picked it up. But it was a decent read, and I will read parts 2/3 but only after they both come out....more

title: Why the Devil Chose New England for His Work
author: Brown, Jason*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I had a really hard time with this book. The writing is truly amazing, from a literary/craftsman point of view. But reading it was a very unpleasant eI had a really hard time with this book. The writing is truly amazing, from a literary/craftsman point of view. But reading it was a very unpleasant experience. If Stephen King's descriptions of Maine don't keep you away, try this book. I don't mean to compare the two authors because they couldn't be more different, not just in terms of skill, but King is so ham-handed and brutal, and Brown is so elegant, spare and haunting. And yet. Truly a hatchet job on Maine. Or any other cold and harsh environments, populated by people in poverty (of spirit as much as of money) and hard luck. What's that old joke -- if it weren't for bad luck, I'd have no luck at all?The horrors in this book are about quiet desperate lives being lived on the margins of nowhere. No hope. And glimmers of hope are crushed, making you sorry you ever had the temerity to hope. Kids falling through the ice in winter and drowning. Lissome teenagers implying unwanted sexual attention from adults, who are then shunned or killed. And it is never clear what is real and what is not.I have a similar complaint about Joan Didion -- exquisite prose squandered on bleakness. ...more

title: Arthur Rex
author: Berger, Thomas
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was an interesting approach, but ultimately, it wore thin for me. Berger is probably best known for Little Big Man, and his cynicism shines brighThis was an interesting approach, but ultimately, it wore thin for me. Berger is probably best known for Little Big Man, and his cynicism shines brightly in this send-up of the King Arthur legend. The problem for me was that while each page was in and of itself hilarious, the literary and historical references demonstrated for me that while my education was good enough to recognize that they were in fact references, my education was not good enough to appreciate them without a little digging/research. I like a good King Arthur story (for me by far the best take is the trilogy by Jo Walton, starting with The King's Peace -- the best of the trilogy) as much as the next person, or more than about 95 out of 100 persons, but clearly there are those who must be into it WAY more than I am (that 5% is INTENSE about their Arthur).At any rate, as I said, each page shines. It is the totality that wore me out. In fact, I didn't finish the book, and that almost never happens. I'm pretty compulsive about finishing books. Reading it reminded me of why the SNL linked movies almost never work...a good/hilarious 5 minute skit, even as a running gag over the years, just doesn't hold up for a 90 minute span....more

title: The Private Diary of Mr. Darcy
author: Slater, Maya
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Loved the idea. Reading it, not so much. For those of you who adore Jane Austen and/or Pride and Prejudice (I adore Colin Firth and Matthew Macfadyen,Loved the idea. Reading it, not so much. For those of you who adore Jane Austen and/or Pride and Prejudice (I adore Colin Firth and Matthew Macfadyen, not so much Austen) you might get a kick out of this. The novel purports to be the diary of Mr. Darcy during the same time period that the events of Pride and Prejudice unfold. The guy's point of view, as it were.Unfortunately, it brings to life in excruciating detail, the point that Mr. Darcy is a bore. First an arrogant bore, then a sympathetic bore. And Lord Byron is a real a-hole. Passionate, funny, misogynistic, slovenly, self-absorbed. Not someone you would want to spend time with, especially if you are female, or a young boy.And sadly, while I enjoyed Pride and Prejudice, there were aspects of it that bothered me a lot. This book brings all of those warts forward without the charm. Even understanding that P & P was written in class-riven 18th century England, I still had trouble with the relationships between the landed gentry (poor and wealthy alike) and their servants. This book reflected those sensibilities, consistent with P & P. Example -- Mr. Darcy, spending some time at Lord Byron's, has difficulties because his own valet was injured and unable to accompany him to Byron's, and Mr. Darcy was crippled in performing his toilette because no one brought him hot water and he (gasp) had to dress himself without assistance. (Note: Byron has servants, but they perform services of a much more personal nature than getting dressed, if you get my drift....)Anyway, I really liked the concept, but I kept waiting to be entertained. And I wasn't....more

review: In some ways this sequel was better than the first, the Girl With the Dragon Tattoo. I think the plot was less cluttered, and more fast paced. But I fIn some ways this sequel was better than the first, the Girl With the Dragon Tattoo. I think the plot was less cluttered, and more fast paced. But I found myself annoyed at the author's penchant for brand names and specifications for all of the toys his protagonists use. I don't really need to know what the make and model computer, car, Ikea specifications, etc etc. In fact, the technology specifications in particular make the book seem dated. Written in 2003 or so, the exponential growth in technology over the last 7 years really screams out at some points, whereas if he had just made more generic references, it might not leap out so much. That said, this book is a great read, and it was probably a good choice to be my first "Kindle" book. I will definitely be going back and forth between electronic reader and hard cover books, if for no other reason than the library is free. However, I did adapt pretty quickly. I'd say after no more than a third of the way through the book I was pretty unaware of the switch. If you liked Girl With the Dragon Tattoo (and see the movie if you liked the book), you'll like The Girl Who Played with Fire. Lisbeth Salander is one of the most interesting protagonists you will ever run across....more

title: Nobody's Fool        (Sully #1)
author: Russo, Richard*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I probably had a soft spot for this book even before reading it, because the film of the same name (starring Paul Newman as Sully) was filmed in my liI probably had a soft spot for this book even before reading it, because the film of the same name (starring Paul Newman as Sully) was filmed in my little hometown Beacon in upstate New York. Wonderful movie, wonderful book.Russo can write. His prose is full of biting wit and clear-eyed development of tragically flawed yet sympathetic characters, such as the aforementioned Sully. And it rings true to my memory of the people I grew up with in that town. The retired 80 year old school teacher (8th grade English), Beryl Peoples, reminiscing at one point about her former students ("the militantly unteachable") and her deceased husband ("Clive Sr. had not been a profoundly stupid man, but he missed his fair share of what Miss Beryl referred to as life's nuances...").. She also understands herself well, and acknowledges to herself [heaven forbid, not to others:] that she has learned to trust her own judgment by questioning others' judgments..And Sully. What a wonderful character. I think I would have loved him even without seeing Paul Newman in my mind's eye. He is charming and obnoxious. Hard-working and a true screwup. He is also Miss Beryl's tenant, much to the chagrin of her own son, who has always been threatened by Sully and has grand designs on Miss Beryl's house, if he can only get her out of it. The heart of the book and movie is the relationship between these two unlikely, but true friends. They have honest respect and affection for each other and it shines like a new penny.This is not plot-driven prose. While there is a plot, it meanders to a non-conclusive conclusion. You read this book for the characters and the elegance of the writing.I cannot imagine that anyone reading the first 10-20 pages of the book not being captivated by it.So read it, already!!...more

title: The Lost City of Z: A Tale of Deadly Obsession in the Amazon
author: Grann, David*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: An interesting armchair read of a real search for a missing Victorian explorer. The search was recent (2005), the disappearance was in 1925. In my youAn interesting armchair read of a real search for a missing Victorian explorer. The search was recent (2005), the disappearance was in 1925. In my youth, I relished a kind of "literature" that included Conan Doyle's "The Lost World", much of Jules Verne's stuff, and the Tarzan and Mars books by Edgar Rice Burroughs. Well, Percy Harrison Fawcett (and if that doesn't scream Victorian gentleman to you, you probably have no idea what I'm talking about...) was a REAL Victorian explorer who became obsessed with finding "The Lost City of Z" - better known as El Dorado in Amazonia. On his umpteenth trip in 1925, he disappeared, along with his son and a friend of his son's. It was quite the media sensation at the time, since he had been sending regular dispatches, that just... stopped. The author, a writer for the New Yorker, became interested in the story and went on his own quest. Part of the book is his own growing obsession, and his absolute incompetence in undertaking this pursuit. (He comments that at an REI store, the clerk who was helping him sort through the possible offerings, ventured to guess that "you've never been camping, have you?") The book is also an interesting compendium of the horrors one could suffer in this kind of exploration -- the pestilence, the possible accidents one can have while wielding a machete, the critters, and starvation in the most life-filled places on earth; all serving to reinforce my preferred status of armchair exploring. My only reason for not giving this 5 stars is my own preference for tauter, plot-drive novels. However, this isn't that kind of a book, and perhaps the meandering is not only understandable, but necessary, for the telling of the tale. I think anyone who has ever dreamed of exploring would enjoy the book. I did....more

Better to quote from a couple of s:"Jandy Nelson has cast the intensity of first love together with the intensity of grief to produce a novel that is unusually rich with both insight and breathless romance. She writes with abandon, setting her characters free to live their excesses.." - LA Times"Nearly everyone who's staggered through life in the wake of a loved one's death will recognize themselves in this brilliant, piercing story. It's a warm, deeply honest story that resonates with truth." - Denver Post“Buoyantly written and brimming with humor and life as it plumbs the depths and ambiguities of grief, full of music and the poems Lennie drops all over town, The Sky Is Everywhere explores betrayal and forgiveness through a vibrant cast of characters.” —School Library JournalPlease read this book....more

This one is also steeped in the crumbling of the British social classes pI've never developed an appreciation for psychological horror/ghost stories. However, it left me disappointed in the same way that I (vaguely) recall from reading The Turn of the Screw many years ago. Creepy atmospherics, lots of little suspenseful moments that build to .... nothing. Wandering around in (overly) extensive narrative exposition and with a narrator that makes it impossible to discern if the characters (including the most impressive character, the country estate "Hundreds Hall") are truly haunted or just descending into the delusions of mental illness. title: The First Rule        (Elvis Cole, #13; Joe Pike, #2)
author: Crais, Robert
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Robert Crais writes very well. It's not hard to believe that he started out as a scriptwriter because his writing seems ready-made for filming. Clean Robert Crais writes very well. It's not hard to believe that he started out as a scriptwriter because his writing seems ready-made for filming. Clean straightforward prose. However, what I like about his books are his two main characters, Elvis Cole and Joe Pike. This book is a Joe Pike novel, with Elvis thrown in as his handy sidekick. If you are into doing what's "right" regardless of body counts, Joe Pike is the guy you want on your side. He is a bit of a parody when first encountered in Crais' earlier works that feature Elvis Cole as the protagonist, and Joe Pike "helps" Elvis provide for justice, mainly in LA, amusing as that sounds. This is the second book that focuses on Pike and makes him more three-dimensional. Not really, more like two and a quarter dimensional. And Crais' previous book about Pike, The Watchman, did it better. Nonetheless, Crais writes a good page turner -- this one is about very bad people from Eastern Europe who learned their craft in places like Odessa and Bosnia.I also appreciated the fact that he dedicated this book to Harlan Ellison, who is a science fiction writer that has turned out some wonderful stuff. Crais also lists some other folks by first name who are clearly science fiction writers also. I thought I had read a while back that Crais did some writing for Star Trek (Next Generations era, one of my favorite series), but I couldn't turn that up in quick internet search. Anyway, read this stuff is you like detective novels and if you like detectives with great wise-cracking humor, pick up the Elvis Cole books and start at the beginning with The Monkey's Raincoat....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Good Arthur tale, but I expected a bit more. Everything I've read by this author so far has been exceptional. He covers British history, especially miGood Arthur tale, but I expected a bit more. Everything I've read by this author so far has been exceptional. He covers British history, especially military history, but weaves real events into stories of (mostly) fictional characters that are used to advance the story and create a context for the historical events. And I really like historical fiction. This is the first of a trilogy and I will probably read the other two just because I like this author and I love knights, Camelot, Lancelot (boy does he savage Lancelot in this retelling), etc. And as usual, his battle scenes are very well done. He puts you into the strategic and tactical framework of battles which makes them really interesting.So, if you really like Arthur, I'd recommend this book. But a better and more interesting version is by Jo Walton, "A King's Peace". She weaves in the magic that was Avalon in a much more interesting way of comparing/contrasting the pagan/Christian tussles that are important in framing this period of history. Arthur may or may not have existed, but the clash between pagans and Christians as well as the friction between "true" ancient Britons and all the hordes overrunning what became England is definitely true....more
