review: Melancholy but lyrical prose. This author can make you feel his pain. And even if your life experiences are different than what his characters go throMelancholy but lyrical prose. This author can make you feel his pain. And even if your life experiences are different than what his characters go through, you can easily identify with their hurts, their anguish, and their passion. Or lack thereof. Several friends have recommended Russo to me over the years, and I finally got around to it. This won't be the last. I'm especially looking forward to Nobody's Fool, which was one of my favorite movies (admittedly, Paul Newman and the locale being the town I grew up in were big selling points). In this book Jack Griffin, a college professor is grappling with his disappointments in life and through the device of visiting Cape Cod (which was the setting for explaining his early childhood experiences that set him on a path to sure disappointment) for two very different weddings a year apart, he begins to sort out his life. review: I love Michael Connelly and I have always liked Harry Bosch, the LA homicide detective he has featured in many of his novels. However, in this one, I I love Michael Connelly and I have always liked Harry Bosch, the LA homicide detective he has featured in many of his novels. However, in this one, I lost my patience with good old Harry. He has always had his inner demons -- part of what makes him such an interesting character -- but in this novel, his inability to control his inner demons has made him someone I don't want to visit anymore. Bad things happen. Bad enough I can't write it off to human foibles anymore. So...I guess I'll see if I read the next one featuring Harry, if there is one.Nonetheless, the writing is consistent with Connelly's high standards -- good, clean expository style that leads you through the plot without giving too much away too early. my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I enjoyed this book and it was an easy read...just what the doctor ordered. That said, I was a bit disappointed about the lack of new ground this bookI enjoyed this book and it was an easy read...just what the doctor ordered. That said, I was a bit disappointed about the lack of new ground this book covered, given the topic was based on the Salem witch trials and the author's personal history. Or, as noted in the coverleaf, she is "a descendant of Elizabeth Proctor, who survived the Salem witch trials, and Elizabeth Howe, who did not."But, like most Americans, I am drawn to the Salem witch trials because they seem so bizarre in a modern-day context. This book helps put pieces together about how it might have happened, but not much here that wasn't in the Crucible, or other literary/historical efforts.It is pretty impressive for a first novel, but it may well be a tough act to follow for the author, since she drew so heavily from her own personal history and her academic pursuits. But I will be looking forward to her next book....more

title: Ha'penny        (Small Change, #2)

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a sequel to Walton's book, Farthing. No murder mystery here, just a thriller about a potential assassination in which you aren't sure who to rThis is a sequel to Walton's book, Farthing. No murder mystery here, just a thriller about a potential assassination in which you aren't sure who to root for or against. This book, like Farthing, is set in post WW2, where England and Hitler reached an agreement to co-exist and the USA never entered the war (under President Lindbergh...).The truly creepy, scary stuff in this book is not about the potential assassination. Rather, it is in watching England becoming more and more Fascist under its own government. So help me, you are rooting for Stalin and the ocmmunists, who are the only ones still trying to take Hitler out.I heartily recommend this book -- it is different, and I have nothing but awe for this author. She writes across genres and histories, real and alternate, in a compelling manner. While the faux King Arthur tales were fairly difficult to get through because of the density of the material, this book and its predecessor are relatively easy reads.Enjoy! ...more

I did enjoy listening as much as I did reading it, but I'm not sure what I would have gotten out of it if I hadn't already read it. This approach was a lighter experience, but still very touching and funny.Listen or read it. Just do one or the other....______________________________________________________________(This is original  from 2009)Very Craig-like. Funny, witty and profane. All other characters are pretty one-dimensional, just there for plot advancement. Anyway, I don't mind empty calories and could have liked this a lot more, but it ended as a @#$ cliff-hanger! I just wasn't prepared for it to be a cliff-hanger, and I was really ticked off at the end of the book. Sucker that I am, I read the next one, Ask The Parrot, which picks up where this left off, but it too ends without resolution. title: Farthing        (Small Change, #1)
author: Walton, Jo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book has several components. First, it is a murder mystery -- a genre I enjoy, but this is a type of murder mystery I usually don't care for - thThis book has several components. First, it is a murder mystery -- a genre I enjoy, but this is a type of murder mystery I usually don't care for - the English countryside murder mystery a la Agatha Christie. I normally find this type to be too cerebral and talky and overly complicated as to motive, etc.However, this is not only a well done murder mystery of that type, it is much, much more. Set in a 1949 England that is not my grandfather's 1949 England, but rather an England that reached a peace accord with Hitler rather than defeating him. England is free, but Europe has been incorporated into the Third Reich. The Soviets are still fighting Hitler and the United States never got involved.This is a truly frightening book, and Jo Walton has come up with a cautionary tale that will give me nightmares for some time to come.This author has a mind and a creativity that know no boundaries...I fell in love with her first books which were a re-telling on the Athurian legends in an alternate reality. Then she wrote Tooth and Claw which I still think about and giggle -- a Victorian society of dragons...Now this. Read her stuff, buy her books. I want her to keep writing!!!...more

review: If you like good mindless action reads, James Rollins fills the bill. His characters, while still pretty two-dimensional, are getting better as he wriIf you like good mindless action reads, James Rollins fills the bill. His characters, while still pretty two-dimensional, are getting better as he writes more. If you like Indiana Jones type action, you'd enjoy this (and his previous books also). Real page-turners, usually has three or four subplots going, all built to come together in rip-roaring finishes.If you need literature, this probably isn't it. I discovered him a while ago when he got a plug from local er because he was a homeboy - another facet that appeals to me is that he is a Sacramento veterinarian, real name James Czajkowski (although now that he's hit NT Times best seller lists, I don't think he has an active practice anymore).This particular book features autistic children as a crucial element of his plot. In part, he was inspired by his admiration of Temple Grandin, a reasonably famous autistic adult who is an author and animal behavorist.I've read s of his work in which he has been favorably compared to Clive Cussler. I've not read any of Cussler's stuff so I can't say. I WOULD compare him favorably however, to Michael Crichton. He uses a similar technique in that he takes his scientific training and extrapolates into "what if" scenarios based on recent scientific breakthroughs.Finally, this is the rare book that I actually purchased instead of borrowing from the library, so if any of my friends reading this want to borrow it, I'm happy to lend it to you....more

title: The Help
author: Stockett, Kathryn*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a book I would have been unlikely to pick out to read, but a friend loaned it to me because she thought I would like it. I did. Set in JacksonThis is a book I would have been unlikely to pick out to read, but a friend loaned it to me because she thought I would like it. I did. Set in Jackson, Mississippi, in the early 60's, there are parallels to books such as "The Secret Life of Bees".Written in the voices of three women, one young white woman recently graduated from college and two black maids (or, "the help") who undertake a courageous project to write a book telling the stories of black women who raise white women's children and keep their households which allows for Southern gracious living. The cross currents of love and hate in the same relationships are pretty believeable, and difficult and uncomfortable as a reader imagining the discomfort of the women who actually lived these lives.There is also a lot of tension as this undertaking is a secret and dangerous activity for all involved, but most especially the black women.I found my self thinking about the book and its issues and read it very quickly. Easy to read and thought-provoking, I would recommend this to anyone interested in our history, especially in the civil rights era....more

review: Definitely different from the Joy Luck Club and the Bonesetter's Daughter. The narrator of this book is a ghost who was to lead a group of 12 of her fDefinitely different from the Joy Luck Club and the Bonesetter's Daughter. The narrator of this book is a ghost who was to lead a group of 12 of her friends on a tour of Burma/Myanmar. The tour goes on without her after her mysterious death and considerable mishaps occur. I really do like Tan's writing. She is very clever and observant and a master of ironic juxtoposition (sp?). However, I was very uneasy reading this book because although the cultural misunderstandings were funny, they also led to situations which could, and did, have horrific consequences. Not as horrific as I was imagining as I read along, but horrific nonetheless.She affectionately lampoons the political correctness of this group, who are as clueless as they are well-intentioned. She forces you to look at yourself and your own foibles through the development of these characters.A nice read, but didn't hold together for me -- in particular, the ending felt like she just ran out of time or got bored with the story....more

title: Year of Wonders
author: Brooks, Geraldine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is another wonderful Geraldine Brooks book. She is the master of historical fiction. Year of Wonders is about the "Plague Village" in England in This is another wonderful Geraldine Brooks book. She is the master of historical fiction. Year of Wonders is about the "Plague Village" in England in the year 1666. Based on true events, this village chose to quarantine itself when some of its members came down with Bubonic Plague. Predictable events ensue. I continue to marvel at the author's ability to recreate horrifying events with an unflinching eye, yet to remind ourselves about what it means to be human. She evokes remarkably authentic voices and puts you in the middle of events as they unfold. My only (tiny) complaint is that the ending to this book, similar to the other two novels I've read that were written by her, feels a bit abrupt -- as though she got tired of writing and wrapped it up a bit too quickly. This is, however, a TINY gripe.I would recommend this book to anyone who likes historical fiction, descriptions of the treatment of women in the middle ages, early medicine and its limitations (not to mention dangers and horrors), and/or a plain good read. I liked "March" a bit more than this book, but it may be because I find the Civil War intrinsically more interesting than the Plague.Read it and enjoy!!...more

title: The King's Peace        (Tir Tanagiri, #1)
author: Walton, Jo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really, really liked this book. However, I am reluctant to recommend it to anyone because it was NOT an easy read. It is an alternative telling of tI really, really liked this book. However, I am reluctant to recommend it to anyone because it was NOT an easy read. It is an alternative telling of the legend of King Arthur, complete with Welsh nomenclature, such as the term "caer" for identifying cities/town, e.g. Caer Sacramento, and the naming of people after their fathers with the "ap" form, e.g. Glee "ap Stanley". Plus the story breaks several conventions with the "traditional" Arthurian lengends. So for a long time reading the book, it felt just a little "off" as my brain tried to translate...e.g. "Isarnagan" is this world's term for Ireland, "Vincans" are Romans etc. It is both rich and dense at once -- somewhat like reading Lord of the Rings -- you just have to adapt to the nomenclature to get into it.That being said, it is a fascinating world, and describes the conflicts and efforts of King Urdo (Arthur) to reconcile two cultures -- early Christianity with a variety of well-established paganism, all of which are very rooted in the physical aspects of the land.If you are a sucker for Arthurian legend, early (roughly 6th century) English history, and the military aspects of early greathorse cavalaries, this is your book. If not, probably not your book. I am eagerly awaiting the second in this series to show up at Belle Coolidge for my checkout........more

title: Dreams from My Father: A Story of Race and Inheritance
author: Obama, Barack*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a really hard one. There are aspects of this book that clearly deserve 5 stars, and others not so much. Roughly speaking, the book consists ofThis is a really hard one. There are aspects of this book that clearly deserve 5 stars, and others not so much. Roughly speaking, the book consists of three parts: (1) childhood in Hawaii and Indonesia and back to Hawaii, (2) as a community organizer in Chicago, and (3) looking for roots in Kenya. I liked the first part, was bored and irritated through much of the second part, and absolutely transported by the third part.In the first part, Obama describes becoming slowly aware of his “otherness”. What I found intriguing about it was that I believe that he is relating a much more universal experience in that virtually all of us come through our childhoods certain that we “don’t fit in”, or that we are awkward, or lacking in some way. To me, that is everyone’s story – the reason for that it is the “all about me” perspective for those pre-adult formative years. It is only with the gift of hindsight that you can see what things probably really looked like from a view somewhat larger than what is in front of your own nose.The second part was heart-breaking but oddly tedious. I think the points that he was trying to make about what might or might not shape a community, especially as seen from the black, African-American experience, were so cerebral as to lose much of the meaning. Maybe I had trouble with it because I am not black, but I think as a woman I know some of the underlying fear that is a constant presence in situations that might or might not be threatening…usually involving moderate to large amounts of testosterone…But the third part was lyrical and heart-breaking. The description of his travels in Kenya to meet his cousins, half-siblings (of which there are many), aunts, uncles, and the ultimate discovery of who his father was and what had shaped him was incredibly poignant. I would recommend this book to anyone who would like to know more about this man who is carrying so much on his shoulders for our country – our expectations, his personal history, and our future are all put into some perspective that will be new to you after reading this book....more

title: The Wordy Shipmates
author: Vowell, Sarah
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm really torn about how to rate this book. I love the way Sarah Vowell writes -- snarky enlightenment. Her research/scholarship is only exceeded by I'm really torn about how to rate this book. I love the way Sarah Vowell writes -- snarky enlightenment. Her research/scholarship is only exceeded by her ability to recast weighty events into Valley Girl speak. This book is about pilgrims, not THE Mayflower ones but the arguably more important ones, the 1630 Arbella contingent that settled Boston and was led by John Winthrop. A typical Vowell rendering of one of the sendoff speeches by the reverend John Cotton: "Cotton's sermon is titled 'God's Promise to His Plantation'. He begins with one of the loveliest passages from the book of Second Samuel, an otherwise R-rated chronicle of King David's serial killer years. Chapter 7, verse 10: 'I will appoint a place for my people Israel, and I will plant them, that they may dwell in a place of their own, and move no more'. Sounds so homey, like that column in the real estate section of the New York Times about how people found their apartments. Until I remember that talk like this is the match still lighting the fuses of a thousand car bombs." See what I mean about her writing? And this is from page 2.The problem I'm having is that she is essentially writing a column or a long essay (sort of New Yorker length) but goes on for 250 pages. I sit there and am enlightened and laughing out loud, but the 15th time it begins to wear. It is somewhat like watching one of your very favorite half-hour TV sitcoms that has been "brought to the big screen". Imagine if they'd tried to make a movie out of Cheers. Or more on point, Seinfeld. But this is comedy combined with Masterpiece Theater and the (good parts of) History Channel.Anyway, I'd recommend it and dare you not to laugh out loud and then feel ashamed of yourself.Vowell is really good, but overall this kept feeling like a dozen or more columns strung together making mostly the same points, but each one wonderful....the sum was less than the whole of its parts, I guess I'd have to say.There's a lot of fascinating stuff in here -- she is a wonderful researcher and brings you along to the musty library reading rooms with their devoted librarians and the treasures they guard. Not to mention the cheesy motels in Plymouth with the Mayflower replicas, complete with the water slide out of the hold into the motel pool....and a truly hilarious encounter between her nephew (who seems quite a bit like Sarah herself) and a "Pilgrim Archie Bunker" - one of those role players in the "authentic" village recreations...Her writing is incredibly informative and laugh out loud funny/tragic.I don't usually go on at such length, but I wanted to share my dilemma with the book......more

review: I'm beginning to think Geraldine Brooks can write about anything. This book is harrowing, but ultimately a rewarding experience about knowing yourselfI'm beginning to think Geraldine Brooks can write about anything. This book is harrowing, but ultimately a rewarding experience about knowing yourself and accepting yourself, including your limitations. The "March" of the title is Mr. March (who may or may not have a first name...), the father of the girls in "Little Women", and was based somewhat on Louisa May Alcott's real father, Bronson Alcott.As in all books that touch on the horrors of the Civil War and the conditions of slavery, some of the reading is very difficult to get through. The author brings the carnage and damage (both physical and spiritual) up close and personal. But the journey is worth it.I have to admit as much of my awe is for the author's ability to write about such different topics with so much authority and background knowledge. Her "Nine Parts of Desire" explained to me the situation of Islamic women better than anything else I've read, including "Reading Lolita in Tehran" which seemed to be the MUST read for a while. "The People of the Book", about the Sarajevo Haggadah, covered medieval through current European/Ottoman history, while throwing in Australian art for kicks...I can hardly wait to read her other novel "Year of Wonders", which by all accounts is the best of her work......more

review: Was supposed to be the third book of a trilogy. This series isn't really a break, since the names, places, etc are all complicated and in different languages. It is "Lord of the Rings" lite, and a reasonable read. I enjoyed the first book, Eragon, liked the second a little less, and this one the least....seems to be a pattern here. While this was a pretty easy read, it did get tedious, and I had trouble finishing. But I did. If you have teenagers who enjoy this kind of thing (e.g. The Golden Compass, etc), they'd probably enjoy this series. If not, let it go because these are LONG books.......more

title: Agincourt
author: Cornwell, Bernard*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I really enjoyed this book more than I thought I would. Historical fiction of the first order -- Agincourt was the famous battle in 1415 in France wheI really enjoyed this book more than I thought I would. Historical fiction of the first order -- Agincourt was the famous battle in 1415 in France when King Henry V of England decided he was the King of France as well as England. The French were of another opinion. Anyway, this is the battle portrayed in Shakespeare's "Henry V", in which the phrase "band of brothers" became famous. Fascinating detail of weaponry and military strategy that culminates in the battle in which the English were outnumberd 6-1, but prevailed. Bloodily. Considering "Road Warrior" and "Braveheart" are two of my favorite movies, I guess it's not too surprising that I liked this. Good side stuff -- bodice-ripping, revenge plays out against the history. If you are squeamish, however, this might not be your cup of tea.... ...more

title: The Wild Shore        (Three Californias Triptych, #1)
author: Robinson, Kim Stanley
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I had already read his Mars trilogy (Red Mars, Green Mars, and Blue Mars) and had liked them but had trouble at times with his didactic style/approachI had already read his Mars trilogy (Red Mars, Green Mars, and Blue Mars) and had liked them but had trouble at times with his didactic style/approach, even when I agreed with his point of view (which I don't always). However, this book was his first novel and I really liked it. It has a simplicity but is as powerful as anything else he has done. It is an interesting post-apocalyptic coming of age story about a group of teenagers and an old man who are part of a small fishing community eking out a subsistence living after America has been nuked. It was written in 1984 and has eerie resonance for events to come that have actually happened -- e.g. 9/11 and climate change for a couple of strong examples. If you like science fiction, I believe that you will like this book. Even if you don't as a general rule, his prose is very elegant and even poetic. It compares well with anything Cormac McCarthy has written, and while dark, he doesn't have the unrelenting grimness that overwhelmed me in reading McCarthy's The Road....more

title: In the Woods        (Dublin Murder Squad, #1)
author: French, Tana*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was a pretty good book, but my expectations were really high, so it suffered somewhat from that. It is a psychological thriller that is not totalThis was a pretty good book, but my expectations were really high, so it suffered somewhat from that. It is a psychological thriller that is not totally satisfying. However, the prose is wonderful, if a bit dense. Example: the protagonist's explanation of his reluctance to try hypnosis to recover some repressed memories:"I'm deeply suspicious of anything with a whiff of the New Age about it -- not because of the practices themselves, which as far as I can tell from a safe distance may well have a lot to them, but because of the people who get involved, who always seem to be the kind who corner you at parties to explain how they discovered that they are survivors and deserve to be happy. I worry that I might come out of hypnosis with that sugar-high glaze of self-satisfied enlightment, like a seventeen-year-old who's just discovered Kerouac, and start proselytizing strangers in pubs." Stuff like that really resonates with me, I'm slightly ashamed to say...On one hand, it was slow going for a lot of the book -- just requires you to pay attention so not an "easy" read. On the other it contains amazing character studies, and beautiful and atmospheric descriptions of places and emotions. Probably a book to savor more than I was able to devote to it. This author is very skilled -- I just think I was looking for something a little lighter in this genre than it turned out to be....more

title: People of the Book
author: Brooks, Geraldine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think this is really a 4-star, but I went to Bosnia in 2005 so this had a lot of resonance for me. This is a nice piece of historical fiction about I think this is really a 4-star, but I went to Bosnia in 2005 so this had a lot of resonance for me. This is a nice piece of historical fiction about the Sarajevo haggadah (which is a real prayer book). Brooks uses actual known facts about the haggadah's travels and origins to weave this story of its creation and perilous journey to the present day. The protagonist is a hard-nosed antisocial archeologist who I really liked...I'm not sure what that says about me, but there it is. In her effort to conserve, NOT restore (a difference she explains VERY clearly), the haggadah, she comes across clues to its past and the book bounces you back to the time of the origin of the clue and then back to (semi) present day events. I like her style of writing, and she has SO much knowledge about world history and events -- as an almost throwaway aside, she covers a fair amount of Australian terrain and aboriginal history just because the protagonist is Australian, and for no other good reason I could discern. But I really liked the Australian bits. (Added Note: now I know that Brooks grew up in Australia from looking around online, it makes a bit more sense.)It kept nagging me that the author's name was familiar so I finally looked her up online and realized she wrote another book (Nine Parts of Desire) I really appreciated for its exposition on Islam and women -- for instance, I read Reading Lolita in Tehran, but I thought Brooks' book, Nine Parts of Desire, was a much better and interesting set of observations on the real hows and whys and whats that Muslim women in the middle east face.I think I am definitely going to read more Geraldine Brooks.......more

However, that said, this woman writes really well and has a great sense of humor and observational style. I really enjoyed the first part of the book (eating in Italy), had trouble with the second part (praying in India) and barely read any of the last part (love in Bali). I just wanted to be done with the book at that point.I think it is worth picking up and thumbing through it to see if you would like it, because like I said, I know lots of people would love this book. review: This is a direct lift from someone else who read this book -- it so described it for me, I thought I'd share...."I feel like John le Carre is thought This is a direct lift from someone else who read this book -- it so described it for me, I thought I'd share...."I feel like John le Carre is thought of as the grand old man of spy fiction. But his books really aren't what I tend to think of when I think of spy novels--they're always about world-weary bureaucrats doing grubby things that they know better than to be doing, about sad beat-up men whose best efforts generally just bring them, and everyone around them, more sadness. title: Tooth and Claw
author: Walton, Jo*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was truly surprised by this book. I read some serious nonfiction, plenty of fiction (including "literature"), and occaisionally young adult stuff suI was truly surprised by this book. I read some serious nonfiction, plenty of fiction (including "literature"), and occaisionally young adult stuff such as Eragon (dragon novel about 16 year old boy-hero). I was expecting this to be an easy-read fantasy about dragons. I was wrong.This is an amazing book, and I can't categorize it as "young adult" although maybe they would like it for its action. What it really is is an allegory for gender and class politics -- dragons with Victorian sensibilities who are oh-so-proper, until they aren't (such as when the patriarchs die and they eat their bodies)....The "Tooth and Claw" reference is from a Tennyson poem and after finishing the book, a remarkable poem. Before I read the book, I sort of liked the visuals created by Tennyson's words, but after reading, I could almost not stop laughing!If you are up for something different, this is wonderful (and DIFFERENT)!!...more

review: This is an amazing book. Extrememly deep and textured. I guess you'd call it a thriller and a murder mystery. It took me a while to get into it, becauThis is an amazing book. Extrememly deep and textured. I guess you'd call it a thriller and a murder mystery. It took me a while to get into it, because it was written by a Swedish author and tranlated into British English. I had to adapt a sort of European sensibility, because the cultural and geographic references are off from my usual American-centric reading. Also, some of the idioms are not quite right...But it is worth the adapting. This is a complicated story of industrial/criminal/economic intrigue and its protagonists, particularly the title character are very unusual.A financial reporter of good reputation is found guilty of libel, and in the wake of his trial he is hired by a mysterious industrialist to find out what happened to his niece thirty-six years ago when she disappeared. The girl with the dragon tattoo helps him solve the mystery and get his reputation back.It is clever and well written. It is definitely worth sticking out the first 50 pages or so....more

title: Kindred
author: Butler, Octavia E.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Liked the book, would have loved it if I had read it 20 years ago. Book was written in 1970's and feels a bit dated. The observations about race and gLiked the book, would have loved it if I had read it 20 years ago. Book was written in 1970's and feels a bit dated. The observations about race and gender are still powerful, but 2008 is pretty different from 1976. However, the comparisons between the status of blacks in the 19th century (in the south, pre-Civil War) to 2008 (or 1976) are still pretty valid. I read a lot of scifi, but this only uses a convention of scifi (time travel) as a plot device and never attempts to explain how it happens, etc. Nonetheless, the point is to explore a modern (1976 California) black woman's experiences when transported back in time to an 1815 plantation in Maryland, and that is undeniably powerful. If you can get past that (and I can because one of my favorite-of-all-time series is Outlander which uses exactly the same device to send a "modern" woman back to 18th century Scotland), you will enjoy this book. It is painful and enlightening. I only wish I had read this 20 years ago....more

title: The Fiery Cross        (Outlander, #5)
author: Gabaldon, Diana*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Re-reading my way through the series. While I hugely enjoyed them the first time, I think I am enjoying them even more this time around, especially thRe-reading my way through the series. While I hugely enjoyed them the first time, I think I am enjoying them even more this time around, especially the later ones, such as this one. The first time through, I was so enthralled with Jamie and Claire that I was actually impatient with the "side" stories of Roger and Brianna, and in fact, was pretty annoyed with Brianna most of the time. This time through, I am enjoying them as characters in their own right. Also, I am realizing that there were a number of plot threads that I gave short shrift to, which now are much more meaningful. As I move to the next two volumes, however, I have a different worry. I originally read the books in print form. On the re-reading, I have done them all in e-book form. Now, as I move on to "A Breath of Snow and Ashes" and "An Echo in the Bone", I actually own them in hardcover, and I've gotten spoiled by not having to lug them around. It will be a good test for me. I once had trouble believing that I would ever enjoy reading in electronic form, and now I'm dreading print. (Mostly because of the size of these books, however. That isn't generally true of other more modestly [say, less than 1000 pages] sized books....)But before I go on with Jamie and Claire, I'll take a break with either Elmore Leonard or Michael Connelly. Decisions, decisions......more

Writing is elegant and spare, and the core mystery is revealed as the layers are peelI was really looking forward to this book, but was disappointed. Writing is elegant and spare, and the core mystery is revealed as the layers are peeled back. This author is a master, but I don't like what he has to say. While richly detailed, the picture is bleak and hopeless. I need a bit more redemption or salvation than this offers.......more

review: Just listened to audio version narrated by Sissy Spacek. Still stunning, still wonderful use of time, place, and characters to tell a story about the Just listened to audio version narrated by Sissy Spacek. Still stunning, still wonderful use of time, place, and characters to tell a story about the best and the worst in us. There may be a better American novel, but none comes to mind. Innocence and evil, and most of all, courage. Atticus Finch is a man for all seasons....more
